DOC.HEAD: Legislators in No Rush to Hit Campaign Trail
DOC.TEXT: At a recent House Democratic leadership meeting, lawmakers were asked to raise their hands if they were eager to adjourn and hit the campaign trail back home. Nobody did. In fact, one member joked: ``We want to be held hostage here, and don't pay any ransom,'' according to one official who attended the closed-door session. The show of hands and the comment that followed were in a lighthearted vein, but they spoke a serious truth: incumbents are finding Washington a good place to ride out the election-season budget storm. ``It's easier to campaign here, doing your work in Washington, than out on the stump,'' said Rep. David Bonior, a Michigan Democrat who faces a stiff re-election challenge. ``I prefer to be doing my job, what the people sent me here to do.'' This year there's a new survival strategy for incumbents: stay in Washington, keep your nose to the grindstone, appear to be above politics and stay in touch through television and radio advertising and news coverage. It is a congressional variant of the Rose Garden strategy sometimes used by incumbent presidents. Such an approach not only keeps challengers at bay, but angry voters as well; members of Congress can avoid the prospect of facing boos and angry interrogation at live public events. Incumbents are not anxious to return home while the government is in crisis, particularly when the government is being shut down and President Bush is laying the blame on Congress. A measure of the public discontent came when vandals spray-painted ``Cut Taxes, Deficit'' and ``Repeal - Stolen Pay Raise'' on the house of House Republican Leader Robert Michel in Peoria, Ill. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., bristled when asked Monday about the budget standoff, another sign of the heat it has generated for lawmakers. ``The president often takes the stance of standing aside as if he's not a participant in these budget negotiations, as if it's somehow a congressional activity,'' he said. Thumping his desk for emphasis, Foley added: ``It was the presidential veto (earlier this month) that shut down the government. He bears full responsibility for that, and he will bear full responsibility'' if it happens again. The threat of another government shutdown this weekend, together with a general anti-incumbent mood and a sparse list of accomplishments for the 101st Congress, has made home a less-than-hospitable place for lawmakers. ``They're pretty darn vitriolic,'' said a senior Midwestern Republican. He said constituents were calling his office and screaming epithets at his staff. A legislator whose image is beamed home in the televised House floor proceedings might think, ``Shoot, I can make more points here doing this,'' said the congressman, who requested anonymity. ``And besides, if he's getting challenged to debate his opponent, it's a good excuse not to.'' That feeling is not universal. Rep. George Brown, D-Calif., who many regard as among the most endangered incumbents this year, has been thrashed by challenger Bob Hammock for missing important budget votes while out campaigning. ``I can't be in both places at the same time, so I have to make tough choices,'' Brown countered. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, who is running for governor of California, also has been chastised for missing votes. His Democratic opponent, Dianne Feinstein, said of Wilson: ``If he's not going to do his duty, then he should resign his job in the United States Senate.'' In other cases, the campaigns have simply moved to Washington. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., and his Democratic challenger, Paul Wellstone, held a debate Sunday night in a studio set up at Washington's National Press Club. It was beamed back to Minnesota by satellite. But those cases seem to be the exception, and the new mood is a pronounced switch from past years. In 1986, Republicans blamed their loss of the Senate on incumbents being held too long in Washington and away from the campaign trail. One senior congressional official said there traditionally are two schools of thought as Election Day approaches - those with tight races who want to go home and campaign, and those who are not threatened and say, ``What's the rush?'' ``Now there's a third school of thought,'' the official said. ``Those who have a tough race, and say, `What's the rush?''' The official added: ``Until we finish the budget and a couple of important pieces of legislation, we don't want to be adjourned.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Keeps Stealth Bomber Alive, Passes Defense Spending Bill
DOC.TEXT: Congressional proponents of the B-2 stealth bomber are breathing easier after the Senate narrowly rejected an attempt to stop production of the radar-evading aircraft. ``We had to have it,'' Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee and a B-2 proponent, said Monday night after the Senate approved a $268 billion defense spending bill. By a 50-44 vote, the Senate rejected an amendment that would have halted production of the stealth aircraft at six planes - far short of the 75 that President Bush is seeking at a cost of nearly $865 million each. Backers of the Northrop-built bomber argued that a plane that can penetrate Soviet air defenses is still needed because of uncertainty over the future leadership of the Kremlin. The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., also pointed out that a predecessor of the B-2 - the B-1B bomber - has failed to meet Pentagon performance standards. He urged his colleagues not to abandon the stealth capability. ``Opponents do not understand we're talking about revolutionary technology,'' Nunn said. But the opponents complained that in the post-Cold War era, a nation on the verge of economic ruin cannot afford to buy a bomber geared toward the Soviet Union. ``There is a threat to the nation greater than the Soviet air defense,'' said Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark. Rejection of the amendment came as House and Senate negotiators on a military authorization bill pushed to complete a final blueprint for the current fiscal year, with the B-2 bomber the main point of contention. Defeat of the B-2 in the Senate ``would have taken the big thrust out of the argument for any continuation,'' said Rep. Bill Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee. Shortly after the B-2 vote, the Senate overwhelmingly approved the military spending package that meets the levels set forth in the budget resolution approved by Congress. The legislation, adopted 79-16, trims about $1 billion from Bush's $4.7 billion request for the Strategic Defense Initiative and cuts the number of U.S. troops by 100,000, including 50,000 in Europe. The spending bill also includes $238 million for the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft Bush has sought to cancel during the past two years; eliminates $1.1 billion the Pentagon sought for the MILSTAR communications satellite and scales back the administration's request for land-based nuclear missiles. The bill includes about $500 million for the MX missile and $200 million for the planned Midgetman missile as well as funds for one SSN-21 Seawolf submarine. Negotiators for the Senate and the House, which had passed a defense spending bill earlier, will meet to thrash out a final version, with an aim to wrap up the legislation by week's end before Congress adjourns for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Plans Will Hit Consumers; Congress Nears Votes
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: If you're a college student, your school may no longer be eligible for certain government-backed loans. If you're a wheat farmer, your federal subsidies will shrink. If you're a veteran, your benefits will be less generous. The deficit-reduction legislation Congress plans to vote on this week will hit home all across America. And it's not only in the bigger bite the Internal Revenue Service will take - although that's likely to sting, too. Congressional votes on budget-cutting packages were expected to begin as early as today. The competing measures aim at slicing the federal deficit over the next five years by about $500 billion, including $40 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The plans range from a measure written by House Democrats that is top-heavy with higher taxes on the wealthy, to a House Republican plan that slashes spending and relies only lightly on new levies. In the Senate, the leaders of both parties are united behind a package that would make the rich pay more but also would double the gasoline tax. ``This is where members put their money where their mouth is,'' said the House Budget Committee chairman, Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif. The votes will be painful ones for members because just three weeks from Election Day, they will be considering packages that mean higher tax bills and reduced federal services for the public. The 33 million elderly and handicapped people enrolled in the Medicare program will feel the pinch in several ways. The $75 they must pay each year in doctors' bills before the government begins picking up the tab would increase to $150 next year under the Senate bill, $100 under the House Democratic plan. And the $28.60 they pay each month for doctors' coverage would increase by 1995 to $46.50 monthly under the House Democratic plan, $47 by 1995 in the Senate package. All Americans who are sick could see their bills increase because the reimbursements doctors and hospitals receive for treating Medicare patients will be held to below the rate of inflation. With their federal reimbursements reduced, doctors and hospitals could be forced to pass their costs on to all patients. The government limits the ability of health care providers to boost costs for Medicare recipients. Farmers also would be hit. Lawmakers would reduce acreage eligible for crop subsidies by 15 percent for each farmer beginning in 1992. And subsidies would be cut in another way: by changing the formula by which farmers receive payments when market prices are low. The five subsidized crops are wheat, corn, feed grains, rice and cotton. Veterans would see many benefits restricted. They would no longer be automatically considered disabled - and therefore eligible for higher payments - at age 65. And they would have to contribute $2 for prescriptions paid for by the government. The Guaranteed Student Loan program, which serves 3 million students in colleges, graduate and technical schools, would also have new limits. Loans would no longer be available at the approximately 1,000 schools where more than 35 percent of past loans have defaulted. The banks that make federally backed loans would receive slightly less interest from the government, which probably would make fewer loans availabl. And for all but the poorest Americans, the tax bite will get deeper under the House Democratic plan, according to Congress' Joint Committee on Taxation. People with incomes under $20,000 would see their taxes drop slightly, but people earning more than $200,000 annually would have to absorb a 7.4 percent increase. Americans in between would see increases in the 1 percent range. The changes would be a result of higher taxes on alcohol and tobacco; giving up next year's income tax adjustment to offset inflation, and raising the amount of wages subject to the Medicare tax. The Senate plan would reduce taxes slightly for people earning less than $20,000; raise taxes by just under 3 percent for families in the $20,000-to-$50,000 income range; increase them 1.9 percent for those between $50,000 and $75,000 and boost them 3.5 percent for those between $100,000 and $200,000. The $200,000-plus group would pay 3.7 percent more. Other measures affecting consumers would: -End, for five years, the option that civil service retirees have to receive their benefits in a lump sum. People over age 64 with 30 years of service would be exempted. -Impose a $1 fee on aircraft or ship passengers entering the United States, including returning Americans, except for those traveling from Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean or U.S. possessions. -Increase U.S. Patent Office fees for items such as patent applications. -Boost fines for violations of labor safety laws.

DOC.TEXT: Rock guitarist Carlos Santana has accused the Miller Brewing Co. of mimicking without authorization his rendition of ``Black Magic Woman'' in a TV commercial. The lawsuit filed Monday alleges Miller and its New York ad agency, Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., violated trademark law in the commercial for Miller Lite Beer. Santana's lawyer, David Phillips, said damages may surpass $1 million. The lawsuit claims the brewer knowingly used an ``imitation of Santana's distinctive guitar playing.'' Last year, singer Bette Midler was awarded $400,000 after suing an advertising agency for using a soundalike in a 1986 car commercial. Although Santana did not write ``Black Magic Woman,'' the lawsuit said, the public considers it his ``theme song.'' Peter Green of Fleetwood Mac wrote the 1970 hit. Miller spokesman Steve Forsythe said the brewer had no comment. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Andie MacDowell, the repressed young wife in ``sex, lies and videotape,'' flinches at the possibility of becoming a superstar. ``I like doing normal things, like going to Disney World with my family. And it would be terrible not to be able to because of fame,'' MacDowell said in the November issue of Glamour magazine. MacDowell, who was a top model before landing her first role in ``Greystoke,'' lives in a Victorian house in upstate New York with her husband, model Paul Qualley, son Justin, 4, and daughter Rainey, 18 months. She said if she weren't an acress she would be ``a mother and a gardener.'' ``I've got a huge vegetable garden, everything from arugula to broccoli, to corn to sunflowers,'' she said. She has two new movies coming out soon: ``The Object of Beauty,'' with John Malkovich and ``Green Card'' with Gerard Depardieu. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Fans snapped up tickets for Bruce Springsteen's first formal concert in two years in just 45 minutes. About 4,500 tickets were sold for the Nov. 16 show, said spokesman Brian Fenske of the 6,300-seat Shrine Auditorium. The $100, $50 and $25 tickets went on sale Sunday. The remaining tickets went to the non-profit Christic Institute and weren't for sale. The concert with Bonnie Raitt and Jackson Browne will raise money for the institute, which is waging a lawsuit accusing the United States of involvement in the drug trade. ``We are not surprised,'' said the Rev. William Davis, the group's West Coast director. ``Bruce and the other artists are very popular and it will give great visibility to the issues that are involved.'' Springsteen's last formal concert appearance was during the 1988 Amnesty International world tour. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Ed Begley Jr. says he's been into recycling since 1970 and recently refused a ride in an NBC limousine during a promotional tour for his new TV series, ``Parenthood.'' Instead, Begley said in the November issue of Redbook, he rode his bike from his San Fernando Valley home to the Century City studio. ``It's late. But it's not too late,'' said the former ``St. Elsewhere'' star, who is on the boards of seven environmental organizations and recycles everything from newspapers to metal products. ``People have to realize that they can turn this around quicker than they think. How? By exercising their voting power and their purchasing power.''

DOC.HEAD: Huge Cocaine Bust; About 1,900 Pounds Seized
DOC.TEXT: In a raid on a rural drug refuge, the army arrested more than 100 alleged traffickers, seized about 1,900 pounds of pure cocaine, discovered huge coca fields and destroyed laboratories, an army official said. The cocaine seized in Monday's operation near Colombia's northern coast was hidden among cargo bags and ready to be exported to the United States, said regional army commander Col. Carlos Castro. He said troops destroyed six cocaine-processing laboratories, arrested 103 suspected drug traffickers and found nearly 5,000 acres of coca leaf, the raw material used to make cocaine. Soldiers also seized 30 vehicles, all with Venezuelan license plates, which had been used to transport drugs, Castro said. Also confiscated were cocaine- processing chemicals and a cache of weapons, he said. The bust was considered one of the year's most important. So far in 1990 security forces have confiscated about 45 tons of cocaine, compared to 33 tons in all of 1989. Colombia's Medellin and Cali cocaine cartels supply most of the cocaine consumed in the United States. The coca leaf is mostly grown in Bolivia and Peru, then processed in Colombia. The Medellin cartel has been blamed for a long series of terrorist attacks in which at least 550 people have died in the past 14 months.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Compromise on NEA Obscenity Issue
DOC.TEXT: A House-approved, $11.9 billion appropriations bill heads to the Senate today with a compromise plan aimed at settling a bitter controversy over the National Endowment for the Arts' subsidy of allegedly obscene works. For the second time in less than a week, the House voted Monday to scrap strict anti-obscenity curbs on the NEA and let the courts decide whether federally supported arts projects are obscene. The plan, drafted by Reps. Pat Williams, D-Mont., and E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., says obscenity ``shall not be funded'' by the endowment. It would require grant recipients to repay the government if they are convicted of violating obscenity laws. A new provision in the money bill, which finances several federal agencies and provides $180 million to the endowment, would require NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer to eliminate his requirement that grant winners sign a non-obscenity pledge. That rule has been strongly criticized by the arts community and its supporters. The Williams-Coleman plan would replace restrictions that Congress slapped on the NEA a year ago at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who was angered by endowment support for an exhibition of sexually explicit works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. Helms' amendment prohibited the NEA from supporting any works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homosexual or sadomasochistic activity or sexual exploitation of children. The Williams-Coleman compromise attached to the appropriations bill was identical to a separate measure that the House approved last Thursday when it authorized extending the NEA's statutory authority for three years. Both measures were sent to the Senate, where a similar but simpler bill favoring a judicial approach to the ``obscene art'' controversy is awaiting floor action. It is unusual for the entire contents of an authorization bill to be attached to an appropriations bill and approved by the House. But Williams said the parliamentary maneuver was necessary to enhance the prospects for final congressional approval of the NEA measure. Williams said there was ``little, if any, chance'' that the previously approved authorization bill would survive in the waning days of an election-year Congress that is mired in a budget crisis. He noted that a high-priority appropriations bill stands a much greater chance of passage than the NEA authorization bill. ``This will assure, I hope, that something that the House wants in this very divisive matter reaches the president's desk and becomes law,'' Williams said. The money bill containing the NEA provisions passed the House on a 327-80 roll call vote. It includes $180 million in arts endowment spending in the new fiscal year that began Oct. 1, a 5 percent increase from the NEA's $171 million budget last year. Before the final vote, the House approved the Williams-Coleman plan, 234-171, as a substitute for a more strongly worded proposal by Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, and ratified the bipartisan compromise on a 342-58 roll call. Regula's amendment would have forbidden the endowment to subsidize obscene or indecent works and ordered the NEA chairman to ensure that federally supported works ``are appropriate for a general audience.'' The measure contains billions more for the Interior Department, the Forest Service, some Energy Department programs, Indian education and health services, the Smithsonian Institution and other federal agencies. The bill also includes a one-year moratorium on exploring for oil and gas in federal waters in many areas off New England, the East Coast, Florida, California, the Pacific Northwest and Alaska. The House also approved, 251-155, a proposal by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., to increase grazing fees on public lands by 500 percent over the next four years. The plan, supported by environmental interests, was heatedly opposed by Western lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Drops Demand for End to All Trade-Distorting Farm Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration no longer is demanding that all farm subsidies that distort world trade be eliminated by the end of the century, but critics question whether the change undermines an effort to boost U.S. agricultural exports. U.S. negotiators on Monday offered a compromise proposal aimed at breaking a deadlock that has threatened to scuttle a four-year effort to reform the global trading system. The administration said it would seek agreement from other countries to cut farm export subsidies by 90 percent and farm income supports by 75 percent over the next 10 years. Previously, the United Stateshad sought total elimination of trade-distorting agricultural subsidies by the year 2000. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter insisted that the administration remained committed to an ultimate goal of eliminating all such subsidies but felt the new proposal represented a good first step and would help to end a negotiating stalemate. ``Ninety percent reform is certifiably better than no reform and if this process fails, we are going to have no reform,'' Yeutter told reporters Monday. But some critics questioned whether the United States, by signaling a willingness to bargain on the percentage of subsidy elimination, was opening the possibility that it will have to settle for a good deal less than even 90 percent. They noted that the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc that is fighting the hardest to retain its subsidy program, is considering offering a negotiating position to trim farm income supports by just 30 percent while leaving its export programs basically untouched. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of a Senate Finance subcommittee overseeing trade issues, said the administration's latest offer embraced ``the dangerous concept of percentage reductions in agricultural support'' rather than insisting on total elimination. ``Since the European Community already subsidizes its agricultural sector substantially more than does the United States, a 75 percent reduction by both the United States and the EC would leave European farmers with a substantial advantage,'' Baucus said. The fight over farm subsidies has threatened to scuttle an ambitious four-year effort to overhaul the world trading system. The talks, being held under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are due to conclude in 50 days with a marathon bargaining session in Brussels. President Bush has made successful conclusion of the discussions his top trade priority but he has threatened to walk away if the United States does not prevail on the farm subsidy question. The administration believes that the trade negotiation, known as the Uruguay Round, offers the best chance for boosting export sales by American farmers and businesses and thus reducing annual trade deficits that have topped $100 billion for six consecutive years. Agriculture is just one of 15 areas being negotiated. The U.S. team is pushing an ambitious agenda that also calls for dismantling barriers to trade in services, a high-growth area where American companies are extremely competitive; and a crackdown on copyright piracy, estimated to cost American companies $60 billion annually. But agriculture is seen as the key to the talks because Third World countries have balked at agreeing to U.S. proposals on removing barriers to trade in services and strengthening copyright enforcement unless they win expanded markets for their farm products. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said that in addition to the new proposal on agriculture, the administration will unveil a proposal, probably this week, on changes needed to lift restrictions on access to markets.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Investigating Beef Industry's `Big Three' Firms
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee is investigating whether the domination of cattle slaughtering by three corporations is hurting farmers and consumers. The House Government Operations subcommittee on information, justice and agriculture is gathering testimony on all aspects of the beef business from the Agriculture and Justice departments, economists, farmers, meat industry representatives and members of Congress. ``There is a huge dispute over whether the so-called `Big Three' is a market-driven concept or whether the `Big Three' is driving the market to its own advantage,'' said Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va., the subcommittee chairman. ConAgra Inc., IBP Inc. and Excel Corp., have dominated the beef industry since the early 1980s. About 24 percent of the business from the raising of cattle to the delivery of carcasses to butcher shops is owned by the three companies, a subcommittee aide said. ``The subcommittee intends to look at the regulatory and legislative aspects of meatpacking concentration from both an antitrust and agricultural point of view,'' said Wise. He said the panel would also investigate allegations that lack of competition in the industry is leading to lower wages and higher injury rates for employees in the plants. ---

Legislation requiring federal inspection of seafood is expected to be debated on the floor of the House this week. However, three bills, with inspection responsibilities assigned to different agencies, have been voted out of three committees. The House Rules Committee was to decide today which bill would be the main vehicle for debate. The other two were expected to be offered as amendments. Floor action would be later in the week. Congress has been in general agreement that seafood inspection must be strengthened, but House members have not been able to agree which agency should do it. One bill would give the job to the Agriculture Department, the second would assign it to the Food and Drug Administration and the third would split the responsibility between the FDA and the Commerce Department. Last month, the Senate unanimously approved legislation that places inspection responsibilities with USDA. ``If the House of Representatives lets the enactment of a mandatory, federal seafood inspection fail due to its own paralysis, then the list of those real victims who have suffered and died from eating contaminated, uninspected seafood will grow longer,'' said Ellen Haas, executive director of Public Voice for Food and Heath Policy. Haas, who has been working for years to get Congress to act on this issue, praised the Senate bill as ``a strong bill with many important public health protections.'' Currently, seafood is inspected on mostly a voluntary basis. Some states have their own programs and a limited service is offered by the FDA. ``Contaminated fish poses a real health threat to consumers,'' said Haas. ``Finfish feed on bacteria-laden algae and shellfish filter-feed water contaminated with sewage, increasing the risk of illness to consumers.'' ---

Phil Sokolof, president of the National Heart Savers Association, is pressuring the Senate through full-page newspaper advertisements to take a floor vote on a nutrition-labeling bill before Congress adjourns for the year. With adjournment, any legislation that has not been acted upon will die. Sokolof, a multimillionaire businessman from Omaha, Neb., said Monday he spent $350,000 of his own money for ads calling for action. ``Americans desperately need this bill enacted into law so they can make the informed choices necessary to lead healthier lives,'' said Sokolof's ad in The Washington Post. The House already approved a bill that would set specific standards for labeling a food ``lite'' or ``low-fat.'' It also outlines the nutritional information that must be on packaged food with requirements on how it must be displayed. Sokolof also has used full-page newspaper ads to attack practices leading to high cholesterol content in foods: use of tropical oils by food processors and beef fat for frying by certain chain restaurants. Two years ago, tropical oils, such as cocoanut and palm oil, were used widely in processed food, but today manufacturers are making known that their products are free of the substance. Restaurant companies attacked by Sokolof are now advertising they fry their potatoes in vegetable oil. Whether the ads will pay off this time remains to be seen. Late Monday, it hadn't been placed on the Senate agenda.

DOC.HEAD: Design-Your-Own-Degree School Celebrates 20th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Hampshire College, the design-your-own-degree school founded when the Summer of Love was still a warm memory, turns 20 this year, having survived the greed-is-good '80s. Graduates and administrators of the school, which still has no course credits, grades or tenure, say that's a testament to Hampshire's staying power. ``We are certainly a long way from the '60s now,'' said filmmaker Ken Burns, a 1975 graduate whose Civil War documentary recently won acclaim on public television. When it opened, Hampshire was a bold experiment, the brainchild of a group of educators from nearby Smith, Amherst and Mount Holyoke colleges and the University of Massachusetts. Its motto: ``To Know is Not Enough.'' From its first class of 175, the school has grown to about 1,200. Tuition, meanwhile, has grown from about $4,800 in 1970 to more than $20,000. ``I think Hampshire's shown an enormous amount of courage in staying the course,'' said 1977 graduate Aaron Lansky, who credits the adventurous spirit of Hampshire with helping inspire him to create the National Yiddish Book Center, now the world's largest collection of Yiddish works. Hampshire, which has also produced nine Oscar nominees and two winners, has always had shock value, with its coed dormitories, grade-less classes and the story of the graduate who wrote his thesis on the aerodynamics of the Frisbee. Graduates say it wasn't all freewheeling fun. ``This whole thing of Frisbee U and kind of the hippie school thing has gotten blown out of proportion,'' Burns said. ``I never worked harder than I did at Hampshire College in all my life.'' At Hampshire, there are just pass-fail designations on a series of exams. Students must pass through three divisions. In Division I, a student must demonstrate a rudimentary grasp of the concepts of the four schools of Humanities and Arts, Social Science, Communications and Cognitive Science and Natural Science. In Division II, courses must be organized around a particular theme. In Division III, a student turns in a project equivalent to a thesis. Competition to get into those early classes was fierce. ``There was a sense that we were making history, that we had pioneered a whole new way of approaching education that wasn't based on processing individuals through a kind of assembly-line method of teaching,'' said Burns, who has twice been nominated for an Academy Award for his documentaries. Hampshire's slump came in the 1980s, when applications dropped and concern grew that unqualified students were being admitted. In response, the student body was cut from 1,200 to 900 and the school spent some of its $10 million endowment to operate. Perennial problems at Hampshire are faculty overload from what amounts to a tutorial system of education, attrition among students unable to cope with Hampshire's unorthodox ways, and money. The college depends on tuition and fees for much of its approximately $25 million annual budget. Financial stability is one of the goals of President Gregory Prince, who became Hampshire's fourth president in 1989. Recently, after a nine-day occupation of a dormitory in 1988 by students protesting what they perceived as indiference to minority issues, students and teachers were required to incorporate a Third World perspective into courses. Administrators say they won't relinquish Hampshire's experimental attitude. ``For a college like Hampshire, what an anniversary like this helps underscore is how much time is on our side,'' Prince said.

DOC.HEAD: Physicians Group Calls for Removal of Nukes from Persian Gulf
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: A Nobel-winning physicians' group is calling for the immediate removal from the Persian Gulf region of the more than 400 nuclear warheads it estimates are aboard U.S., British, French and Soviet warships in the area. The group, the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, appealed Monday toall parties in the Persian Gulf crisis to renounce the use of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. ``The gulf crisis presents an unprecedented threat of conflagration of a war with catastrophic consequences,'' said the group, which won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985. The physicians released their appeal in Rome following a three-day meeting in the northern Italian city of Prato. Among those attending were representatives from Israel, Jordan, Egypt and the Palestinian Red Crescent. The Red Crescent is the equivalent of the Red Cross in the Arab world. ``Our greatest fear is that if hostilities break out, there is a very real prospect that nuclear weapons would be utilized,'' said William W. Monning, executive director of the group, which is based in Cambridge, Mass. Monning released the details of a study predicting the consequences of a nuclear strike on Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. Under this scenario, dropping a single one-megaton nuclear bomb on the city would immediately kill 1 million people, or 23 percent of the population, and seriously injure another 1.28 million. The blast would kill 770 of the city's 3,080 physicians and incapacitate 920 others, leaving 1,400 doctors to care for the 1.28 million wounded, Monning said. The physicians presented their appeal to officials of the U.S., Soviet and Iraqi embassies in Rome. Monning said an American diplomat told the group the United States has no intention of starting a war or using nuclear weapons, while the Iraqi ambassador pledged his country would only use chemical or biological weapons in case of nuclear attack. The group offered to send a multinational team of doctors to Iraq, Egypt, Israel and Jordan to explain the possible effects of a nuclear war. About 40 doctors or representatives of medical associations attended the meeting, the first bringing together Israeli and Arab doctors to discuss the Middle East crisis, Monning said. The Palestinian Red Crescent was represented by its president, Fathi Arafat, brother of PLO chief Yasser Arafat. Hillel Schenker attended on behalf of the Israeli branch of the international physicians' group. No Kuwaiti delegate was able to attend. Two Iraqi doctors had planned to take part but were denied visas by the Italian government, Monning said. Iraq precipitated the gulf crisis with its Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. A U.S.-led multinational force has since massed in the Saudi Arabian desert and on ships in the region to counter Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Encephalitis Outbreak Claims First Fatality
DOC.TEXT: Florida health officials warned against trick-or-treating after dark on Halloween after an outbreak of encephalitis claimed its first confirmed fatality. St. Louis encephalitis is carried by a mosquito that feeds at dusk. A 58-year-old West Melbourne woman who died Saturday was identified on Monday as the first confirmed fatality of the outbreak. Authorities also awaited test results on a possible encephalitis death last month. Dr. Charls S. Mahan, state health officer, called on all Florida communities Monday to hold Halloween activities in the afternoon to reduce the risk of exposure. Thirty-four people in 15 counties across central and southern Florida have contracted St. Louis encephalitis since mid-August. Twenty-one others have shown positive results on the first of two tests needed for confirmation. The state usually has one to three cases a year. The death rate from St. Louis encephalitis typically is 7 percent. Eight people died in 1977 during the last Florida outbreak. Symptoms of the brain inflammation include headaches, a stiff neck, irritability, extreme sleepiness, tremors, seizures and coma. On Monday, the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services said Florida's first confirmed fatality was Alvena Patton, who had been in a coma since Aug. 21. ``The county needs to get serious about this virus,'' said her husband, Harry Patton. ``They need to get spray trucks out and try to stop this thing. I know it costs a lot of money, but people's lives are at stake.'' Mahan said that although mosquito eradication efforts have been increased, recent rains could prolong the mosquito population until drier and colder weather.

DOC.HEAD: Record Cocaine Haul In Mexican Drug Bust
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents raided two ranches in northern Mexico, seizing a record 5.9 tons of cocaine along with three small jet planes from Colombia and five trucks, the government said Monday. Sunday's seizure in Chihuahua state was the biggest ever made in Mexico, the Attorney General's office said in a news release. No arrests were reported. Minutes after five jet planes from Colombia had landed, about 60 members of the Federal Judicial Police raided a clandestine airfield in a ranch near Ciudad Jimenez, the government said. Two of the planes managed to take off, and a third crashed as it attempted to get airborne, but the pilot and several ground crewmen fled in pickup trucks after exchanging gunfire with police, the news release said. About two tons of cocaine, packed in bags, were seized there along with the vehicles, including a tank-truck loaded with jet fuel, it said. Several hours later, the agents acted on a tip and raided a second ranch nearby, seizing another 3.9 tons of cocaine apparently belonging to the same gang of drug smugglers, the release said.

DOC.HEAD: The East Could Get Hit With a Catastrophic Quake, Exert Says
DOC.TEXT: Easterners afraid to come to California because of earthquakes should consider the risks at home. New York, Boston and other Eastern cities are gambling with catastrophes far worse than last year's San Francisco-area earthquake if they don't prepare better for a major quake expected within 30 years, an expert said Monday. The prediction from Ian Buckle, deputy director of the National Center for Earthquake Engineering Research, shook up a national quake conference two days before the anniversary of the Oct. 17, 1989, quake here. ``The earthquake in the Bay area last year is the writing on the wall for the East,'' he told more than 300 scientists, government officials and engineers. ``This is a race against time, and the odds of winning do not look favorable.'' Seismologists at the U.S. Geological Survey estimate there is a 64 percent probability of a quake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale occurring somewhere in the East within the next 30 years. If that happens, hundreds of thousands of apartment buildings are in danger of collapsing, along with some bridges, roads and railroad passes, Buckle said. The result would be a huge number of deaths and injuries and tens of billions of dollars in damage, he said. New York City, hit hard by a quake in 1884, could get some of the worst damage because of its poor soil in Brooklyn and Queens, its dense population and thousands of older buildings of unreinforced masonry. If the 1884 quake - estimated at 5.9 on the Richter scale, much less severe than the 7.1 quake a year ago in the Bay area - were to occur again in New York it would cause $11 billion to $26 billion in damage, Buckle said a study has shown. Damage in the better prepared Bay area was estimated at $6 billion. ``And this is not thinking of fires because of broken water mains and the inability to control fires,'' said Buckle, a professor of civil engineering at the State University of New York in Buffalo. Skyscrapers, built to withstand wind shear, and long suspension bridges are less vulnerable, he said. Medium-height masonry buildings are common all along the Atlantic Seaboard, where moderate and strong quakes have been recorded over the past 200 years. Charleston was struck by a quake estimated at 7.5 magnitude in the 1800s and Boston had an estimated 7.0 in the 1700s. Buckle said that because of a growing awareness of the earthquake hazard in the East, some progress has been made. Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Jersey, New York City and Memphis, Tenn., have adopted or are close to adopting seismic provisions in their building codes. But he said that would affect only new structures. ``The retrofit of critical existing structures and lifelines must be undertaken without delay,'' he said. In addition, he said, ``The drop-and-cover rules that California schoolchildren are taught should be taught to schoolchildren in New York and along the Atlantic Seaboard.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Peace Prize: No Tongues Wagged Here
DOC.TEXT: To those Americans who shrugged at the news that Mikhail Gorbachev won the Nobel Peace Prize, some experts on U.S.-Soviet relations say: exactly right. That makes the point. ``We always said that they started the Cold War and it was up to them to end it,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, director of East-West studies at the Council on Foreign Relations. ``Now they've ended it. The Nobel prize simply recognizes that fact.'' Forty or 20 or 10 years ago, there'd be an uproar in America if the leader of the Soviet state had been singled out for the prize and the title of peacemaker. ``It would have been a slap at the United States and would have discredited the Nobel Peace Prize'' for a Soviet leader to have won it then, Mandelbaum said. But the revolution that Gorbachev made - the event that brought him the prize - made communism no longer much relevant in world affairs and the Cold War no longer a reality shaping every aspect of American life. ``I can't imagine anybody in this country would take it as a slap in the face today,'' said John Gaddis, a diplomatic historian at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio, of Gorbachev's singular honor. ``The things that were done in the Soviet Union last year were things only a Soviet leader could do, but they were things that we've been asking Soviet leaders to do since the beginning of the Cold War. So we can only applaud.'' For Gregory Treverton, senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and a former member of the staff of the National Security Council, the award raised questions about how long the honoree will be in office. Treverton said Gorbachev, like so many revolutionaries, may be consumed by the flames he lit. ``It's hard to believe that he will be around for too many more acts in the Soviet drama,'' said Treverton, alluding to the economic and nationalistic unrest in the Soviet empire. ``He's likely to go down as a man who set forces in motion and then was overwhelmed by them.'' Diplomat Winston Lord, who spent nearly three decades observing communist affairs at the State Department, Pentagon and White House and as Ronald Reagan's ambassador to China, said Gorbachev's honor reflects well on America, too. Without taking away credit from the Soviet leader, he said, it should be recognized that this country had a hand in persuading him to ring down the Iron Curtain and to curtail Stalinist repression and Marxist dogma at home. ``One can debate to what extent his own domestic problems plus Western firmness induced him to make the moves on the world scene that he's making,'' said Lord, ``but the fact is objectively he has helped make the world less tense. I believe the United States, including Presidents Reagan and Bush, deserves credit for these developments as well.'' If Americans shrugged at the news, Soviet citizens probably did too, said Lord. ``For many, Gorbachev is irrelevant'' and so are his foreign achievements at a time when Russians are short of bread and see their economic system is a state of disarray. ``The Soviets are preoccupied with their own problems,'' he said. A cautionary note was sounded by Helmut Sonnenfeld, a former associate of Henry Kissinger in the Nixon administration. Events will yet determine whether Gorbachev was a man who brought peace to his country, he said. ``It is a question of whether the Soviet Union dissolves in chaos or whether things improve,'' he said. ``Gorbachev's own role may be diluted if it turns out the people of the Soviet Union start fighting each other and, God forbid, nuclear weapons get set off.'' In the meantime, Sonnenfeld said, the world, in celebrating Gorbachev's prize, should not forget what 45 years of Cold War meant. ``A lot of people were treated miserably, a lot died, and we spent a huge amount of treasure and got involved in huge and costly wars,'' he said. ``That doesn't get swept under the rug.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Issues New Proposal on Corporate Fines
DOC.TEXT: Fines for corporate crimes should be based on the seriousness of the offense, rather than the amount of ill-gotten gain or the financial loss to victims, the Justice Department says. ``The system we are advocating will result in stiff corporate sanctions,'' said Paul L. Maloney, a deputy assistant attorney general who briefed reporters Monday. The department's position was contained in a letter to the U.S. Sentencing Commission, which is considering various ways to punish businesses convicted of crimes. The Sentencing Commission was set up in 1984 when Congress passed legislation aimed at ending disparity in sentences given to criminal defendants. The commission has set guidelines for individual defendants that are based on the severity of the offense and any aggravating or mitigating factors, such as a person's criminal history or acceptance of responsibility. The Justice Department shied away from its earlier proposal, in which companies involved in a massive fraud could be fined twice their gain or twice the loss to victims. ``We no longer believe that this alternative maximum fine is appropriate since it is inconsistent with the approach of basing the fine on the seriousness of the offense,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a letter to the commission. The department rescinded its earlier position on corporate sentences after receiving an inquiry from the White House, which had been lobbied heavily by business groups concerned about heavy fines. At the time, the attorney general said the views had been submitted without his knowledge or permission by then-Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer. The dispute with Ayer was one of several that contributed to his resignation last spring. After a lengthy review, the department reiterated its support Monday for basing fines on the severity of a crime. Such factors as the knowledge or participation of top management in a criminal scheme, the involvement of bribery, or a history of corporate misbehavior would determine the crime's severity and therefore the fine. Companies that promptly report wrongdoing of employees and cooperate with government prosecutions would receive lower fines. Corporate lawyer Victoria Toensing, who had argued against the earlier proposals, called the department's proposal ``a sensible approach.'' Calculating fines according to mitigating and aggravating factors would help distinguish between responsible companies whose employees go astray and firms whose executives don't care about observing the law, said Toensing, a former senior Justice Department official.

DOC.HEAD: `Marked for Death' Tops Again at the Box Office
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The martial-arts drama ``Marked for Death'' survived another week in first place at the box office with $7.4 million. The World War II film ``Memphis Belle'' soared into second with $5 million in its premiere engagement, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. The supernatural thriller ``Ghost'' was third with $4.2 million. Within two weeks or so, ``Ghost'' should pass the Cinderella comedy ``Pretty Woman'' to become the year's biggest moneymaker. ``Ghost'' has made $167.4 million, ``Pretty Woman'' $176.3 million. In 10th was ``Henry & June,'' the first film given the NC-17 rating instead of X. It made $1.4 million. Playing in limited release, writer-director Barry Levinson's autobiographical ``Avalon'' collected $201,574 for a spectacular per-screen average of $28,796 on seven screens. The film opens nationwide on Friday. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Marked for Death,'' 20th Century Fox, $7.4 million, 1,974 screens, $3,761 per screen, $21.7 million, two weeks. 2. ``Memphis Belle,'' Warner Bros., $5 million, 1,087 screens, $4,625 per screen, $5 million, one week. 3. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $4.2 million, 1,766 screens, $2,392 per screen, $167.4 million, 14 weeks. 4. ``Fantasia,'' Disney, $4 million, 481 screens, $8,308 per screen, $11.2 million, two weeks. 5. ``GoodFellas,'' Warner Bros., $3.7 million, 1,318 screens, $2,805 per screen, $27.1 million, four weeks. 6. ``Pacific Heights,'' 20th Century Fox, $3.6 million, 1,291 screens, $2,761 per screen, $19.3 million, three weeks. 7. ``Mr. Destiny,'' Disney, $3 million, 727 screens, $4,115 per screen, $3 million, one week. 8. ``Postcards From the Edge,'' Columbia, $2.2 million, 1,314 screens, $1,674 per screen, $30.8 million, five weeks. 9. ``Welcome Home, Roxy Carmichael,'' Paramount, $1.8 million, 635 screens, $2,762 per screen, $1.8 million, one week. 10. ``Henry & June,'' Universal, $1.4 million, 189 screens, $7,408 per screen, $2.8 million, two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Legend Finds He's Got a Race
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Mark Hatfield has been a force in Oregon politics for four decades, but the Republican now finds himself in a tough re-election fight after watching his comfortable lead plummet. Pouring on the pressure is businessman Harry Lonsdale, a staunch environmentalist waging a television ad campaign that portrays Hatfield as beholden to special interests. Hatfield is out of touch with Oregonians on timber and abortion issues, says Lonsdale. Lonsdale also has raised questions abou possible conflicts of interest by the senator's longtime chief of staff, Gerry Frank. The 67-year-old Hatfield, who is seeking a fifth term, wouldn't mention Lonsdale by name in the early going. Now he is fighting back with a vengeance. ``When people begin to attack your family and your friends, it demonstrates to me that they have no issues, no program and no vision,'' says Hatfield. ``It is negative campaigning at its foulest.'' Lonsdale says Hatfield is the negative campaigner. ``The guy paints himself as Mr. Clean, but, by God, he's just one more Washington insider,'' Lonsdale says. He calls the senator ``the imperial Mark Hatfield'' for refusing to debate. Hatfield says debates are political theatrics. He keeps in touch with voters by traveling extensively around the state, he says. ``Oregonians deserve a debate. We pay his salary,'' complains Lonsdale. Hatfield has never lost a political race and was regarded as invulnerable when the campaign began. The alarms went off when a poll late last month showed Hatfield's lead had fallen sharply. He led by six points in a survey carrying a margin of error of four percentage points. That was a surge of 16 points for Lonsdale since August. Hatfield said the latest poll ``has done for us what we couldn't do for ourselves. It has dispelled over confidence among our supporters.'' Hatfield's acceptance of campaign contributions from political action committees shows he's beholden to the rich and powerful, says Lonsdale, who plans to spend as much as $600,000 of his own money on the race. But Hatfield contends Lonsdale is being hypocritical about the campaign finance issue. As a wealthy businessman, Lonsdale can afford to make pious statements about not accepting special interest contributions, says the senator. Lonsdale, 58, runs a high-tech company employing about 80 people. ``He said very clearly that anybody who takes PAC money is on the take,'' Hatfield said. ``He's saying that rich people are the only ones who can be impartial. I think it's a phony accusation.'' The two also have clashed over timber supply issues. Hatfield said Lonsdale wants to prohibit all logging in old growth forests. ``He is supporting the basic concept of creating ghost towns in this state because he's going to lock up timber supply,'' Hatfield said. Lonsdale says Hatfield is siding with timber interests in opposing a ban on log exports from private lands. ``It's estimated that if we keep all the logs here, they'll provide 20,000 jobs in Oregon,'' Lonsdale said. Lonsdale also has hit Hatfield on the abortion issue, saying that Hatfield's opposition to abortion puts him at odds with largely pro-choice Oregonians. Hatfield said he is philosophically opposed to abortion and supports contraception and sex education programs to cut down on unwanted pregnancies. Lonsdale's questions about Frank center on the Hatfield aide's past position as a member of a savings and loan that later failed and on trips that he took at government expense.

DOC.HEAD: House Clean Air Negotiators Agree to Give Steel Industry a Break
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Talks scheduled to resume behind closed doors; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators are edging closer to an agreement to control toxic industrial pollution, one of the last hurdles to enactment of a clean air bill. A House proposal on air toxics was presented to the Senate late Monday after House members decided to give the steel industry more time to comply with the pollution controls. The House negotiating team had been divided on whether to accept the Senate proposal to give steel companies an additional 20 years - to the year 2020 - to fully comply with the measure. The House negotiators agreed Monday to a provision similar to the Senate plan. Congressional sources said the House and Senate were largely in agreement over the broad outline of the toxic section of the bill. The section on toxics, which requires industry to cut these emissions by more than 90 percent over the next 10 years, and another section on acid rain are the two major remaining issues. House-Senate conferees have been trying to craft a clean air bill since mid-July. The acid rain provisions would require electric utilities to cut annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons. Much of the debate over acid rain is expected to concern the division of pollution credits among utilities in various parts of the country. Midwest lawmakers also are pushing for a change in the base figures for calculating how much sulfur dioxide will have to be cut. They contend the current base figures will require emissions to be cut by substantially more than 10 million tons. The steel industry has argued that the proposed pollution control requirements will force the nation's coke ovens to shut down. Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, who fought for special treatment for the steel industry, said the industry would be faced with ``very, tough standards.'' Environmentalists have acknowledged that coke ovens will need more time to comply with the toxic emissions requirements, but opposed giving the steel industry special treatment beyond 2010. The conferees earlier reached agreement on urban smog controls, including pollution controls for industrial plants and automobiles as well as requiring the sale of cleaner-burning fuels in cities with the worst smog. Agreement also was reached to phase out chemicals that harm the atmospheric ozone layer and on timetables for cities to reach federal air quality requirements.

DOC.HEAD: President Visits Texas to Bolster GOP Ticket
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's four-hour fund-raising visit to Dallas put a fast $2 million into the pockets of two of the state's top Republican candidates - Clayton Williams and lieutenant governor hopeful Rob Mosbacher. ``What a team they will make in Austin,'' Bush said. The Texas stop was the first of a two-day political trip which also was taking him to Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois and Michigan. Bush said his presence at the two affairs at Dallas' Hyatt Regency Hotel was to show support for Williams, whom he called the next governor of Texas, and for Mosbacher, son of his commerce secretary, Robert Mosbacher.
DOC.HEAD: Traveling Americans Urged To Cast Absentee Ballots
DOC.TEXT: Americans who are on the road before the election should vote by absentee ballot, says a non-partisan foundation. All frequent travelers and those who think they might be away from home in early November should vote absentee if possible, says Vote America, a non-partisan foundation. Requirements and deadlines can vary from state to state. In all but two states, Oklahoma and New York, it is possible to vote early in person, at a designated location before Election Day.
DOC.HEAD: Muenster Campaign Running Low on Money
DOC.TEXT: Senate candidate Ted Muenster is running low on money going into the final weeks of his campai,075, she said. Muenster continues to rely heavily on labor unions to pay for his campaign.
DOC.HEAD: Republican Lawyer Files Cuomo Voting Charge
DOC.TEXT: A Republican lawyer is asking the state Board of Elections to investigate whether Gov. Mario Cuomo is illegally claiming New York City as his voting residence when he lives in Albany. The elections board was also asked Monday to probe whether Cuomo illegally voted by absentee ballot during the Sept. 11 Democratic primary when he was actually in New York City. Election law says absentee ballots can only be used when a person knows he's going to be out of the city on Election Day, says Thomas Spargo, who filed the complaint. In fact, he said, Cuomo was in New York City on the day of the primary. The complaint is an example of the ``hyper-technical silliness'' that Cuomo is trying to change by simplifying state election law, said Gary Fryer, Cuomo's press secretary. If Cuomo were convicted of intentional voting fraud, he could face one to four years in jail and up to $5,000 in fines, said David Flanagan, Board of Elections spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Sometimes You've Got to Spend Money to Save Money
With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While House members are trying to reduce the nation's massive deficit, they're also voting to authorize new spending for projects that are too politically appealing to resist. For instance, 15 bills approved by the chamber Monday would cost taxpayers about $3 billion over a number of years if the money is actually spent. But the appropriations are not guaranteed. All the bills were approved by voice vote. They included measures to help veterans, strengthen financial management in the federal government, protect the environment in Antarctica, create a new federal agency and help the disabled. The most expensive was the $2.6 billion Veterans' Compensation Amendments bill, which would provide a 4.5 percent cost-of-living increase for those with service-connected disabilities. The measure also would provide permanent disability benefits for Vietnam veterans who suffer health problems that resulted from exposure to Agent Orange, the herbicide used as a jungle defoliant. Another bill is designed to revise financial management systems in federal agencies and establish a U.S. chief financial officer. But in this case, you have to spend money to save money. Additional audits under the bill would cost $10 million a year. The potential savings have not been estimated. The House authorized $3 million for measures that would protect the environment in Antarctica. A $4 million authorization would give taxpayers a new International Cultural and Trade Center to create opportunities for U.S. trade, commerce, communications and cultural exchanges with other nations. It would be housed with other agencies in a new building at the Federal Triangle in Washington. Another $251 million would be authorized in new programs for education and training for the disabled.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Negotiators Note Progress by Japanese in Trade Changes
DOC.TEXT: U.S. negotiators are cautiously encouraged by Japan's progress in implementing an unusual agreement to attack the underlying causes of the huge trade imbalance between the two nations. The two countries began a two-day negotiating session on Monday aimed at reviewing the efforts made to put the agreement, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, into effect. Assistant Treasury Secretary Charles Dallara termed Monday's talks constructive and useful in exploring concerns of both nations in making sure the June agreement is implemented. ``You have to have these occasions so that one side can sense where the other side has its priorities,'' Dallara said in a telephone interview. The U.S. side said it raised questions in particular about Japanese spending proposals on public works projects, efforts to stiffen enforcement of anti-monopoly laws and plans to conduct pricing surveys aimed at determining how much Japanese consumers are being harmed by government policies that protect home industries. The talks, being held in Boston, were scheduled to conclude today. For their part, Japanese negotiators focused on the current gridlock over reducing the U.S. budget deficit, which Tokyo has targeted as a chief culprit in this country's poor trade performance. Many economists believe that government borrowing to finance the deficit drives up U.S. interest rates and thus makes it more expensive for American companies to raise the capital they need to modernize and become more competitive. A senior administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Japanese expressed concern about the failure so far of U.S. policy makers to reach agreement on a deficit-reduction plan. However, the official said, they were encouraged by the apparent willingness of the administration and Congress to consider raising taxes to close the gap. The official said U.S. negotiators were pleased to see initial steps by the Japanese to open up business opportunities for American and other foreign firms. But they believed much more progress needed to be made, particularly in eliminating the practice of keiretsu, the interlocking arrangements between Japanese companies that keep foreign firms out of the marketplace. This week's talks were to be followed by another session in early 1991 leading up to an interim status report expected in April or May. The administration is counting on the structural-impediments agreement to significantly reduce the trade deficit with Japan, which last year totaled $49 billion. Critics in Congress, however, question how long it will take to show results. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., said Monday that the Japanese have failed to live up to many past market-opening agreements. ``It is critical in this first round of talks to review (the initiative) that our negotiators emphasize that the United States expects Japan to fully implement all commitments made,'' he said. Baucus, who chairs a Senate trade subcommittee, said that where compliance was lacking, the administration must be prepared to use sections of U.S. law that permit economic retaliation if barriers are erected to prevent sales of American products. Among the commitments made by Japan in June were to increase public works spending, reduce the time it takes to issue patents and begin vigorous criminal enforcement against bid-rigging, price-fixing and other anti-competitive business practices. While past negotiations with the Japanese have sought access for specific American industries, the new talks sought to address fundamental problems in the American and Japanese economies that have contributed to the trade imbalance.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Comes Across As Anti-Washington Outsider
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Pre-noon lead likely
DOC.TEXT: A governmental insider for more than 20 years, President Bush comes across as an anti-Washington outsider as he campaigns for Republican candidates. At stops in Texas and Nebraska on Monday, Congress was the villain along with that ``inside-the-Washington, D.C., beltway jargon.'' More of the same was certain to follow today as Bush campaigns in Iowa, Illinois and Michigan. Iowa voters were not kind to Bush in 1988. They gave him an embarrassing third-place finish in the GOP presidential caucuses and then backed Democrat Michael Dukakis for president. Not one to accept rejection easily, Bush is asking Iowans to back his choices this November - Republican Gov. Terry Branstad and Rep. Tom Tauke, who is challenging Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin. In the latest Iowa poll published Sunday in the Des Moines Register, Branstad was leading his Democratic opponent, Don Avenson, by 19 percentage points. But the same survey said Harkin was 14 points ahead of Tauke. In Illinois, Bush hopes to give a critical boost to Jim Edgar, the GOP candidate for governor, who is in a close race with Democrat Neil Hartigan. Gov. James Thompson, a Republican, is not seeking re-election. But as in Iowa, the GOP prospects for upsetting an incumbent Democratic senator were not bright. Polls show GOP challenger Lynn Martin trailing well behind Sen. Paul Simon. Bush's last stop for the day was Michigan, where neither gubernatorial candidate John Engler or GOP Sen. challenger Bill Schuette were given more than long-shot chances of upsetting Democratic incumbents. It was hard to tell from his stump rhetoric that Bush has spent most of his adult life in such Washington insider jobs as Republican Party chairman, CIA director, U.N. ambassador and vice president. ``Oh, how nice it is to be out where the real people are, outside of Washington, D.C.,'' the president told a Republican audience in Omaha, where he raised $250,000 for Gov. Kay Orr. The GOP governor, who alienated many voters when she pushed for a tax increase after a no-new-taxes campaign, is trailing her Democratic opponent by eight percentage points in the most recent poll. ``What the states need is not more programs mandated from Washington, D.C., said the president. ``Texas and Texans have the solutions,'' he said in Dallas. ``Give Nebraskans a chance to solve the problems,'' he said in Omaha. ``I honestly believe,'' said the president, ``if we had had more Republicans in control of Capitol Hill over the last couple of decades, this budget mess that we're in right now would never have happened.'' That partisan sentiment ignored the fact that budget deficits soared while there was a Republican president - Ronald Reagan - working with a Republican-controlled Senate. As for the current budget crisis, the president laid the blame on the Democrats in control of Congress, even though much of the opposition to the bipartisan agreement rejected two weeks ago came from his on party. But that is the way of campaign rhetoric and for all his jibes at the Democrats in Congress, Bush stopped far short of the attack rhetoric used by Ally Milder, the GOP candidate challenging Democratic Rep. Peter Hoagland in Nebraska. Milder described Congress as ``full of rats, gnawing at the ship of state.'' ``Throw the rats overboard,'' she urged the partisan audience.

DOC.HEAD: People Discouraged, Poll Says
DOC.TEXT: Fewer than one in five people in the United States believe things in the country are ``generally going in the right direction,'' according to a new poll. That response reported Monday was the lowest since The Washington Post-ABC News poll began asking the question in 1982. Seventy-nine percent of respondents said they believed ``things have gotten pretty seriously off on the wrong track.'' Most people still approve of the way President Bush is handling his job - 56 percent. But only a week before, 65 percent approved, In early September, three-quarters of respondents approved. Similarly, the proportion approving the way Bush is dealing with the economy fell from 53 percent in September to 38 percent during the survey taken Wednesday through Sunday. Bush still got high ratings for his handling of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait - 64 percent - but it was down from 78 percent in September. Respondents were asked whether they approved or disapproved of the way the president, Democrats in Congress and Republicans in Congress were handling the deficit. Nobody won high marks. Compared with the previous week, the president's ``approve'' response fell to 33 percent from 38 percent, the Democrats' fell to 30 percent from 32 percent, within the likely margin of error, and the Republicans' fell to 23 percent from 33 percent. The poll interviewed 1,006 people selected at random. In such a poll, the likely margin of error is 3 percentage points either way.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Air Force Chief Still at Work in Pentagon
DOC.TEXT:
Gen. Michael J. Dugan, relieved last month as Air Force chief of staff after talking about what the United States might do in a war with Iraq, is working as an aide to Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice. Dugan remains on active duty and has been working as a special assistant to Rice since shortly after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney demoted him on Sept. 17, said Air Force spokesman Col. Joe Purka. The matter of Dugan's status arose after Cheney said during a radio interview in London on Monday that Dugan is ``no longer in the Air Force.'' However, Dugan, a 32-year veteran and former fighter pilot, maintains his rank as four-star general until President Bush formally nominates him for retirement and the Senate acts on the nomination. Purka said Bush had not yet made the nomination. If the Senate does not act within 90 days of the date of Dugan's dismissal as chief of staff, his rank would slip to major general, Purka said. Major general is two notches below general.
---
DOC.HEAD: Company Recalling Cough Drug
DOC.TEXT:
A drug company is recalling three lots of a bronchodialator drug product that may have been packaged in mislabeled cartons. The Food and Drug Administration said Monday the product is Metaproterenol Sulfate Inhalation Solution, USP 5 percent. Some bottles of the product may have been packaged in an outer folding carton labeled Carbinoxamine Compound Drops, which is used to treat cough and upper respiratory symptoms associated with allergy or colds in children. The FDA advised parents who have been prescribed Carbinoxamine Compound Drops that the correct medication is purple in color with a grape flavor and grape odor. It uses a dropper with four distinct graduation lines between \ and 1 milliliter. The inhalation solution is pale yellow and its dropper shows measuring lines at 0.2 milliliter and 0.3 milliliter. If used as pediatric drops in infants, the inhalation solution could cause nervousness, excessively rapid heartbeat, tremor and nausea. It also could cause hypertension, palpitation, vomiting and bad taste. Both products are made by Pharmaceutical Basics Inc. of Morton Grove, Ill, which issued the recalled in cooperation with the FDA. The FDA also recommended that pharmacists review their records since February and notify any patient who had been given either of the products so they could examine the medications and their labels. The recalled lots of Metaproterenol Sulfate Inhalation Solution, USP 5 percent, are numbers 18222K, 18421H and 18421C. Packages of Carbinoxamine Compound Drops with the same lot numbers also are being recalled.
---
DOC.HEAD: House Approves Bill to Hire Watchdog Official
DOC.TEXT: Legislation that would establish a chief financial officer to target wasteful spending in the bureaucracy has cleared the House over the Bush administration's opposition. The House passed the bill on a voice vote Monday. It now goes to the Senate, where similar legislation is pending. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., the bill's sponsor, said scandals in the Department of Housing and Urban Development and elsewhere in government could be traced to ``the deplorable state of the government's own management infrastructure - particularly our financial management systems.'' ``It is almost inconceivable that an organization which controls almost one-fourth of the country's gross national product has incompatible and outmoded financial management systems,'' Conyers said. The bill would create a ``centralized and professional leadership structure'' at the Office of Management and Budget, he said. The Bush administration opposes the bill, the OMB said in a statement. While supporting efforts to improve government management, the bill would create confusion and blur the lines between the executive and legislative branches, it said. The administration favors establishing a deputy director for management and a government-wide controller in OMB, as well as chief financial officer positions in each department, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,606.10, up 496.90 points, or 2.15 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: As Hong Kong and China Tussle, Fate Uncertain of New Airport
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: An ambitious plan to build a glittering new airport in Britain's last great colony has turned into a battle between Beijing and London for political influence and billions of dollars. The airport was supposed to be a parting gift. Now there are widespread worries that it won't open by the target date of 1997, when Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule. Some fear it will never be built at all. The airport's expense - $16 billion by conservative estimates - has prompted charges that it will be a cash cow for British companies. ``It's Britain's last great present to itself,'' says Gordon Wu, a leading Hong Kong businessman with close links to China. ``It's their license to print money.'' These allegations provoke countercharges that China will not back the project unless it gets a substantial slice of the pie. The controversy highlights fears that the colonial government is a lame duck, that China already calls the shots in the territory. The first works contract for the airport, a $26 million deal for dredging, went to a Chinese-owned firm. ``Beijing's main reason for allowing Hong Kong to exist is so the goose can lay golden eggs,'' said an American executive involved in the project. ``The airport project is definitely a golden egg.'' The latest chapter in the imbroglio concerns funding for a main item in the project, a 4,719-foot suspension bridge that would be the second-longest in the world and connect the airport to Kowloon peninsula, the side of Hong Kong located on the Chinese mainland. On Friday, Chinese officials lashed out at Hong Kong's decision to fund the bridge from government coffers. The move added further weight to Chinese fears that London is treating the project as its last Asian pork barrel. Ji Pengfei, the most senior Chinese official in charge of Hong Kong affairs, called the move ``unilateral and inappropriate'' and warned the Hong Kong government not to try any more ``tricks.'' Hong Kong authorities defended the bridge and criticized one pro-Beijing awyer in the territory for making a ``political speech'' against the airport. Hong Kong's governor, Sir David Wilson, announced the airport plan last October, saying it demonstrated Britain's commitment to Hong Kong's future. The announcement came as the government tried to restore confidence in this territory of 5.7 million people severely shaken by China's bloody crackdown on a pro-democracy movement in June 1989. Many people in the colony do not believe China's promise that it will maintain Hong Kong's open economic and social system for 50 years after it resumes control. The airport plan, one of the biggest engineering projects of the 1990s, includes flattening two hilly islands and connecting them by dumping 260 million cubic yards of rocks and sand into the ocean. The centerpiece is the new airport on Chep Lap Kok, an island separated from downtown Hong Kong by 16 miles of open sea. The airport would replace the current one, Kai Tak, on the Kowloon peninsula, famed for its wild landings. Some approaches are so harrowing that passengers feel they're heading for an unwanted kiss with a poster of the Marlboro man on a garage wall. The new airport would operate 24 hours a day and handle 80 million passengers a year, more than three times the capacity of Kai Tak. When the airport was announced, Zhou Nan, China's top representative in Hong Kong, demanded negotiations with the colonial government. But after intense pressure from Beijing, the government relented and talks began Monday in Hong Kong. Joseph Y.S. Cheng, a leading educator and political observer in the colony, predicts problems like the airport project will multiply in the next seven years. ``China is staking a claim to exert control over Hong Kong not in 1997,'' he said, ``but now.''

DOC.HEAD: Radiation Survivors Feel Vindicated by Government's Decision to Pay Them
DOC.TEXT: Residents downwind from open-air nuclear tests of the 1950s and '60s said they felt vindicated by the government's decision to pay up to $50,000 compensation to those who may have gotten cancer from the radiation. But some remained bitter Monday after years of legal wrangling over the issue. Others doubted whether they would actually see any money. President Bush signed a bill during a campaign trip to Dallas on Monday that provides up to $50,000 to cancer victims who were exposed to test radiation in three Western states and up to $100,000 to uranium miners also stricken. It also offers an apology to the victims. The White House said victims do not have to establish scientifically that the fallout caused their cancer. ``I'm glad they're owning up to it,'' said Rula Orton of Parowan. ``I feel very good about that.'' Orton's 14-year-old daughter, Peggy, died in 1960 of leukemia that her doctors believe may have been linked to nuclear radiation. Elmer Pickett, whose wife died of leukemia in 1960, was still bitter. ``I feel those people who were running the Atomic Energy Commission knew very well what they were doing to us up here,'' he said from his home in St. George. ``They're just as guilty of murder as those running the death camps in Germany. There should be some punishment there.'' The number of victims or survivors eligible for the payments was not immediately known. The United States conducted more than 200 atomic tests in the open air in the South Pacific and Nevada before they were outlawed by the Test Ban Treaty of 1963. Rep. Wayne Owens, D-Utah, who co-sponsored the bill, called those who lived downwind from the tests ``victims of the Cold War.'' Elizabeth Wright of the National Association of Radiation Survivors said Monday's action is vindication for her father, Arthur F. Bruhn. The former president of Dixie College in St. George died of cancer in 1963. ``He said, `Someday they'll know these tests are killing me,' '' she said. One of those who helped lead the fight for compensation, former Gov. Scott M. Matheson, died of cancer last week. He grew up in Cedar City during the tests of the early 1950s. His son, Scott, said his father found it an ``interesting wrinkle'' that he too was diagnosed with a disease linked to the tests.
