The downwinders won a federal lawsuit against the government for compensation in 1982, but it was overturned on appeal. The bill signed by Bush on Monday provides compensation for people who developed cancer in certain time periods and: -Spent one or two years, depending on their type of cancer, in downwind areas of Nevada, Arizona or Utah between 1951 and 1958, or were present in June or July of 1962. -Or mined uranium in Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Wyoming or Utah from 1947 to 1971. The bill authorizes placing $100 million in a Radiation Exposure Trust Fund for victims. Future legislation is needed to actually allocate the money. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, another of the bill's sponsors, said some payments could be made before the end of the year. Steve P. Foster, a uranium miner from Grand Junction, Colo., who lost part of his right lung to cancer, was skeptical. ``I suspect from my past association with the government, I don't think we will ever get anything out of it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: The King of Tonga Has a Deal for Washington State
DOC.TEXT: The king of Tonga, a banana-exporting South Pacific island nation with 443 cars, wants all the tires Washington state can spare. Not to put them on cars, but to burn them. King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV sees mounds of rubber as the answer to his kingdom's quest for energy independence and is pounding on the governor's door to cut a deal. Washington state has an estimated 30 million old tires, which pose a major fire and environmental hazard that grows by 4 million to 5 million tires a year, officials say. But so far, the state has been cool to the king's idea. The king wants the state to spend $25.5 million up front to gather, chip and ship the 30 million tires to his kingdom, a group of islands about 3,000 miles southwest of Honolulu. He also wants a guaranteed supply of old tires. By taking the tires off the state's hands, the deal would ``lay a sound base for future trade and commercial development projects'' with Tonga, the king told Gov. Booth Gardner in a recent letter. The king requested a meeting with the governor by month's end, but a Gardner spokesman said Monday he was too busy to meet anytime soon. ``Besides, we want to be sure and be fair,'' said Dan Youmans. ``We are expecting other proposals by February on handling waste tires. It wouldn't look right to meet with just the king.'' The king's proposal and a similar request from the South Pacific island of Yap are drawing opposition from environmentalists, who contend Washington's waste problem should not be exported to the Third World. But Dale Clark, the state's tire recycling coordinator at the Department of Ecology, considers the proposal worth investigation. He said the king has given assurances the tires would be burned only if the best pollution control technology were employed. Such technology is in use at a tire burning plant near Modesto, Calif., Clark said. Tonga lives on tourism and banana exports. As of 1983, the kingdom of 108,000 people had 443 cars. ``Based on our plan to provide for future energy requirements as well as the present needs of Tonga, we would need a guaranteed supply'' of tires, the king wrote. In 1989, Washington began collecting a $1 tax on every new tire for studies on tire disposal. The fund has grown to about $2 million. But the Department of Ecology is still searching for ways to dispose of tires in an environmentally sound manner. Clark said some tires are chipped and used in highway asphalt. Others are made into truck floor mats, tugboat bumpers and other products. But the supply still overwhelms demand, Clark said, and they pose a serious threat if they catch fire. Tire fires are extremely hard to fight and can burn for weeks. Their thick, acrid smoke can make people sick and force evacuations. An arsonist was blamed for a monthlong 1984 fire that burned 5 million to 7 million tires in Everett. Firefighters tried to douse the flames with water but the Environmental Protection Agency made them stop, saying the runoff was polluting a river nearby. ``Burning tires is an environmentally disastrous idea,'' said Joe Thornton, a toxics information specialist for Greenpeace International in Chicago. ``Tires are a complex stew of heavy metals, chlorine and hydrocarbons. The heavy metals, arsenic, lead, mercury, come out of the stack or wind up in the ash, which becomes another disposal problem.'' When burned, toxic compounds such as cancer-causing dioxin and PCBs are produced, Thornton said. ``As has been amply demonstrated in this country, the best technology is not good enough. Better equipment will not make the pollution problem go away,'' he said. ``Let me ask you a simple question,'' said Ann Leonard, a spokeswoman for Greenpeace's International Waste Trade Project in Washington, D.C. ``If it's environmentally safe to burn waste tires for energy, why aren't you doing it in Washington? I'll tell you why. Because it isn't safe and people in your state wouldn't stand for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Makes His Move After Kasparov's Big Win
With PM-Chess-Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: The third game of the world chess championship between champion Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov was suspended until tonight with neither man showing a clear advantage. Play was halted just after 10:30 p.m. Monday when Kasparov wrote down his 41st move and sealed it in an envelope. The game was to resume at 5:30 p.m. with the match arbiter opening the envelope. ``The adjourned position is a complete mess,'' said one spectator, Joel Benjamin, a grandmaster from New York City. ``Nobody knows what's happening.'' In the adjourned position, Karpov, playing the white pieces, has a king, rook, bishop, knight and four pawns. Kasparov has a king, two bishops, a knight and five pawns. ``There are chances for both sides and I predict a draw,'' said grandmaster Dmitri Gurevich of Chicago. Kasparov, 27, the highest-rated player in the history of chess, leads 1{ points to { point in the 24-game match against Karpov, 39, the world champion he unseated in 1985. The arch-rivals have played more than 120 games. Most of them, like Game 1 of this match, were draws. Kasparov, who has a bold, attacking style, won Game 2. Karpov is known for a more methodical, defense-minded style.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Rocks the Mail With Stone Postcards to Celebrities, Others
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: You might call them postcards from the ledge. Artist Nick Agid carves messages into slabs of stone and mails them to politicians, celebrities, world leaders, authors and fellow artisans. Using material left over from his sculpture work, Agid has lovingly etched more than 600 mineral missives out of onyx, marble and granite. ``It started out being a whim and it became a serious art project,'' he says. He spends about an hour chiseling a message into each polished stone, always including a request for a reply. The cost of mailing the four- to five-pound cards is heavy - up to $10 a throw, and much more for international celebrities. But Agid doesn't mind. ``The responses were so humorous, it became kind of addicting to check the mail and see who wrote me back,'' he said. ``I got a letter from the pope and Ted Kennedy on the same day.'' Many who have gotten the rock cards - including President Bush, Elizabeth Taylor, director Mel Brooks, author Ray Bradbury and actor Vincent Price - have responded. Price sent his response on the inner sole of a shoe, writing, ``Upon my sole, I've never had such a heavy fan letter. Are you sure you have all your marbles?'' From others - Iraq's Saddam Hussein, for instance - there has been stony silence. Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Los Angeles, known for his opposition to the National Endowment for the Arts, cast stones at Agid's artistic endeavor. ``The only true value something like your brick has is that which people will voluntarily pay for it,'' he said. ``That's why so many no-talent artists end up seeking grants from the NEA.'' San Francisco Examiner columnist Rob Morse took the Postal Service to task for the way it handled his five-pound slab of onyx. ``I still have the rock,'' he wrote in his column. ``It arrived in a plastic envelope and says `Damaged in Shipment.' ``Only the post office could damage a rock.'' Relations between Agid and the Postal Service are indeed a bit rocky. Postal workers tend to balk when he shows up with as many as 40 stone slabs to mail. ``We were never mad at him,'' said Betty Baker, a clerk at the Torrance Post Office. ``It's just we avoid him. It takes so much time to mail his rocks. It gets our counters real dirty.'' At one point, the Postal Service threatened to stop accepting Agid's mailings. Word was that one of his rocks broke a conveyor belt. To smooth things over, he sent a carved card to Postmaster General Anthony Frank, who wrote back, ``It is always a pleasure to be contacted by one of our customers, especially one as rock-solid as you are.'' Not wanting his year-old project to gather moss, Agid plans to put the responses he's gotten into a book. ``I have brought a few laughs into the lives of the people who have gotten my cards,'' he said. ``After you've gotten a rock in the mail, you never know what to expect from then on.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Edges Down, Stocks Surge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged down against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Tuesday despite a brief morning rally, and stocks surged for the second day. The dollar ended the day at 128.05 yen, down 0.10 yen from Monday's finish. After opening at 128.08 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 127.75 and 128.35 yen. On Monday, the dollar fell 1.15 yen. The dollar's closing was its lowest since its 127.63-yen finish on March 6, 1989. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,606.10, up 496.90 points, or 2.15 percent. An estimated 500 million shares were traded on the market's first section. On Monday, the Nikkei index gained 719.04 points. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds rose to 83.67 points from their close of 83.40 on Monday. Their yield dipped to 7.990 percent from 8.055 percent on Monday. Traders said the stronger yen, stable bond prices and an overnight rise on the New York Stock Exchange helped buoy share prices. In New York, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 18.32 points to 2,416.34 on Monday, following a 32.92-point gain on Friday. Despite some profit-taking sell pressure, the Nikkei index was supported by arbitrage buying prompted by strong advances in futures prices, traders said. Traders said caution over the rapid pace of the dollar's recent fall slowed its decline on Tuesday. The brief early morning rally spurred by traders seeking to cover short dollar positions failed to build strength because of a lack of fundamental factors to support buying, said Yasuhisa Morikuni of the Bank of America. ``The factors favoring the rise of the yen have been prevalent recently. This trend has been prolonged and has encouraged the buying back of the yen,'' said a Bank of Tokyo official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Traders said short-term sentiment for the dollar appeared mixed. While many market participants forecast that the dollar would fall over the medium term, its steep losses over the past several weeks led some to predict a technical rally.

DOC.HEAD: Media Appeal Judge's Barring Press From Jury Selection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jury selection resumes at 9 a.m. EDT$
DOC.TEXT: News organizations appealed a decision by a federal judge to close jury selection at the trial of one of nine state lawmakers indicted in a vote-buying scandal. The move Monday by U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins tightened the lid on coverage of the case of Rep. Luther Taylor. The judge already had barred attorneys from discussing the case outside court and sealed records from the media. Hawkins said he feared prospective jurors might not answer as truthfully if reporters were present during questioning. He also said open jury selection could affect cases against others charged in the FBI sting. News organizations asked a federal appeals judge to stay Hawkins' ruling, but he refused. They then filed an emergency appeal before the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va. No hearing was immediately scheduled. ``There has to be a balancing process so that any restriction on our right of access is as narrow as can be and still protecting the Sixth Amendment right'' of a fair trial, said Jay Bender, an attorney for the South Carolina Press Association. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel took no position on the matter. Taylor, 40, a Democrat from Columbia, is one of nine state lawmakers indicted in August and September on charges of taking bribes in exchange for their support of a bill legalizing betting on horses and greyhounds. Some lawmakers were videotaped taking payoffs. Four lawmakers have pleaded guilty to bribery. A fifth has pleaded guilty to a drug charge that resulted from the investigation. Taylor's attorney, Joel Collins, did not ask that jury selection be closed, but had sought the sealing of court records about Taylor and other lawmakers. Collins had argued further disclosures about the case would make it impossible to find an impartial 12-member jury. Seven jurors had been seated by Monday night, and Bender said pretrial publicity apparently had not had a great effect on prospective jurors. Taylor, who has served in the state House since 1983, is accused of accepting $4,300 for supporting the betting bill. If convicted, he could get up to 120 years in prison and a $1.5 million fine.

DOC.HEAD: Ulysses Solar-Exploring Spacecraft Maneuvers by Firing Thrusters
DOC.TEXT: The Ulysses spacecraft, speeding toward Jupiter on a roundabout mission to explore the sun's poles in 1994-95, is firing its thrusters this week to adjust its course, NASA says. ``Everything is proceeding as planned. There hasn't been a single hiccup or glitch of any kind,'' Franklin O'Donnell, spokesman for NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said after the four-day maneuver started Monday. Ulysses was released from shuttle Discovery on Oct. 6 on a 1.86 billion-mile mission during which it will use the gravity of Jupiter, the solar system's biggest planet, to sling it into orbit over the sun's poles. Ulysses was 6.1 million miles from Earth on Monday, traveling toward Jupiter at a speed of 25,370 mph relative to the Earth. It is expected to make its closest approach to Jupiter in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The things that were done in the Soviet Union last year were things only a Soviet leader could do, but they were things that we've been asking Soviet leaders to do since the beginning of the Cold War. So we can only applaud.'' - John Gaddis, a diplomatic historian at Ohio University, on Mikhail Gorbachev's winning the Nobel Peace Prize. --- ``I'm glad they're owning up to it. I feel very good about that.'' - Rula Orton, a Utah resident whose daughter died of leukemia, on the government's decision to compensate those who may have gotten cancer from radiation from open-air nuclear tests. --- ``It started out being a whim and it became a serious art project.'' - Artist Nick Agid, who carves messages into slabs of stone and mails them to pplitical and cultural figures.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Measuring 5.5 Strikes Iran
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale jolted the Iranian town of Tabas and nearby areas, Iran's official news agency reported today. There was no immediate word on damage or casualties. The Geophysics Institute of Tehran University said the quake struck late Monday about 370 miles southeast of Tehran, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said no reports of damage or casualties had been released. In July, tens of thousands of people were killed in an earthquake that devastated a large part of northwestern Iran. A quake measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale, which measures ground motion recorded on a seismograph, can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest U.S. Aircraft Carrier En Route to Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The USS Midway, the oldest of the Navy's 15 aircraft carriers, is being dispatched to the Arabian Sea in support of Operation Desert Shield, naval sources say. The 62,000-ton Midway, based at Yokosuka, Japan, and currently on maneuvers with Japanese self-defense forces, will replace the USS Independence next month, the sources said on Monday. The sources, who asked not to be named, said they did not know why the World War II-vintage Midway was chosen for the deployment ahead of one of the Navy's newer carriers. The ship has a limited operational capability compared to its larger, more modern counterparts, and has been marked for retirement for the last few years. In addition, the 64,000-ton ship has had problems since 1987, when it underwent a $200 million overhaul designed chiefly to upgrade its ability to handle the F-18 Hornet attack aircraft. The hull was redesigned with special ``blisters'' intended to improve stability in rough seas. Instead, Naval officials have said, they cause the ship to ``porpoise'' in seas running more than five to eight feet, making flight operations more difficult in such conditions. U.S. Navy spokesmen declined comment on the reported deployment plan, citing a policy against discussing the future movements or locations of U.S. warships. The Naval sources said they did not know why the Midway was chosen over newer and larger carriers for the Desert Shield deployment. The Midway, built during World War II but launched too late to see action, has gone through several modernizations in its 45 years, to keep pace with newer flattops. It has been based at Yokosuka since 1973, the only U.S. carrier based outside the United States. It has had numerous assignments to the Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea, including at least one stint during the 1980-88 Iraq-Iran war. It carries about 75 aircraft, including F-18s, AS-6 intruder and A-7 Corsair attack bombers. The ship reportedly will be accompanied by its usual battle group, including the Aegis missile cruiser USS Bunker Hill and the missile cruiser USS Sterett. The United States has three other carriers in the region, the Independence in the Arabian Sea, the John F. Kennedy in the Red Sea and the Saratoga in the eastern Mediterranean. The 80,000-ton Independence, based at San Diego and sent to the Arabian Sea in July, was already in the area when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since then, its 70-plus warplanes have flown regular patrols over the Persian Gulf and trained for possible action against Iraq. The Independence made a two-day sortie into the Persian Gulf, the first by an aircraft carrier since 1974.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Puts Overnight News Service on Hold
DOC.TEXT: ABC News says it is putting on hold its plans for an overnight news service and considering closing several U.S. bureaus. ABC News President Roone Arledge on Monday cited the expense of covering the Persian Gulf crisis and a reduced revenue from a soft advertising market. The network last month said it planned to start a 1 a.m.-to-6 a.m. weekday broadcast in January that would give affiliates live and taped segments, domestic and international news, sports and weather in 30-minute packages. Richard C. Wald, ABC News senior vice president, said the plan ``has been put off for the time being'' and he didn't know when it might become active again. ABC spokeswoman Sherrie S. Rollins said no decision has been made on bureau closings but that an announcement probably will be made in a week or two.

DOC.HEAD: Katyusha Rockets Fired Into Israel From Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A number of Soviet-made Katyusha rockets fired from southern Lebanon exploded in northern Israel today but caused no damage or injury, the military command said. Israeli forces returned fire to the source of the rockets, an army communique added. Army radio said the Katyushas were apparently fired by the fundamentalist Shiite militia Hezbollah, or Party of God, from north of the buffer zone that Israel maintains in southern Lebanon. Last week, a number of ground-to-ground Katyushas were fired from Lebanon but none reached Israel. Israel carved out the two- to 10-mile wide buffer zone in 1985 to help protect its northern border from guerrilla raids after it withdrew the bulk of its forces from Lebanon after a three-year occupation. The zone is jointly patrolled by Israeli soldiers and some 2,500 members of the South Lebanon Army, a Lebanese-militia trained and financed by Israel.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Delegation Arrives in North Korea for Talks
DOC.TEXT: The highest-ranking South Korean official ever to cross the armed border into North Korea said today that he would propose that the rival countries officially recognize each other. ``The first step toward improving bilateral relations must be, above all else, recognizing and respecting the existence of each other,'' said Prime Minister Kang Young-koon. Kang was to hold talks with his North Korean counterpart, Yon Hyong Muk, on Wednesday in the second round of the highest-level contacts between the rival Koreas since the division of the peninsula in 1945. The two met in Seoul in September. News reports said the two premiers embraced ``in a bear hug'' on meeting today in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. ``We heartily welcome you here,'' Yon said. ``We felt overwhelmed by a thousand emotions,'' said Kang, who was born in the north and fled to the south as a refugee in 1945. The 90-member South Korean delegation will return home on Friday after two days of talks. Their agenda includes formal dinners and sightseeing. In the South Korean capital of Seoul, meanwhile, more lawmakers joined opposition leader Kim Dae-jung in a hunger strike to demand democratic reforms. Kim, leader of the Party for Peace and Democracy, was in the ninth day of his fast, and 41 lawmakers have joined him in the past two days. Officials of the governing Democratic Liberal Party indicated today they would make concessions on some opposition demands, including moving up the date of local elections. Although the policy-making jobs of the prime ministers of the north and south are limited and their roles are largely ceremonial, the talks hold symbolic value between two nations that view each other as enemies. The border between the two Koreas remains tightly sealed with more than 1.5 million troops on either side. The nations fought a three-year war in the early 1950s and a peace treaty was never signed. South Korea has recognized Communist North Korea as a separate countary, but the north has steadfastly refused to recognize the south, claiming that to do so would perpetuate division. South Korea has said hostilities will not end until both governments officially accept the existence of the other. ``Differences in ideology and system between the two parts of Korea must no longer form a barrier dividing the people,'' Kang said at a welcoming ceremony at the government guest house, where the delegation will stay. ``Just like the proverb saying that things begun are already half done, let's make rapid progress and fulfill the desires of 70 million people,'' Kang said. In a separate move, the North Korean Red Cross proposed a resumption of talks on Nov. 15 to discuss the reunion of families separated by partition of the peninsula. The Red Cross talks were broken off about a year ago. An estimated 10 million people are separated from family members, and the issue of reconciliation is emotional for both sides. Even as the two sides readied to meet, North Korean radio broadcast a statement threatening an end to the north-south dialogue if South Korea does not end its annual military exercises with U.S. troops. A demand to halt the Team Spirit exercises was one of three made by North Korea in the first round of talks. The north also demanded the release of dissidents jailed for visiting North Korea and insisted the South halt efforts to join the United Nations as a separate nation.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up, Dollar Slips
DOC.TEXT: News ranging from lower oil prices to Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Nobel Prize boosted stock prices in Tokyo today, brokers said, while the dollar slipped further against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average surged 496.90 points, or 2.15 percent, closing at 23,606.10. It had gained 3.21 percent, or 719.04 points, on Monday. ``An overall combination of factors contributed to the performance of the market today,'' said Yasufumi Kawashima of Sanyo Securities Co. He added, however, that buying was leisurely. News such as Gorbachev's winning the Nobel Peace Prize added to a feeling of stability, he said. Brokers also mentioned stability on the New York market, lower oil prices and foreign investors' buying of high-tech issues such as Hitachi Ltd. and insurance shares that had been considered under-priced. Large securities firms were selling aggressively to foreign investors, whose purchases moved prices because they were buying thinly traded issues, the brokers added. Reports that the long-term prime interest rate may be lowered also encouraged buying, said Toshiyuki Higuchi of Daiwa Securities Co. Trade volume on the first section was about 500 million shares, up from 370.7 million shares Monday. The dollar, meanwhile, closed at 128.05 yen, down 0.10 yen from Monday's close of 128.15 yen. After opening at 128.08 yen, it ranged between 127.75 yen and 128.35 yen. The dollar now has fallen 9.90 yen in the last 11 trading days. ``The factors favoring the rise of the yen have been prevalent recently. This trend of the yen's stability has been prolonged and encouraged the buying of the yen,'' said an official at the Bank of Tokyo, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But another dealer at a major bank commented, ``There is a definite overselling of the dollar. No one thinks the dollar is going to plunge, that the U.S. economy is going to be destroyed overnight or that the tools they own are going to become dust overnight.'' He said market players seem to be turning cautious, preparing for a possible reaction to the overselling. ``Everything bad there is to say about the dollar has already been said. It can't hit a further bottom,'' he added. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds rose to 83.78 points from their close of 83.40 on Monday. Their yield dropped to 7.970 percent from 8.055 percent Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Consul: He Unknowingly Sought Money from Drug Trafficker
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's consul, a nephew of President Violeta Chamorro, says he unknowingly solicited money for the Contras in the 1980s from a drug trafficker but denies he received millions of dollars for cocaine shipments. Adolfo ``Popo'' Chamorro was accused during a trial in Tulsa, Okla., earlier this year of involvement in a ``guns-for-drugs'' scheme. Two sources who spoke on condition of anonymity have since said that Chamorro, along with Octaviano Cesar, brother of a top aide to Mrs. Chamorro, are being investigated by the Customs Service and other agencies. At a news conference Monday, Chamorro said he met in 1984 with George Morales, who he thought at the time was a wealthy Miami Cuban sympathetic to the anti-communist Nicaraguan rebels, to gain support for the Contras. Chamorro said that U.S. officials authorized the contact and that he had no knowledge or involvement in drug trafficking. But Chamorro, 41, abruptly ended the news conference when asked whether U.S. authorities warned him that Morales was under indictment on drug charges when the Contras took cash and planes from him. Accusations linking Chamorro with ``guns-for-drugs'' deals are not new. In testimony before a 1987 Senate committee, Morales said Chamorro and Octaviano Cesar arranged a trade of guns and drugs in Costa Rica. The accusations against Chamorro lay dormant until testimony by Colombian drug pilot Fabio Ernesto Carrasco in a Tulsa drug case seven months ago. Carrasco said he paid millions of dollars to Chamorro and Octaviano Cesar to fly cocaine into Florida on planes that returned to Central America with arms. Morales is serving a 16-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Killed In Bloody Battle At Coal Mine In Latest Factional Violence
DOC.TEXT: Rival Zulus and Xhosas armed with spears and knives clashed in a factional fight at a coal mine and 10 people were hacked to death and 48 injured, police said today. A police spokesman, who declined to be named, said that fighting erupted late Monday at Hlobane Colliery near Vryheid in northern Natal Province. The area has been a battleground between conservative Zulu forces and followers of the African National Congress. A group of Zulus went on a rampage in the workers' quarters at the mine, attacking rival Xhosas, the spokesman said. The two groups fought with knives, axes and spears, he said. Police said they did not know what started the clash. The fight followed a clash in Johannesburg that left eight people dead. The incidents marked a new outbreak of black factional violence after several weeks of relative calm. More than 800 people were killed in factional fighting between Zulus of the Inkatha movement and ANC supporters in black townships around Johannesburg in August and September. Police also said Tuesday two men and one woman were killed in separate unrest incidents in other parts of Natal during the past 24 hours. One of the men was killed when two groups armed with spears fought at a bus station in Empangeni. In other developments, police in the black Kwazulu homeland said 43 people had been murdered durng the weekend. The report did not say how many deaths were politically motivated. Kwazulu, a semi-autonomous black homeland, is administered by Mangosuthu Buthelezi, head of the Inkatha movement. South African news reports Tuesday said the clash Monday in Johannesburg began when a mini-bus filled with armed men attacked a workers compound nar the Kempton Park district. The attackers, some of whom were wearing masks, opened fire on sleeping workers with automatic weapons, the reports said. Unidentified men in mini-buses were blamed for starting much of the bloody fighting in the Johannesburg area last month. ANC leaders charged the attackers were linked to the security forces and were trying to fan black violence. President F.W. de Klerk's government and police commanders have denied the ANC charges. The government imposed curfews and introduced strict security last month in black townships around Johannesburg hit by factional fighting. Curfews had been lifted in some areas and security relaxed in recent days as the fighting appeared to have ended. Police commanders said today that they were keeping a close watch on the fresh outbreaks of violence and would increase security to prevent it spreading. The fighting has pittted Inkatha against Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the left-leaning ANC. The two sides oppose apartheid, but differ over goals for a future South Africa, including economic plans and leadership questions.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Requires Cigarette Machine Tokens; New York Considers Ban
DOC.TEXT: Pittsburgh has acted to keep cigarettes out of youngsters' hands by requiring the use of tokens in all cigarette vending machines, while New York City moved toward banning the machines in almost all public places. The token law was signed by Mayor Sophie Masloff on Monday. It becomes effective Nov. 7. In New York, the City Council's health committee voted 6-0 to ban cigarette machines in stores, fast-food outlets and most other public places. The proposal must still be approved by the full council and Mayor David Dinkins. Both measures are among the toughest anti-smoking proposals in the country. ``We know that most smokers get hooked on the addictive quality of tobacco when they are young,'' said New York City Councilman Joseph Lisa, chairman of the health committee. The measure would allow cigarette machines to remain in taverns, in hotel and motel bars and other establishments not open to everyone. Masloff said Pittsburgh officials didn't ban the machines because they feared the courts would rule such action unconstitutional. She said the vending machine industry has indicated it will challenge the new law, designed to remedy the way cigarettes are available to practically anyone with loose change. ``Until a court tells the industry otherwise, it will have to comply with the new law when it takes effect or remove their coin-operated machines from the city,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Couples Exchange Wedding Vows in Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Valary Shtraks had never ever seen a Jewish wedding. But the Soviet emigre, like 53 other men, eagerly stomped a wine glass in a ceremony that had been prohibited when he wed in the Soviet Union. Soviet couples at 30 Philadelphia-area synagogues were married anew Monday night in religious ceremonies rrganized by Operation Exodus, an effort by the Federation of Jewish Agencies to help Soviet Jews settle in the United States. The religious ceremonies were held to supplement the secular weddings the couples had in the Soviet Union. ``It's now a complete wedding with the family,'' said Shtraks, who with Rita, his wife of 13 years, and parents, Lev and Annuta Shtraks, arrived in this country from the Ukraine 10 months ago. Eight couples, including both Shtrakses, exchanged vows at Har Zion Temple in front of more than 600 congregation members, friends and relatives. The bridegrooms, wearing yarmulkes, stood under chuppahs, or wedding canopies, with their brides. Rabbi Gerald Wolpe then handed wine glasses wrapped in cloth to the eight bridegrooms, who stomped the glasses with a festive pop. Children sang and the audience clapped as the couples danced down the aisles. Wolpe said rabbinical scholars had ruled it was proper to give the ceremony as if the couples were being married for the first time. ``To these families it is almost a symbol of a reunification of their people,'' Wolpe said. ``That they can choose the ceremony, that is such a miracle to them.'' Another couple, David and Ana Bolotin, said they plan to celebrate Monday as well as the day they first married 16 years ago as their wedding anniversary. At the Reconstructionist Congregation Or Hadash in nearby Wyncote, Mark and Natalie Peymer were also married, as were Mark's parents, Liubov and Semyon Peymer. Both couples came from Leningrad on March 15. ``Now we can have the religious ceremony,'' said the younger Mrs. Peymer, 20. ``We can have a complete marriage, and be husband and wife before God.'' At the Oxford Circle Jewish Community Centre-Brith Israel, Rabbi J. Harold Romirowsky married five couples before a crowd of about 500. ``We are doing this to create a stronger attachment to the Jewish community by the Russian immigrants. They can make a contribution to this country,'' he said. Each family was given a candelabra and a book on Judaism. Federation members came up with the idea of celebrating the immigrants' marriages in freedom last spring, when the Soviets relaxed their emigration laws.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Alaska, Fog in the South
3 Year Old in AIDS-Ravage Family Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old girl whose father committed suicide rather than watch his family ravaged by AIDS has died of the disease, a month after her mother. The death of Angela Folsom on Sunday left just one survivor in the family of Jennifer Folsom, who made her battle with AIDS public this summer to show the disease can strike the traditional family in rural America. Mrs. Folsom's husband, Doug Folsom, committed suicide in June. His wife said he was unable to bear watching the disease destroy the family. Angela had never learned how to walk and moved in with her grandparents after her mother died Sept. 3. ``She was just worn down,'' said Fred Kenney, her uncle. ``A lot of it was the transition of losing her mother and moving to another home.'' ``I have mixed feelings,'' he said. ``Mostly I'm glad that she's not in pain anymore, because she had been on morphine. Of course we hate to see her go.'' Mrs. Folsom believed she contracted the disease through a blood transfusion during an emergency appendectomy in 1979. That was before blood supplies were tested for the virus. She was diagnosed with the disease in 1988, and tests later found that Angela also had AIDS. Another daughter, 5-year-old Nicolette, has not tested positive for the virus and is the sole surviving member of the family. Kenney said Angela was hospitalized for four days last month after a feeding tube inserted into her stomach failed to heal properly. In recent weeks, she had received 24-hour nursing care. ``Over the last three or four weeks she deteriorated just the way Jennifer did,'' Kenney said. Kenney said Nicolette, who attended her mother's funeral, is living with her grandparents but may move in with an aunt and cousin. He said an art therapist visits Nicolette twice weekly. The girl once drew a picture of the sky with a rope hanging down to the house. She told her mother it was God sending a rope for Angela. But shortly after her father's suicide, Nicolette amended the caption, saying, ``It was for Daddy.'' ``She feels that she still has family,'' Kenney said. ``I'm just hoping my parents can get through it and we'll go on from there.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Strengthens, Gold Drops
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly in European trading today as dealers awaited fresh U.S. economic news or a development of events in the Persian Gulf. Gold dropped slightly. Dealers said a general decline in other high-yielding currencies is likely to support the dollar in the short term. But, the dealers said, they are uncertain whether the U.S. currency will be able to hold its own for much longer, especially against the yen. ``People are still looking for reasons to sell the dollar, particularly against the yen,'' said Pat Magill, head of corporate trading at Daiwa (Europe) Bank Ltd. Mark Sexton, senior dealer at Bank of Montreal in London, said the dollar now is starting to look cheap against the German mark. Overall, dealers said, the dollar is likely to trade in a narrow range as the market waits for fresh U.S. economic news or an escalation of tensions in the Persian Gulf, where an international force has been massing since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen to a closing 128.05 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 128.45 yen. Other dollar rates at mid-morning compared with late Monday: -1.5255 German marks, up from 1.5230 -1.2875 Swiss francs, up from 1.2870 -5.1138 French francs, up from 5.1035 -1.7205 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7165 -1,143.50 Italian lire, up from 1,141.50 -1.1569 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1520 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9415, compared with $1.9545 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $375.15 per ounce at mid-morning, from $379.75 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $375.45, down from $379.50 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $8.75 to close at a bid $376.33. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.22 a troy ounce, the same as Monday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Afrikaner Leader Claims Thousands Moving to Proposed White State
DOC.TEXT: An Afrikaner leader who wants to establish an independent white homeland claims that more than 12,000 families have signed up to settle in the proposed state. Carel Boshoff, who leads the Afrikaner Volkswag party, says the group expects to ask the government early next year for official recognition of it right to an independent homeland. He told the government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. Monday that talks with the government are already under way. ``We want to emphasize that we do not need confrontation. That's why we are negotiating with the government,'' he told SABC television. Boshoff envisions an Afrikaner state in the northwestern Cape region, a sparsely populated and underdeveloped area. Afrikaners, descendants of Dutch settlers, could become a majority in the region by hiring only other Afrikaners and not having to rely on black labor, he says. Boshoff said 90 families have settled in the proposed state and that more than 12,000 families from across South Africa have signed up to settle in the region. Afrikaner Volkswag organizes interested settlers into ``trek groups,'' then searches for jobs or business opportunities for them in the planned settlement area.

DOC.HEAD: Seventeen Militants, Two Border Guards Killed, Fires in Villages
DOC.TEXT: Security forces said today that they killed 17 Moslem militants caught crossing into India from Pakistan, and two border guards were killed and 10 wounded in ambushes. Fires destroyed about 200 shops and homes in several towns and villages near the cease-fire line as skirmishes continued today, witnesses said. Two charred bodies were found in the village of Shabnag, about 40 miles north of Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir state, Press Trust of India reported. Moslem militants are seeking independence for Jammu and Kashmir, the only state in Hindu-dominated India with a Moslem majority. About 1,400 people have been killed since India cracked down on the insurgency last January. Government officials said the militants shot near the cease-fire line were in the Kupwara district. They did not give details of the fighting or an exact location. Two border guards were killed and four wounded while patrolling the village of Sangrama, police sources told the United News of India news agency. Fire brigade officials said they had reports of more than 100 buildings in flames in the town of Trehgam, including a mosque. The officials in Srinigar said continuing clashes prevented firefighters from reaching several villages where fires were reported early Tuesday. A reporter was turned back outside the apple market town of Sopor, where firemen said 15 houses were ablaze. Gunfire could be heard in the distance. United News of India said the buildings caught fire during an exchange of gunfire between militants and security forces. Three security men were wounded in ambushes there Monday, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Boy Scouts Over Son's Death
DOC.TEXT: A woman has sued the Boy Scouts of America, claiming advertisements in its magazine contributed to her 12-year-old son's accidental shooting death in 1988. Jan Way of Forth Worth maintains a 16-page advertisement in the September 1988 issue of Boys Life ``influenced and motivated'' her son, Rocky William Miller, and other boys to experiment with a bullet and rifle. The National Shooting Sports Foundation and Remington Arms Company Inc., were also named as defendants in the lawsuit filed in Dallas County District Court. They were listed as sponsors of the advertisements. The lawsuit said Miller died Nov. 19, 1988, after several boys found an old gun and a .22 cartridge and accidently shot him. It said the boys had read the shooting supplements and ``particularly'' an advertisement by Remington. Lee Sneath, national spokesman for the Boy Scouts, said he could not comment on the lawsuit. But he said ``the editorial content as well as a majority of the ads in that advertising supplement stress responsibility and safety.'' Remington spokesman Paul Kbederis also said he could not comment. ``We have not been served with the suit, so we have no knowledge of the allegations,'' he said. Dallas lawyer Windle Turley said the lawsuit sought to stop the Boy Scouts from ``promoting shooting and the sale of ammunitions and firearms to impressionable youth.'' Turley said the amount of damages has not been determined, but they would be in the millions.

DOC.HEAD: Texas A&M Trains Vets to Treat Pet Fish
DOC.TEXT: Hooked on that pet fish of yours? Want to keep him in the swim of things as long as you can? Just send him to the fish doctor for a checkup. More people are doing that these days, said Hugh Bishop, editor of Pets Supplies Marketing magazine, as word spreads that veterinarians can now treat fish with bath solutions and shots and even perform surgery on them. ``Fish are obviously something people do develop an affinity for and would look for some help if they develop a problem,'' Bishop said. He also noted that some people pay as much as $1,000 each for exotic fish. John A. Shadduck, dean of Texas A&M's school of veterinary medicine, said fish studies have been added to his school's programs. ``It's part of our overall attempt to do two things: diversify veterinary medicine and address a societal need,'' he said. But not everyone at the university thinks fish are best kept as pets. Student Roger Parker, who works in food safety, said the only treatment he usually gives fish is ``over a frying pan.''

DOC.HEAD: Vandal Paints Anti-Tax Message on Michel's House
With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The home of U.S. House Minority Leader Robert H. Michel was vandalized with graffiti that expressed displeasure with the federal deficit and tax proposals facing lawmakers. Michel's spokesman labeled the vandalism disgusting and said the congressman was angry and disappointed by the attack. For the second time in nine months, a vandal painted anti-tax messages across the front of Michel's house of more than 35 years, located in this Illinois River city just west of downtown. ``Cut Taxes, Deficit'' and ``Repeal - Stolen Pay Raise'' were sprayed in green paint on the front of the home. A dollar sign, in the same green color, was painted on the door. ``It's one thing for people to disagree with you on the issues of the day, but to take it out on personal property, it's kind of disgusting,'' said Ray LaHood, chief of staff for Michel. Michel was in Washington at the time of the incident, which police said happened between 1 p.m. Saturday and 7:30 a.m. Sunday. The first message appeared to be a comment on the raging deficit debate in Congress and a proposed five-year, $500 billion deficit reduction plan that Michel supported. The second apparently refers to Michel's support for a pay raise for members of Congress and the executive branch approved last December. No one was arrested in the incident and police had no suspects. LaHood said the latest graffiti will be removed in a couple days. Michel is unopposed in his bid for re-election to a 18th term in the House. The 33-year veteran of Congress has been Republican floor leader since 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit by Man Whose Comatose Wife Had Abortion
DOC.TEXT: A man who won the right to order an abortion for his comatose wife cannot sue the hospital and two anti-abortion activists for damages, a judge has ruled. State Supreme Court Justice Harry Hunter on Monday dismissed the $10 million suit filed by Martin Klein, who sought the abortion after doctors told him it might help his wife's chances for recovery. The judge also found that Klein's suit against North Shore University Hospital was ``clearly retaliatory,'' and said the hospital was entitled to have its legal fees reimbursed. Hunter set a hearing for Nov. 7 to determine the amount. Klein's lawyer, Jay Dankner, said an appeal was likely if Klein is penalized at that hearing. The suit, filed in Nassau County in June 1989, said the hospital and activists John Short and John Broderick caused ``emotional distress'' - and cost Klein more than $50,000 in legal fees - in court battles over whether the abortion could be performed. But Hunter ruled Monday that the hospital ``acted properly'' in refusing to allow the abortion unless Klein was appointed his wife's legal guardian by a judge. The judge also found that Short and Broderick's actions ``did not rise to the level of `extreme and outrageous conduct.''' In fact, Hunter wrote, they ``effectively protected Nancy Klein's interests.'' ``I feel vindicated because the court agreed with us that any time one defends life he is doing the right thing,'' Short said. Mrs. Klein, who was about four months pregnant, was injured and left comatose in a car accident in December 1988. Klein went to court in January seeking guardianship, but Broderick and Short challenged him, losing each time but appealing all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court. The high court refused to hear the case. Mrs. Klein, 34, eventually emerged from the coma and lives at a rehabilitation center in Oyster Bay, Dankner said. She is able to communicate and makes frequent trips home to be with her husband and daughter, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Branstad Jog Under the Stars
With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Guided by aides with flashlights, President Bush and Gov. Terry Branstad went jogging under the stars this morning. The pre-dawn outing caught some White House aides by surprise. They scrambled to arrange the standard motorcade of staff and media to accompany the president. But Bush left without reporters shortly after 6 a.m. and was well into his run by the time the press caught up with him at the Des Moines Water Works park. He called out a greeting and continued running. It was dark when he began and dark when he finished. There was just a sliver of moonlight, but the sky was clear and full of bright stars. Bush was in Iowa to raise campaign funds for Branstad and other Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: Former PTL Aides Get Reduced Sentence For Testifying Against Bakker
DOC.TEXT: A judge has reduced the prison sentences of two former PTL aides who testified against Jim Bakker. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter cut five years from the sentences of both James and David Taggart, who are serving time for tax evasion at Maxwell Air Force Base prison camp in Montgomery, Ala. The Taggarts testified against the former PTL leader during Bakker's trial. Bakker, convicted last October of mail fraud, wire fraud and conspiracy, is serving a 45-year prison sentence in Minnesota. ``These defendants' testimony was not crucial in the prosecution of Bakker,'' Potter wrote. ``However, I believe it can be said that their testimony was helpful.'' Even with the sentence reductions, David Taggart is still serving 13 years, 5 months. James Taggart's new sentence is 12 years, 9 months. They likely will not be eligible for parole for four years. Potter's five-page order was issued Friday. David Taggart, Bakker's former personal aide, and James Taggart, PTL's former interior decorator, were convicted in July 1989 of tax evasion and conspiring to impede the IRS in tax collection. They were accused of using more than $1.1 million in PTL money to pay their personal bills and of not reporting that income or paying $525,000 in income taxes from 1984 to 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Little Indication Iraqis Feel Threatened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 13th pvs, ``They're used...' to UPDATE with army newspaper predicting no military action before Christmas. Pickup 14th pvs, `There is...' SUBS 20th pvs, `In the...' to CORRECT subject-verb agreement.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: As soldiers and their war machines mass across the desert in Saudi Arabia poised for battle with Iraq, the people of Baghdad seem to merely shrug and go about their business. Restaurants on the banks of the Tigris River are full until at least 9 p.m., serving their speciality of baked fish. After dinner, people retire to bars, which are open a couple of hours longer. Streets lights keep the city aglow through the night. There's little indication that the people of this city of 4.5 million feel threatened by the possibility of war over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Some say it's fatalism, or perhaps a sense of invicibility. ``It's a strange, psychological buildup where many just can't perceive that anyone can attack Baghdad,'' an Asian diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``There is either a total non-comprehension of the seriousness of the situation - or many Iraqis just don't care.'' On an Iraqi Airways flight from Amman, Jordan, Iraqi children clapped and chanted ``Watan, Watan'' - ``homeland, homeland'' - as the Boeing 737 touched down at Baghdad's Saddam Hussein International Airport. ``Do you see a war fear?'' asked an Iraqi businessman returning from Amman, the only city still connecting Baghdad with the rest of the world following the U.N. air and sea blockade in retaliation for the invasion of Kuwait. ``We are prepared for war but not afraid of it,'' he said. In downtown Baghdad, another Iraqi pointed to the window pane in his office. ``Look at this,'' he said. ``During the war with Iran, we used to tape them so that splinters don't come, but now there is no tape.'' Baghdad residents proudly tell how they lived through eight years of war with Iran. Many don't seem to sense similar hardship or danger in the face of the arsenal at the disposal of the U.S.-led multinational forces camped in Saudi Arabia and patrolling the Persian Gulf and Red Sea. ``You may call it Arab sense of fatalism,'' said an Iraqi, who like most people here spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They're used to the atmosphere of crisis, but maybe they are underestimating the real power of the soldiers sitting across the border,'' he said. ``At least I know that if a war breaks out, it will not be one of the weekend skirmishes. It will be serious, but aren't we prepared?'' Iraq's army newspaper, Al-Qadissiya, today discounted the possiblity of war before Christmas, saying President Bush was not likely to allow American soldiers to come home in coffins during the holiday season. There is little visible civil defense preparedness in Baghdad, where txis fill the streets by the hundreds. Very few soldiers are seen, except to check a passing vehicle occasionally. On Sunday, there was a wedding party at the Sheraton Hotel complete with a Western-style band and dancing. The women, many with glittering jewelry and brightly colored silk and synthetic dresses, swirled slowly around the floor with men in suits and ties. Despite the calm, there's still the sense of unease that has been a hallmark of Baghdad for years. Spontaneous laughter is rarely heard. No one seems to joke. There are no foreign newspapers, books or magazines. Facsimile and telex machines are forbidden. Overseas telephone calls must be placed through operators at the local exchange. The two-channel televison is full of reports of support for President Saddam Hussein and programs on how to grow more vegetables and raise poultry. Food markets are open and doing steady business, but there are few takers at shops selling shoes and clothing. In the bazaar, shops still have stocks of canned food, including beef, corn and peas. Fruit, mostly apples and oranges, is much scarcer. Pepsi Cola seems to be everywhere. Life-saving drugs have disappeared from pharmacies since the blockade was imposed, and the government has rationed nine items: rice, sugar, wheat, cooking oil, tea, soap, laundry detergent, dried beans and powdered milk. Each Iraqi can purchase a monthly allotment that includes 9 pounds of wheat, 3 pounds each of sugar, rice and cooking oil, one bar of soap and 6 pounds of powdered milk. Arab bread, flat and about the size of a big pancake, is limited to three pieces per person a day at government cooperatives. ``The food shortages are affecting, no doubt, but it is not biting yet,'' one Iraqi said. ``We are getting used to the idea of eating less than the body needs. At the same time, no one is dying of hunger and there is no fighting over food.''

DOC.HEAD: New Haven Register CEO Dismissed As More Layoffs Loom
DOC.TEXT: The New Haven Register's chief executive officer was dismissed after clashing with the company's new owners over their decision to lay off more employees. Thomas P. Geyer, 43, opposed the additional layoffs, the second round this month, because he believed they would seriously weaken the newspaper, a company executive said Monday. ``I disagree with that 100 percent, and that's why he is not here,'' said Robert M. Jelenic, president and chief executive officer of the Journal Register Co., of Princeton, N.J. The Journal Register is a holding company of the New York investment firm of E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Co., which acquired the Register and other U.S. newspapers from Ralph Ingersoll II in July. Jelenic said workers would be laid off today in every department, but he declined to give a number. He said the reason was the region's economic slump and sagging advertising revenues. ``Business is bad,'' he said. Geyer, who joined the New Haven daily in 1986, had been a longtime Ingersoll associate. He did not immediately return a telephone call Monday night to his home. The Register laid off 19 employees Oct. 3, and announced that nine vacant positions would be eliminated. Eleven of the employees who lost their jobs earlier this month worked in the newsroom. Jelenic said today's layoffs would be the last round and that the company is taking other steps to reduce costs. He told news employees those steps would include reducing the amount of space for news stories in the Register, Connecticut's second-largest daily. He emphasized the Register remains the biggest and most profitable newspaper in the Journal Register Co., formerly Ingersoll Publications. The Register has a circulation of more than 100,000 daily. Jelenic said a new chief executive officer for the Register would be named in a few weeks. Geyer's first newspaper job was at an Ingersoll paper in Pennsylvania, The Mercury in Pottstown, where he went to work after college. After working as managing editor of a weekly trade newspaper he rejoined Ingersoll in 1974 to become editor of the Claremont (N.H.) Eagle Times. He was named chief operating officer of Ingersoll in 1981. In 1986, Geyer was named editor of the Register and Journal-Courier. His first job was to oversee the consolidation of the morning Journal-Courier and evening Register.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Swedish Academy Citation
With PM-Nobel-Economics
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the text of the citation issued in English by the Swedish Academy of Sciences for the 1990 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. The prize went to Americans Harry Markowitz, Merton Miller and William Sharpe for their work in the theory of financial economics. ---= Financial markets serve a key purpose in a modern market economy by allocating productive resources among various areas of production. It is to a large extent through financial markets that saving in different sectors of the economy is transferred to companys for investments in buildings and machines. Financial markets also reflect companys' expected prospects and risks, which implies that risks can be spread and that savers and investors can acquire valuable information for their investment decisions. The first pioneering contribution in the field of financial economics was made in the 1950s by Harry Markowitz, who developed a theory for households' and companys' allocation of financial assets under uncertainty, the so-called theory of portfolio choice. This theory analyzes how wealth can be optimally invested in assets that differ in regard to their expected return and risk, and thereby also how risks can be reduced. A second significant contribution to the theory of financial economics occurred during the 1960s when a number of researchers, among whom William Sharpe was the leading figure, used Markowitz's portfolio theory as a basis for developing a theory of price formation for financial assets, the so-called Capital Asset Pricing Model, or CAPM. A third pioneering contribution to financial economics concerns the theory of corporate finance and the evaluation of companys' on markets. The most important achievements in this field were made by Merton Miller, initially in collaboration with Franco Modigliani (who received the Alfred Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 1985 mainly for other contributions). This theory explains the relation (or lack of one) between companys' capital asset structure and dividend policy on one hand and their market value on the other.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Soviet Talks Begin on Persian Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Richard Cheney opened talks today with his Soviet counterpart on cooperation in the Persian Gulf crisis and the long-term course of economic and political reforms in the Soviet Union. Cheney and U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock, flying on an Air Force Boeing 707, were welcomed at Sheremyetevo Airport by the defense minister, Marshal Dmitri Yazov, and a Soviet military band. ``I look forward over the next few days to have the opportunity to visit with members of the Soviet armed forces and to exchange views with Marshal Yazov and other Soviet officials about important world issues that face both our two nations at the present time,'' Cheney said on arrival. During the four-day visit, he is to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. He will also inspect an elite airborne unit, an air defense command post and a factory that produces MiG-29 jet fighters. Yazov visited similar military posts during a trip to the United States a year ago. Cheney, speaking with reporters on the flight from London, said he would ask Gorbachev and his aides ``to explain what they are talking about in their long-term plans'' for economic and political reform. The defense secretary, a longtime hard-liner toward the Soviet Union, said he had reached no conclusions on whether Gorbachev's reforms would transform the country. But he praised the announcement Monday that Gorbachev had won the Nobel Peace Prize, saying ``I think it is appropriate.'' Cheney also told reporters on the plane he had no specific requests of the Soviets in the standoff with Iraq. ``They've got to make their own decisions,'' he said. The Soviet Union has not joined the multinational force, but has supported its deployment and the embargo. Shevardnadze on Monday told Soviet lawmakers that the Kremlin had no plans ``for participation in a military operation'' and assured them that any such deployment would require their approval. Cheney said the United Stats was prepared for a ``long haul'' in the gulf and that troops would remain deployed there for as long as necessary. He rejected the notion of a quick strike or any deadline for economic sanctions to succeed in forcing Iraq to end its 10-week-old occupation of Kuwait. ``No one should make the mistake of assuming this is the kind of operation which will be over in a very short period of time,'' Cheney told reporters Monday at a news conference in London. ``The United States is prepared for the long haul if that is what it takes to get the job done,'' he said. In London, Cheney met with British Defense Secretary Tom King and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. From Moscow, Cheney will continue to Paris for the conclusion of his 10-day mission.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon, France Deadlocked Over Aoun's Fate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with army setting up checkpoint outside French Embassy, army engineering units continue work to tear down Green Line dividing city. Pickup 13th pvs, `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: The army today set up a checkpoint outside the French Embassy where defeated Christian Gen. Michel Aoun took refuge, heightening Lebanon's diplomatic quarrel with France over Aoun's fate. Government bulldozers continued removing mines and earth mounds along the five-mile Green Line that divides Beirut into Christian and Moslem sections. Workers on Monday opened one key intersection, the Galerie Semaan crossing, and motorists honked horns in jubilation as they drove through. Several Cabinet ministers today compared the planned dismantling of the Green Line to the removal of the Berlin Wall. The unification of the war-torn Lebanese capital is the next step following Saturday's end to Aoun's 11-month mutiny. Aoun's troops were crushed in a Syrian-led assault. France granted Aoun asylum Saturday, and French President Francois Mitterrand called the decision Monday ``a matter of honor.'' But Lebanese Agriculture Minister Mohsen Dalloul said the government was determined to bring him to trial and have asked the French to turn him over. The army posted an armored personnel carrier and 12 soldiers, one equipped with tear gas canisters, on a checkpoint about 300 feet from the embassy in east Beirut. French diplomats said the measure amounted to a siege. The French news agency Agence France-Presse quoted diplomats as saying large numbers of troops surrounded the embassy and closed all approaches. Reporters on the scene said the small checkpoint made no move to stop people from leaving or entering the embassy or block traffic in its vicinity. Presidential spokeswoman May Kahhaleh said the ckeckpoint was set up to prevent anti-Aoun demonstrations near the embassy. ``It's purely a security measure to protect the embassy, not to blockade it,'' Ms. Kahaleh said. French Ambassador Rene Ala met President Elias Hrawi twice Monday to discuss the impasse over Aoun. Civilians started returning to Aoun's former enclave in the Christian area to repair damage caused during the Lebanese-Syrian assault. Lebanese army engineering units continued work along the Green Line, the five-mile line that has divided the capital into Moslem and Christian sectors since the outbreak of civil war in 1975. ``Berlin has been united and has gotten rid of the wall that had divided it for many years. Now it's Beirut being united with the Green Line ceasing to exist,'' Dalloul was quoted by local radio stations as saying. The government aims at creating a militia-free ``Greater Beirut,'' which covers Beirut's Christian and Moslem sectors and their immediate suburbs, to be policed only by government troops. The main obstacles are the Christian, Shiite and Druse Moslem militias. Police said some of the civilians who fled Aoun's former enclave returned today to repair their damaged property, despite reports that leftist and Moslem militias were kidnapping Christians. The Lebanese army's military police were `trying to keep the situation under control and protect civilians,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with regulations. Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, said the government now ``has enough power to enforce implementation of (last year's) peace pact which calls for disbanding all militias.'' ``I hope that the government will not be obliged to resort to force to implement this.'' he said. He said Dalloul and Defense Minister Albert Mansour were asked to ``set the mechanism'' for disbanding the various militias. He did not elaborate. Aoun had rejected the peace plan agreed to last year that distributed power equally between Moslems and Christians. He refused to accept the November election of Hrawi by members of Parliament and rebelled. Syria is the main power-broker in Lebanon. It has 40,000 troops in the country, deployed in predominantly Moslem regions. Aoun's main objection to the peace plan was that it failed to include a timetable for a Syrian withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Three May Have Been Victims of Asian Gang Turf War
DOC.TEXT: Three members of a Vietnamese gang known as Born to Kill were shot to death, and police said the slayings may stem from turf wars with longer established Chinese gangs. The victims, all in their early 20s but not immediately identified, were found shot in the head at dawn Monday in an outdoor parking lot about three blocks from City Hall. Investigators found three .380-caliber shell casings at the scene, said Officer Scott Bloch, a department spokesman. He said one of the victims had a tattoo of BTK, for Born to Kill, and a second bore a tattoo that he described as ``associated with BTK.'' In a widely publicized incident late in July, gunmen posing as mourners at the New Jersey burial of a BTK member from Chinatown opened fire with several weapons. Seven of the 100 or so people there for the burial were wounded by gunfire, and seven more were injured in the panic. On Oct. 1, a 27-year-old Vietnamese man was shot to death when at least two gunmen sprayed a crowded Chinatown street with more than a dozen rounds of 9mm bullets. Police said the slain man was a member of a gang other than BTK but his killers may have been from BTK, a robbery and extortion gang.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Raise Questions About New Kids' Management
DOC.TEXT: A former millionaire entrepreneur claims in a bankruptcy lawsuit that he is a partner in New Kids on the Block and is entitled to $5 million in the pop group's profits. Jeffrey Furst, who filed for bankruptcy protection early this year, said in his suit that New Kids co-producer Maurice Starr promised Furst and Furst's one-time business partner, James M. Martorano, each a 25 percent interest in the pop group in return for a loan. Starr denied that Furst or Martorano had any partnership in the group. He said he, co-producer Richard Scotts, and the five members of New Kids are the only ones with a stake in the group. Documents released Monday in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court lawsuit include an affidavit by David Jemmott, a state trooper on a leave of absence, that Starr and Furst agreed during a 1988 meeting to be 50-50 partners in the group and shook hands on it. In another affidavit, Middlesex County Sheriff John McGonigle said Starr told him that he and Furst were partners when McGonigle posed with the New Kids for a photograph. In the court papers, Furst said Barry Rosenthal, an attorney for New Kids, oversaw a loan of $175,000 to Starr and drew up corporate documents for Furst and Starr. Furst contends that last December, when he needed money, Starr told him he was not a partner because they had not signed a written agreement. Starr said he did get a $175,000 loan from Furst but paid it back at an interest rate of about 30 percent. Starr said two corporations, Furst-Starr Management Inc. and Furst-Starr Productions, were legally dissolved. But the secretary of state's office said Monday the corporations have not been legally dissolved. The incorporation papers said the corporations were formed to represent and furnish entertainers and performers. Len Lewin, another lawyer for New Kids, said the group is managed by Dick Scott Entertainment Inc., and that New Kids has nothing to do with Furst-Starr Management Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Government Coalition Big Loser in Local Elections
DOC.TEXT: The governing center-right coalition - in power for only six months - fared poorly in local elections over the weekend, while opposition liberal parties made gains, results showed. Turnout for Sunday's voting was low as Hungarians went to the polls for the sixth time in less than a year. It averaged 27 percent in rural Hungary and 36 percent in Budapest. In the first round of the local elections Sept. 30, less than the required 40 percent of eligible voters cast ballots in municipalities of more than 10,000 residents. On Sunday, there was no required minimum turnout. Local elections were the last hurdle as Hungary completed passage from a single-party state to a multiparty democracy. Hungary began its move away from 40 years of Communist Party rule in a democratic revolution late last year. In towns of less than 10,000 inhabitants, the vote was conclusive Sept. 30. More than 80 percent of the mayors and two-thirds of the new council members chosen in those communities ran as independents. Many held office under Communist rule, and their victories were seen as reflecting discontent with the parties now in power and Hungary's worsening economic situation. In larger communities, the main opposition liberal party, the Alliance of Free Democrats, and the more radical League of Young Democrats made gains Sunday. But the center-right governing coalition led by the Hungarian Democratic Forum failed to win wide support. Of the individual constituencies, 302 were won by the Free Democrats, 142 by the Young Democrats, and 289 by a Free Democrat and Young Democrat alliance. Independents won 264 constituencies, the Forum won 195, and its coalition partners the Smallholders and Christian Democrats won 108 and 82 respectively. Recounts are planned in five constituencies. Up for election in the larger communities was a variety of local offices. Some voters cast ballots for lists of candidates for local councils. In some cases, the councils will chose the local officials. In the first free nationwide elections in March and April, the Forum gained 165 seats in Parliament, the Smallholders 43 and the Christian Democrats 21. The Free Democrats won 92, the Young Democrats 21 and the Socialist Party 33 seats. The big prize Sunday was Budapest, where local councils elected Sunday will choose the mayor. Free Democrat Gabor Demszky, a lawyer and veteran dissident under the Communists, appeared the frontrunner in that dispute. The official result in the Budapest mayoral dispute will be announced later this month.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Blames Apartheid For Black-On-Black Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with reaction to end of key apartheid law. Pickup 3rd pvs, `About 800...' Minor editing to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela today welcomed the abolition of a basic law of South African apartheid but said the main issue toward ending segregation is allowing the black majority to vote. The South African black leader spoke at a news conference on the first stop of a three-week Asian tour. He was greeted Monday in India with the pomp usually reserved for heads of state. Monday's end to a 37-year-old law that segregated South African public facilities was ``a step forward,'' Mandela said. But until equal voting rights are achieved, ``any other change will remain peripheral,'' Mandela said. Mandela told a rally of 20,000 people Monday that the black-against-black violence in his homeland emanates from the ``war psychosis'' of living under apartheid. Mandela warned the clashes could undermine efforts to begin negotiations with the white minority government on ending the system of racial segregation. About 800 people have been killed since August in fighting between followers of Mandela's African National Congress and the rival Inkatha movement of Zulu chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi. The latest flare-ups were in the black townships around Johannesburg and in the eastern province of Natal. The rivalry has claimed about 5,000 lives since 1986. He said the violence ``promotes white privileges and domination. It engenders differences over a common humanity. It is calculated to weaken the ANC and abort the process of achieving a peaceful resolution of the conflict created and maintained by apartheid,'' he said. Mandela's Asian tour began in India, where he said the worldwide movement against apartheid was conceived. In 1954, India became the first country to sever diplomatic relations with South Africa and to impose trade and travel restrictions. Mandela paid tribute to Mohandas K. Gandhi, who began developing his strategy of non-violent resistance during his 21 years in South Africa. Gandhi, then a young Indian lawyer, founded the Natal Indian Congress in 1894 to press for the rights of Indians, descended from indentured servants brought to work the sugarcane fields. He left South Africa in 1914 and led India's campaign for independence from Britain. Mandela said the anti-apartheid movement was ``based on the Gandhian philosophy.'' Mandela was released from prison in February after 27 years internment for plotting the overthrow of the government. He was elected the ANC's deputy president. Indian leaders pledged Monday to keep up pressure on the government of President F.W. de Klerk until it adopted irrevocable steps toward dismantling apartheid. Prime Minister V.P. Singh gave Mandela a check for $800,000 and said more money was being set aside for aid to his movement, news agencies reported. Following his trip to India, Mandela is to visit Brunei, Australia, Indonesia, Japan and Malaysia, returning home Nov. 4.

DOC.HEAD: 4-Year-Old Left Alone Calls Wisconsin Looking For Mother
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old girl, left home alone with a bad cold, was found by police after she randomly dialed a Wisconsin county's Health Department in an effort to reach her mother. ``I don't know how she did it,'' said Sarah Weeks, a receptionist at the the Health Department in Walworth County, a farming area east of Wisconsin's capital of Madison. ``It's pretty miraculous.'' Police Monday charged the girl's mother, 27-year-old Luvisca Deligny, with leaving a child unattended, a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to $500 and a 30-day jail term. Deligny said she left her daughter with a roommate while she went to the bank. Police said the mother's roommate left the child alone when they had to go to work. The girl, whose name was not released, began dialing random telephone numbers to try to find her mother. She reached the Walworth County ``Public Health Line'' about 9:30 a.m. ``It was real quiet at first,'' Weeks said. ``Then there was this little voice saying, `Hi.' She talked about her mom and that she wasn't there.'' For the next two hours, Weeks kept her little caller busy singing nursery rhymes and other songs, while authorities traced the call to the Washington area and notified Montgomery County police. About 11:30 a.m., Montgomery County police officers found the girl in a ground-floor apartment. Mother and daughter were reunited at the police station. Interviewed by telephone by The Washington Post, the girl said: ``I said, let me call somebody. I was going to call my mommy. I wanted to tell her I was all alone.'' Deligny said she took the day off to care for her sick child and had left to run an errand. ``I'm still not sure she was on the phone that long,'' she said. ``I'll wait to see the phone bill to determine if it's true.''

DOC.HEAD: Zulus, Xhosas Battle At Coal Mine, 10 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 52 injured, company statement, mine shut down; Pickup 6th pvs ``The fight...''.
DOC.TEXT: Rival Zulus and Xhosas armed with spears and knives clashed at a coal mine in a factional fight that left 10 people dead and 52 others injured, police and the company said today. A police spokesman said the fighting began late Monday at Hlobane Colliery near Vryheid in northern Natal province. The area has been a battleground between conservative Zulu forces and followers of the African National Congress. A group of Zulus went on a rampage in the workers' quarters at the mine, attacking rival Xhosas, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The groups fought with knives, axes and spears, he said. Police said they did not know what started the clash. ISCOR, the state-run iron and steel corporation that operates the mine, said in a statement that 32 people were admitted to a Vryheid hospital and 20 people were at the mine hospital. It said production has been temporarily halted at the mine while management tries to resolve the differences between the groups. The fight followed a clash in Johannesburg in which eight people died. The incidents marked a renewed outbreak of black factional violence after several weeks of relative calm. More than 800 people were killed in factional fighting between Zulus of the Inkatha movement and ANC supporters in black townships around Johannesburg in August and September. Police also said today that two men and one woman were killed in unrest in other parts of Natal during the past 24 hours. One of the men died when two groups armed with spears fought at a bus station in Empangeni. In other developments, police in the black Kwazulu homeland said 43 people were slain over the weekend. The report did not say how many of the deaths were politically motivated. Kwazulu, a semi-autonomous black homeland, is administered by Mangosuthu Buthelezi, head of the Inkatha movement. South African news reports said the clash Monday in Johannesburg began when a mini-bus filled with armed men attacked a workers compound near the Kempton Park district.
