The attackers, some of whom were wearing masks, opened fire on sleeping workers with automatic weapons, the reports said. Unidentified men in mini-buses were blamed for starting much of the fighting in the Johannesburg area last month. ANC leaders charged the attackers were linked to the security forces and were trying to fan black violence. President F.W. de Klerk's government and police commanders have denied the ANC charges. The government imposed curfews and introduced strict security last month in black townships around Johannesburg hit by factional fighting. Curfews had been lifted in some areas and security relaxed in recent days as the fighting appeared to have ended. Police commanders said today that they were keeping a close watch on the violence and would increase security to prevent its spread. The fighting has pitted Inkatha against Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the left-leaning ANC. The two sides oppose apartheid, but differ over goals for a future South Africa, including economic plans and leadership questions.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Receive Gas Masks With A Touch Of Fatalism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th pvs, `Last week...' to UPDATE with Israel beginning training for Palestinian doctors in the occupied territories. Pickup 7th pvs, `Residents of...'
DOC.TEXT: Abdallah Hsein, a bearded auto mechanic, is not afraid of an Iraqi chemical attack. God, he says, will decide if he lives or dies. Yet, like most of the 5,000 Arabs in the south Jerusalem village of Beit Tsafafa, he stood in line to get his gas mask Monday, the first day of nationwide distribution of the protective kits. Handing out the masks to Palestinians points up the contradictions the Israeli army faces in dealing with Arabs in Jerusalem. The government considers the residents of Beit Tsafafa Israeli citizens, but many see themselves as enemies of the Jewish state. Some youngsters receiving the masks in the Arab village said they'd been tear-gassed by the army for stoning soldiers. The government decided earlier this month to hand out the masks to Israel's 4.7 million citizens in case Iraqi President Saddam Hussein makes good on his threats to attack Israel with chemical weapons. Israel today began training Palestinian doctors in the occupied territories on how to prepare for a chemical attack, officials of the Israeli military government said. Lt. Col. Shmuel Ovenboy, spokesman for the military government, said the training was launched because Israel is responsible for the residents under its administration. Masks are also being purchased for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories, the army says, although the government has not announced plans for distributing them there yet. Last week, the army tested its distribution network for gas masks in three small Jewish towns. On Monday, it opened some 400 stations throughout Israel, hoping to distribute two million masks by the end of the week. Residents of Beit Tsafafa trickled into a community cewnter to be among the first Arabs to get the masks. A half-dozen paramilitary border police armed with M-16 assault rifles and clubs were on guard - a sign that not all is peaceful in Beit Tsafafa. Some houses, half-hidden amid dusty olive trees, flew black flags from rooftops in mourning for the 19 Arabs killed by police on the sacred Temple Mount in Jerusalem on Oct. 8. ``The killing won't go without revenge,'' said Hsein, the mechanic who lined up for a mask. ``I don't think any relative of those harmed in the attack will be satisfied by getting a gas mask.'' For Hsein, getting the mask is proving ``our right as Arabs who are living in Israel and paying taxes.'' The Arabs of Beit Tsafafa are an acute double loyalty case. Until Israel captured the Arab sector of Jerusalem in 1967, the border that divided the city divided the village. One quarter was Israeli, the rest Jordanian. Today, many of the villagers support Saddam. The village has lost two people in the nearly three-year Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. ``Saddam, O hero, strike with chemicals,'' a cluster of children defiantly sang into the microphone of an Israel army radio reporter outside the gas mask distribution center. A boy waved a toy pistol. In the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip - unlike in Arab sectors of Jerusalem - Palestinians will have to buy the gas masks. Rabiha Alayan, a smiling, dark-haired secretary who lined up for masks, said she was not afraid of a chemical attack. If it comes and ``somebody remains on the earth after that,'' she said, ``it may change the situation in the area, make things better.'' Mrs. Alayan came to the center only because of her three children. Dozens of children and adults were trying on the masks and listening to Arab instructors as uniformed army officials handed out boxes with protective kits. Hsein was unimpressed: ``I think these masks will not be good against Saddam's chemicals,'' he said. ``Even if Saddam attacks with chemical arms, I'm not afraid. There is God and He decides if I live or die.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Die in Florida House Fire
DOC.TEXT: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. (AP - A fire destroyed a two-story frame house near downtown, killing six people, and six counts of murder were filed today against the husband of one of the victims. The fire was reported late Monday by a police officer who spotted the blaze while on routine patrol, Police Lt. Lorin Mock said. By the time firefighters arrived, the house was fully involved in flames, he said. The man arrested, whose name was being withheld by police, also was charged with setting the fire that killed his wife, another woman, and four children, three girls and a boy, said police spokesman Asa Higgs, who offered no other details. He also was charged with violating an injunction ordering him to stay away from his wife, Higgs said. Investigators did not say how the blaze was started. A man sleeping in a car outside the house was able to save a 3-year-old boy, Mock said.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Party Status Threatened In New York
DOC.TEXT: The foundering campaign of Pierre Rinfret threatens the Republican Party with more than another big loss to Democrat Mario Cuomo in the New York governor's race. Some Republican leaders say there is a chance, albeit slim, that GOP defections and voter apathy could allow Conservative Party candidate Herbert London to out-poll Rinfret on Election Day. Beyond the psychological blow of a third-place finish for the Republicans, such an outcome would have practical political consequences. The GOP would lose its No. 2 ballot spot - Row B - to the Conservatives for at least the next four years. Election experts maintain that higher ballot spots attract more votes. ``It would be absolutely outrageous if the Republican Party were to drop to Row C,'' said Republican state Sen. Roy Goodman. ``I think it's slight, but I think that the possibility of voter apathy, coupled with some of these defections, does pose a threat,'' Goodman said. GOP leaders also are concerned about the impact on crucial state Senate races if Rinfret's stumbling campaign causes rank-and-file Republicans to stay home on Nov. 6. Republicans control the state Senate 32-26 with three vacancies. A Democratic majority in the Senate likely would give the party complete control over the redrawing of congressional and legislative districts next year. Robert Haggerty, the Senate GOP's chief political strategist, said party loyalty should protect the GOP ballot status. But he said the remote possibility that London could best Rinfret was ``something we've got an eye on.'' Haggerty said that to protect the GOP's ballot spot - and GOP Senate incumbents - at least $400,000 would be spent on a get-out-the-vote campaign. A September poll by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion found that 60 percent of those surveyed favored Cuomo while less than 15 percent backed Rinfret. London was at 4 percent. However, Marist pollster Lee Miringoff said London may be picking up strength because of Republican voter dissatisfaction with Rinfret. It's unlikely Republicans will come in third, but ``the only thing that keeps them in the running at this point is the strength of the party line,'' Miringoff said. Were the Conservatives to claim the second spot on the ballot, they would be able to fill several hundred patronage jobs on boards of elections at the state and county levels. London joked about that prospect. ``There probably aren't enough Conservatives to fill all those jobs,'' he said. There are more than 100,000 enrolled Conservatives in New York, and about 3.9 million Democrats and 2.6 million Republicans. The GOP defections to London include U.S. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp and Lewis Lehrman, the GOP's unsuccessful candidate for governor against Cuomo in 1982. Rinfret was a politically unknown economist when desperate party leaders recruited him to run after several prominent party members declined to challenge Cuomo. Last month, Rinfret said his campaign was broke and threatened to quit the race because party leaders hadn't supported him politically or financially. Rinfret has riled GOP regulars with a series of outspoken remarks. He called Kemp ``a lackey for Governor Cuomo,'' and said state Senate Majority Leader Ralph Marino was ``in bed with Cuomo'' on raising state taxes and spending. Goodman was labeled ``one of the most destructive people in the state'' by Rinfret. Rinfret called other Republicans who refused to run against Cuomo ``gutless wonders.'' ``Bizarre behavior,'' said Richard Rosenbaum, a member of the Republican National Committee. Goodman suggested Rinfret needed a rest. London has been quick to take advantage of Rinfret's problems. ``It looks like something produced by Saturday Night Live,'' he said of Rinfret's campaign. ``The Republican Party is quite obviously in desperate shape.''

DOC.HEAD: Small Group Demonstrates Against Gulf Action
DOC.TEXT: A half dozen demonstrators opposed to U.S. military involvement in the Persian Gulf poured a quart of oil onto a patio in front of the American Petroleum Institute today to show support for a Marine who refused to be sent to Saudi Arabia. The protesters read a message from the 22-year-old Marine, Cpl. Jeffrey Paterson, who is confined to his base in Hawaii awaiting a court-martial. Paterson's message urged other Americans to join him in saying: ``Hell, no, we won't go; we won't fight for Texaco.'' Two counter-demonstrators also showed up. David Almasi, who said he worked in a building next door, came to the lunchtime rally with a handmade sign asking: ``Why did Jeff Paterson join the Marines? To surf? Or the free paycheck?'' His companion, Leslie Carbone, carried a Marine Corps flag. Paterson supporters said demonstrations als were planned on his behalf today in San Francisco, Houston, Seattle, Honolulu, New York, Orlando, Fla., and Australia. The protest came just hours after President Bush, on a campaign trip in Iowa, was interrupted by three young men who urged him to ``bring our troops home.'' The demonstrators here, who were outnumbered by reporters at one point, poured the quart of 30-weight motor oil after facing toward the 9th floor offices of institute and shouting anti-war slogans. ``We are here at API because API is the lobbying arm of the oil industry in the United States and they are asking these young guys to go and die for the oil industry,'' said Clark Kissinger, a member of the national council of the organization Refuse & Resist. Bill Wordham, a spokesman for API, said the organization would have no comment. Cynthia Briggs, also a member of Refuse & Resist, read the message from Paterson, in which he said: ``There are no guarantees that anything we do will make any difference at all. ... Maybe the best thing to learn from the military is that the best defense is a good offense. It's time that we take the offensive.'' Paterson, from Hollister, Calif., is apparently the first Marine to file conscientious objector status to avoid combat duty in the gulf. He has been confined to his base awaiting trial since a federal judge ordered him removed from a brig.

DOC.HEAD: Clash Between Rival Groups Kills 10, Injures 52
DOC.TEXT: A clash between rival groups killed 10 people and injured 52 at a northern Natal coal mine as renewed black factional fighting erupted in South Africa, according to reports Tuesday. Eight other people died in violence linked to the political and tribal warfare that has gripped black townships near Johannesburg for two months. A police spokesman said fighting between Zulus and Xhosas broke out late Monday at Hlobane coal mine in northern Natal Province, on South Africa's east coast. The area has been a battleground between conservative Zulu forces and followers of the African National Congress. A group of Zulus attacked Xhosas in the workers' quarters at the mine, the spokesman said on condition of not being identified by name. He said the groups fought with knives, axes and spears, he said. Police said they did not know what started the clash, which killed 10 people. ISCOR, the state-run iron and steel corporation that operates the mine, said in a statement that 32 people were admitted to an area hospital and 20 to the mine hospital. It said mine production was temporarily halted while management tried to resolve the differences between the groups. Also Monday, a mini-bus filled with armed men attacked a workers' compound near the Kempton Park district of Johannesburg, according to news reports. The attackers, some wearing asks, opened fire with automatic weapons on sleeping workers, the reports said. Unidentified men in mini-buses were blamed for starting much of the fighting in the Johannesburg area last month. ANC leaders charged the attackers were linked to security forces and trying to fan black violence. President F.W. de Klerk's government and police commanders have denied the ANC charges. More than 800 people were killed in factional fighting between Zulus of the Inkatha movement and ANC supporters in black townships around Johannesburg in August and September. The fighting had eased in recent weeks after periods in which dozens of blacks died daily. It spread to the Johannesburg area from Natal, where five years of warfare between the black factions has killed more than 5,000 people. Police said Tuesday two men and one woman were killed in separate unrest incidents in other parts of Natal during the previous 24 hours. One of the men was killed when two groups armed with spears fought at a bus station in Empangeni. The government imposed curfews and strict security last month in black townships around Johannesburg hit by faction fighting. Curfews had been lifted in some areas and security relaxed as the fighting eased. Both Inkatha and the ANC oppose apartheid but differ over goals for a future South Africa, including economic plans and leadership questions.

DOC.HEAD: Archaeologists Seeking Evidence of DeSoto Expedition in Chattanooga
DOC.TEXT: A group of archaeologists is searching a wooded area minutes from downtown for evidence that Spanish explorer Hernando DeSoto visited Chattanooga 450 years ago. Every weekend, members of the Chattanooga Regional Anthropological Association head across the Tennessee River from downtown and sift through the soil at Moccasin Bend for Spanish artifacts. They're looking for proof that DeSoto visited Indians there in 1540 while searching for gold, silver and jewels in a three-year expedition across the southeastern United States. Historians know that the explorer ventured into Tennessee and that Spaniards made contact with local Indians, but they are not sure whether the two events coincided. ``He either came through the sphere of influence of Chattanooga just to the east or he marched into it and made contact and perhaps stayed as long as a month in its towns, dealing with its chieftains and extorting corn and other provisions for the army,'' said Major McCollough, association president. ``Chattanooga obviously was one of the great focuses of later Spanish trade and, by implication as much as anything, some of the earliest contacts. The difficulties are that DeSoto himself only brought a small inventory of goods to present.'' The archaeologists, with thig at Hampton Place, a wooded area on Moccasin Bend that was the site of one of several Mouse Creek Indian villages that once dotted the banks of the Tennessee River in southeast Tennessee. The first evidence of Spanish contact at Moccasin Bend was found in 1915 by an archaeologist named Clarence Moore, who spent a year digging at sites along the Tennessee River between Paducah, Ky., and Knoxville. In the 1970s, vandals and grave robbers seeking Indian artifacts plundered the area across the river from Chattanooga's business district, leaving craters that still scar the site. That prompted the creation of the anthropological association in 1982. The group eventually found enough traces of pottery, stone tools and arrow points to confirm the village's existence and configuration. Evidence shows Hampton Place contained a plaza, houses, trophy poles and a burial area, all surrounded by a stockade well in view of the river, McCollough said. ``We knew even from the little bit that was known that it was a big and important historical complex that nobody had ever taken a serious look at or tried to define,'' McCollough said. In 1986, the 960-acre Moccasin Bend site was designated a National Historic Landmark. Last year, the state bought nearby Williams Island and declared it a protected state archaeological area. The association has uncovered about 50 archaeological sites at the two locations, including the buried remains of Indian houses that have been dated to 1540 and 1530. Both houses yielded Spanish artifacts, and McCollough thinks the recent discovery of another buried house in the Moccasin Bend village could produce even mre. But even if the National Geographic project, which will run through next spring, does not find proof of DeSoto's visit, McCollough said, it won't be a failure. ``It's so important, so unusual,'' McCollough said of the Moccasin Bend site. ``So basically we're just working to have it understood and protected for the short run - hopefully so its real value is understood and it has a chance to survive for good.''
