DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Steep Increase In Brain Cancer Among Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Brain cancer has increased by up to 500 percent among elderly Americans, a trend that an expert at the National Cancer Institute calls ``alarming'' because the disease is almost always fatal. ``It once was considered that brain tumors reached a peak rate (among people in their 30s) and then would rapidly decline in the older population, but it now appears that the incidence continues to increase with age,'' said Nigel H. Greig, a National Institute on Aging researcher. ``I think it is alarming.'' In a study to be published Wednesday in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, Greig and three co-authors report that the rate of brain cancer appears to have increased by up to sixfold for elderly age groups in 1985 compared to the rates measured from 1973 to 1974. For persons aged 75 to 79, the rate increased 187 percent, the study finds. For those aged 80 to 84, the rate went up by 394 percent, and the rate of increase was 501 percent for those aged 85 and older. Primary brain cancer rates showed little change in 1985 among younger U.S. population groups, said Greig. ``In virtually all other age groups, the incidence rates were approximately the same as in 1974,'' he said. ``But these groups (the elderly) had a dramatic increase. It is a large rise over a 10-to-15-year period.'' Brain cancer is relatively rare in the population as a whole, representing only about 1.5 percent of the total new cancers diagnosed annually. Each year, there are about 15,000 brain cancer patients in all age groups. Incidence of all types of cancer among all U.S. population groups rose 10.7 percent during the study period, Greig said. The study measured only primary brain tumors - cancers that started in the brain and were not spread there from tumors elsewhere in the body. The most common primary brain tumors among the elderly were glioblastoma multiforme and astrocytoma, two extremely dangerous forms of cancer. ``It (the brain tumor increase) is alarming from the point of view that it is a lethal disease with a dismal prognosis,'' said Greig. ``It is also alarming because treatment is not particularly good right now. And it's alarming that with the treatment that there is, the survival time of the elderly is poorer than for the young patient.'' Half of all patients are dead of such tumors within 10 months, he said. Improved diagnostic techniques may explain some of the increase in brain cancers found among the elderly, Greig said. Since the use of X-ray computed tomography, or CAT scan, became widespread in the late 1970s, brain tumors are more easily detected. Precise diagnosis before CAT scans depended upon invasive techniques, such as intercranial biopsies, that were usually not performed on the elderly, he said. Stanley I. Rapoport, a co-author in the study, said the increase may also come from a greater interest in the health of the elderly since the 1970s. ``People then essentially gave up on the elderly,'' he said. ``They didn't spend much time evaluating their mental dysfunction.'' Now, with a greater interest in Alzheimer's disease, said Rapoport, doctors tend to seek a precise diagnosis for brain disease symptoms among the elderly. But Greig and Rapoport both said they believe at least part of the detected increase in brain cancer is not a result of sharper diagnostics. ``We feel that there is a true increase and we're are trying to determine just what that is,'' said Greig. As to the cause, Rapoport said ``there is a possibility that it is environmental factors to which we are all exposed, but we don't know that yet.'' Other co-authors in the study were Lynn G. Ries, of the National Cancer Institute, and Rosemary Yancik of the National Institutes of Health. The National Institute on Aging and the National Cancer Institute are both part of the National Institutes of Health.

DOC.HEAD: Youngsters Have Study Hall in Former Crack House
DOC.TEXT: Two social workers have set up an after-hours tutoring program for school kids in quarters once used by drug dealers. ``Drug lab to learning lab,'' said Sister Julia Huiskamp. About 50 pupils have signed up to participate in the study hall at Villa Griffin housing project. Sister Huiskamp and Sister Diane Sonneman have furnished the two-bedroom apartment with donated desks, books and study cubicles. ``Most of our children are right here from Villa Griffin,'' said Sister Sonneman. Sister Huiskamp also has asked that suitable convicts be made available as tutors and reading instructors to serve their court-ordered community service at the public housing project. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Belleville runs the after-school learning lab in cooperation with the East St. Louis Housing Authority. Stephanie Stafford, the authority's director of operations, said the drug dealers who had rented the apartment were evicted after undercover state police detectives recently raided it.

DOC.HEAD: Baltimore City College - Isn't
DOC.TEXT: Most college graduates have no trouble naming their alma mater, but four corporate executives did when asked by Standard and Poors, the national financial rating agency. Standard and Poors' latest Executive College Survey lists four executives as having received degrees from Baltimore City College. As Baltimore residents know well, Baltimore City College is a high school. ``We'll do our best to rectify this,'' said Ellen Hartery, assistant supervisor of Compmark Data Services, the Standard and Poors subsidiary that compiles the survey. The survey is designed to show which colleges graduate the most people who go on to become corporate executives. It lists roughly 500 colleges and about 54,000 executives, Hartery said Tuesday. The survey form asked executives to list their undergraduate and graduate degrees. Hartery said the number of entries made it impossible for S&P to verify the information. Baltimore City College is accustomed to confusion over its name, said college spokesman Joseph Antenson. ``We get calls several times a day from people wanting to enroll in graduate programs or people trying to contact the CCB (Community College of Baltimore),'' Antenson said.

DOC.HEAD: Boot Camp Readies a Few Good Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Armed with pencils and notebooks, 40 raw recruits have begun political boot camp - a three-week drilling in campaign tactics such as the sound bite, the fund-raiser and the media event. They are preparing for battle in next year's elections for the newly empowered and enlarged City Council. ``You will work very hard. We will ask a lot of you,'' David Fleischer, the program's organizer, told the neophytes. ``Saturday and Sunday will be free for homework'' - writing speeches and raising money. ``But no matter how tough we are here, it won't be as tough as when you go out and start your campaign,'' he added. ``The more you get into shape here, the readier you'll be to run and to win.'' A new city charter gives the council new powers and 16 new seats, for a total of 51. The program's organizers, a coalition of good-government and community groups, want to give it some new blood as well - in recent years only 1.5 percent of incumbents seeking re-election were defeated. The student candidates come from all five boroughs and both major parties, 65 percent are members of racial minorities, and 55 percent are women. They came to class Monday at the Bank Street College of Education in upper Manhattan looking for information, courage and eloquence. Saleem Shah, 43, a Republican from Harlem, couldn't name his party's last victory there. He said he wanted to learn about the new city charter so he can show Harlem voters he can use it to get more help for their community. Anna Capell, an elderly handicapped rights advocate from the Bronx, uses a wheelchair. ``I have the confidence, but I think they will embellish it here so I will not be frightened by getting run over by a political machine,'' she said. Tom Gebert's voice cracked the first time he spoke to a group of parents and teachers at a school board candidate's night in Queens. Now, at 29, the attorney is ready for a bigger forum, but admitted: ``there's a big difference between speaking to 30 people and speaking to 300 or 3,000. As the groups get larger, so do your apprehensions.'' The candidates will attend a series of lectures and workshops featuring political pros such as Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, media adviser Jonathan Schenker, political strategist Joel Bradshaw and election law expert Jerome Koenig. Things they say a candidate should do: -Think like a journalist. Write a speech as if you're also writing a story about it. ``If you don't write the headline and the lead you want, why should the reporter?'' asks Schenker. -Make news, and make it before noon. ``Or at least by 1 p.m.,'' says Schenker. ``By mid-afternoon everyone is editing videotape.'' -Raise as much money as possible before Jan. 15, the financial disclosure deadline. ``That's when reporters write their stories, and you have to have raised enough money by then to demonstrate to everyone that you're a serious candidate,'' Fleischer says. -Think. ``Most campaigns don't,'' says Bradshaw, an adviser to several Democratic candidates around the nation. ``They think strategy is deciding whether to have buttons or bumper stickers.'' Things NOT to do: -Waste reporters' time. ``Come up with quotable quotes, and count the number of words in them,'' says Schenker. ``You can speak about three words a second and 180 words a minute. For television, 15 to 40 words is quotable.'' -Look at the camera. ``Look at the interviewer. Television captures the interaction between people,'' says Schenker. ``And if you look at the camera, you might not be looking at the right one.'' -Overextend yourself. ``Look at yourself in the mirror every morning and repeat, `I can't do everything,' '' advises Messinger. Messinger also told the candidates that before getting started, they should go out and shake hands with some strangers. ``If you can't do that, you shouldn't run,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Relaxes Rules on Foreign Travel
DOC.TEXT: Cuba has informed U.S. diplomats that it is lowering from 55 to 45 the minimum age for Cuban men to visit relatives in the United States. The requirement for women was reduced from 50 to 40 years, officials said Tuesday. U.S. officials said the Cuban move to increase traffic between the two countries may have been prompted by Cuba's desire to increase hard currency holdings. Alternatively, the officials said, Cuba may be hoping that large numbers of those who leave will never return to the island, thereby easing housing and other shortages. ``We could be faced with a legal Mariel,'' said one official, referring to the boat lift 10 years ago that brought an estimated 125,000 Cubans without documents to Florida. The official added that U.S. consular officials will have to issue visas on the basis of whether they believe applicants are going to remain in the United States. ``If we think he's an intending immigrant, we wouldn't issue a visa,'' the official said. There was no immediate comment from Cuba's diplomatic mission here. The U.S. officials, asking not to be identified, said the liberalized travel rules most likely have an economic motivation because of the steady decline in the Cuban economy. Reductions in the delivery of oil and other goods by the Soviet Union to Cuba has forced the government to take draconian austerity measures. Cuba's ability to import has been severely restricted by low levels of hard currency holdings. Regular air service between the United States and Cuba was suspended three decades ago but there are three L-1011 ``humanitarian'' flights a week between Havana and Miami, each carrying a maximum of 316 passengers. They permit elderly Cubans to visit their U.S. relatives and also allow Cuban-Americans to visit family members on the island. In the latter category, Cuba has increased the number Cuban-Americans permitted to travel to Cuba each year from 2,500 to 5,000, the officials said. Cubans visiting the United States are permitted by their government to return with a maximum of $500. They are required to exchange their dollars for pesos at the official rate. Immigration has been a sore point in U.S.-Cuban relations for years. Under a 1987 agreement between the two countries, Cuba claimed the United States committed itself to accept 20,000 emigrants a year from Cuba. U.S. officials denied that any such commitment was made, pointing out that immigration levels are based on whether a would-be emigrant has close relatives in the United States who are U.S. citizens. Many Cuban immigrants have never become U.S. citizens, thereby reducing the number of Cubans still on the island who would qualify for permission to emigrate. U.S. officials said about 3,500 Cubans have been emigrating annually to the United States. Former political prisoners are treated as a separate category. An average of 3,000 have been admitted annually as refugees.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Misses TV Broadcast Announcing She Won $2 Million
DOC.TEXT: NBC broadcast the winning number to the nation, but Tanya Jackson didn't learn until the next day she had won $2 million - she doesn't have a television set, at least not yet. She won the prize through the ``McMillions on NBC'' contest. Players pick up numbered game cards at McDonald's restaurants and the winning numbers are announced during prime time each night on NBC. Ms. Jackson's number was announced Sunday night on a break during NBC's ``Hull High'' program. She found out she was a winner when her father, Burbert, drove her to a McDonald's the next day to check. ``He said the number, and I started screaming that I'd won the money,'' the 22-year-old eastern Indiana woman said. ``I said, `Let me recheck the ticket.' But she was right,'' her father said. ``She sure had a ball going home.'' The woman plans to use the money to pay off medical bills for herself and her mother. She recently broke her ankle, and her mother suffers from a bone ailment. She's luckier than Thelma and Charles Bellows, of Kawkawlin, Mich. They had the winning number for a $10 million prize in the contest last week and starting making plans for a new house and furniture and a trip to the Caribbean. They even started work on a McDonald's commercial. Then McDonald's executives learned that their daughter, Charlene, works at a McDonald's in Auburn, Mich., and the Bellows were automatically disqualified.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Asks Public To Help Decide Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A county judge is taking his court to the people. Berkeley County Circuit Judge Patrick Henry III is asking residents to help him decide how to sentence former city dispatcher Kimberly Gaither, who pleaded guilty to embezzling more than $6,000 from the city. Henry ordered Gaither on Monday to spend 60 days at the Pruntytown Correctional Center while he gets opinions from ``the little man on the street.'' The judge said Tuesday he would accept written comments to the court or to the probation officer. Henry said deciding a sentence for Gaither is difficult because she was once married to a state trooper and is now married to a city police detective. Henry said he doesn't think Gaither will be a repeat offender, but he thinks she should serve some time because she violated the public's trust. Gaither pleaded guilty in July to two counts of embezzlement of funds and falsifying city records from 1985 to 1989 while a dispatcher. She is scheduled to report to prison Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Rejects Hurd's Appeals For Compromise On U.N. Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: A defiant Israel on Tuesday rejected appeals by British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd to find a way to cooperate with a U.N. inquiry into the Temple Mount killings. However, Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said he was willing to meet with a U.N. fact-finding team if it comes to Israel to look into the fatal police shootings of at least 19 Palestinians on Oct. 8. ``I think that I am secure (enough) in our intentions and with the situation in Jerusalem, that whoever comes here I can receive them and answer them,'' Kollek told Israel radio. ``Not to do this doesn't portray strength. It portrays weakness.'' Avi Pazner, spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said Shamir was cool to Kollek's idea. ``A mission that comes to Israel should see the government and not mayors,'' he said. Hurd met separately Tuesday with Shamir and Foreign Minister David Levy, urging them to find a way to compromise on the U.N. inquiry. Pazner said Shamir refused. He quoted the prime minister as saying: ``This resolution deals with the question of Jerusalem, which is our capital, and we don't see any reason for the United Nations to investigate here.'' Government officials said Hurd, in his meeting with Levy, suggested that Israel separate the U.N. Security Council condemnation of the Temple Mount shootings from the call for an investigation. The British foreign secretary said Israel could reject the criticism but agree to see a U.N. fact-finding team, according to the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Hurd, who plans to meet with Palestinian leaders on Wednesday, refused to tell reporters about his meetings with Shamir and Levy. Levy told reporters that the U.N. resolution on the inquiry places ``demands that Israel cannot accept under any circumstances.'' He added: ``The basis of this (U.N.) delegation was a serious indictment against Israel before the facts were checked.'' Israel has been under increasing pressure to accept the U.N. inquiry into the shootings at the Temple Mount, known to Arabs as Haram al-Sharif. More than 140 Palestinians were wounded in addition to the deaths. President Bush made it clear Monday that he wants Israel to cooperate with the United Nations. ``We want to see that U.N. resolution fully implemented,'' Bush said. The Israeli Cabinet decision Sunday to reject the U.N. resolution came despite an appeal by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker said that rejecting the inquiry would detract from international efforts to solve the Persian Gulf crisis. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar says he has not yet decided if he will send a fact-finding team to Israel. Several Israeli newspapers published editorials Tuesday urging the government to allow the U.N. investigatation. The daily Yedioth Ahronoth noted that the government allowed a visit by Hurd, although ``he and his people were the architects of the Security Council resolution against us.'' Levy said the unanimous Security Council decision ignored the fact that police fired on the Temple Mount because Palestinians had stoned Jews worshiping at the nearby Western Wall, Judaism's holiest site. Palestinians have maintained that the stoning was provoked by rumors that an extremist Jewish group was marching on the Temple Mount mosques to symbolize Israeli control. Israel has rejected any move that would call into question its sovereignty over all of Jerusalem, including the Arab eastern sector captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The annexation has not been accepted by the United Nations or by most Western countries, including the United States. Seymour Reich, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, told a news conference here he was assured by Shamir that Israel's own investigation of the killings would be completed next week. ``It very well may be this report may be made available to the United Nations ... and hopefully it can be utilized by the United Nations and may satisfy the needs of the Security Council,'' Reich said. The government has appointed a three-man independent panel to investigate the shootings.

DOC.HEAD: US Increases Rewards For Information on Terrorists
DOC.TEXT: The United States raised the ante in the war against terrorism Tuesday, announcing that rewards up to a possible $4 million will now be paid to obtain information on major terrorist operations. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who announced the increase, also launched a radio and television campaign featuring actors Charlton Heston, Charlie Sheen and Charles Bronson encouraging the public to help develop information leading to the arrest or conviction of terrorists. Under the new program, the $2 million in reward money previously provided by the federal government will be bolstered by donations of $1 million each from the Air Transport Association, representing the U.S. airline industry, and the Airline Pilots Association, representing 42,000 commercial pilots. The $2 million contributed by the airlines and pilots is earmarked for rewards for information involving terrorist attacks on U.S. civil aviation. The expanded rewards campaign comes amid increasing concerns that Iraq may launch or inspire terrorist attacks against Western targets in retaliation against the United Nations economic blockade ordered after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``Obviously we are quite concerned about the threats that have emanated from Baghdad,'' Baker said. ``We will be very alert ... to the possibility that there will be an expansion of terrorism worldwide.'' Such acts as the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, and last week's assassination of the speaker of the Egyptian parliament, Baker said, ``are meant to seize us with horror, to bring daily life to a standstill, to hold entire nations hostage.'' ``Even as we recoil in horror at the carnage, there are ways that governments and citizens can work together to ensure that the warped psychology of the terrorist does not dominate our lives or distort our policies,'' Baker said. ``Every government and every citizen has a stake in bringing terrorists to justice,'' he said, adding that the rewards program can play a key role. Baker disclosed that $500,000 in rewards were paid out last year for information about terrorists and their operations. He declined to give details, saying they are classified to protect the informants. ``We can also relocate people who provide helpful information, and that's been done,'' he said. The television and radio commercials have been produced in six languages: English, French, German, Spanish, Arabic and Greek. Each encourages the sending of information concerning terrorism and asks the question: ``Are you the next hero?'' State Department officials said they are negotiating with U.S. radio and television networks to broadcast the commercials free of charge, and that at least one television network thus far has shown interest. They did not identify the network. The officials said the U.S. Information Agency and U.S. diplomatic missions overseas would make efforts to have the spots shown in other countries. Persons not wishing to approach a U.S. Embassy or consulate are urged to write ``HEROES, Box 96781, Washington, D.C., 20090-6781.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Americans Win Nobel Prize In Economics
LaserPhotos STO1, CX4, TOK11
DOC.TEXT: Three Americans who gave investors, stockholders and corporate directors a better understanding of the intricate financial markets won the Nobel memorial prize in economics Tuesday. Harry F. Markowitz of the City University of New York, Merton Miller of the University of Chicago and William Sharpe of Stanford University will share the prize, worth about $700,000. Since the prize in economics was first awarded by the Swedish Academy of Sciences in 1969, 18 of the 30 winners have been Americans. ``There has been a very powerful and rich development of finance economy as a scientific subject, and that was a main reason for giving them the prize,'' said academy committee member Bengt Naslund. The academy said financial markets serve a key purpose in a modern market economy by allocating resources to various production areas. ``It's important that these markets function efficiently. That, they can really only do if we have a proper understanding of them,'' Naslund said. Therefore, he said, Markowitz, Sharpe and Miller made ``an essential contribution which concerns us all.'' Miller, 67, said he thought it was a crank call when committee chairman Assar Lindbeck called him early Tuesday with the news. ``I picked up the phone, and you don't hear anything ... and suddenly I hear a voice with a Swedish accent, and my heart stopped a bit,'' he said. Lindbeck said Miller and Sharpe were ``really stunned'' by the news but recovered enough to ask about the exchange rate for kronor. The academy deayed announcing the prize for about 45 minutes while trying to reach Markowitz in Japan, where he begins teaching a course Wednesday at Tokyo University. But reporters found him first. ``I'd thought it was never going to happen,'' the 63-year-old Markowitz said. Markowitz developed a theory in the 1950s explaining how households and companies choose shares and reduce the risks involved, the so-called theory of portfolio choice. ``His theory analyzes how wealth can be optimally invested in assets which differ in regard to their expected return and risk, and thereby also how risks can be reduced,'' the academy said. Markowitz published his pioneer works in 1952 and 1959. Sharpe and Miller drew on his theories. ``My work follows Harry Markowitz,'' said Sharpe, reached in Arizona. ``He was my mentor. ... I owe him a huge debt.'' Sharpe, 56, developed the Capital Asset Pricing Model in the 1960s. It is considered the backbone of modern price theory for financial markets. The model helps in calculating capital costs associated with investments and takeovers, regulating public utilities and deciding court cases involving expropriated firms whose shares are not listed on stock exchanges. It is also used in empirical analysis to arrange statistical data systematically and efficiently. Miller showed what factors determine a company's choices in accruing debt and distributing assets. ``He underscored the important relationship between a company and that same capital market which the other two prize-winners analyzed,'' Naslund said. Miller's theory is based on the assumption that stockholders have access to the same capital market as firms. As a result, corporate managers saw that the best way to safeguard the interests of stockholders was to maximize the firm's net wealth. Miller initially collaborated with 1985 economics prize-winner Franco Modigliani of the United States. ``Our work was known as the Modigliani-Miller propositions of corporate finance,'' Miller said. ``He then won it (the prize) for his contributions with me, but also for his other work in economics.'' The economics prize was instituted in 1968 by Sweden's Central Bank to complement the five prizes established in the will of dynamite inventor Alfred Nobel. Nobel's original prizes in physics, chemistry, medicine, peace and literature have been awarded since 1901. The Nobel physics and chemistry prizes are to be announced Wednesday. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was awarded the peace prize on Monday. Mexican poet and essayist Octavio Paz won the prize in literature, and Americans Joseph E. Murray and E. Donnall Thomas won the prize in medicine. The prizes are presented Dec. 10, the anniversary of Nobel's death in 1896.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Asked to Probe National Merit Tax Exemption
DOC.TEXT: A private research group asked the Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday to investigate the tax-exempt status of the National Merit Scholarship Corp., contending it discriminates against women and minorities. The National Center for Fair & Open Testing, known as FairTest, said only those students who are the highest scorers on the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test-National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test are eligible to compete for the ``prestigious and financially-valuable awards.'' And it said those tests are biased against ``non-white and female students.'' National Merit officials said they were unaware of the letter and did not immediately respond further. Internal Revenue Service officials said the matter was confidential and refused to comment. In a letter to IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr., FairTest officials said, ``The Internal Revenue Service has previously determined that institutions which fail to follow racially nondiscriminatory policies are not to be considered 'charitable.' This policy requires, among other things, that schools not discriminate on the basis of race in their scholarship programs.'' National Merit's ``exclusive reliance on scores from a biased exam ... violates this fundamental policy of nondiscrimination. Therefore, (National Merit) should not be subsidized by federal money through tax exemption,'' said the letter. FairTest, a Cambridge, Mass., research organization, estimated that minority students, who make up a quarter of high school graduates, receive a much smaller proportion of the National Merit Awards. National Merit declines to make public an ethnic breakdown of scholarship winners. FairTest said it also has found that nearly two-thirds of the semifinalists are boys. ``Thus rather than selecting from among the brightest and best college-bound students, (the program) picks finalists from a pool of outstanding test-takers by eliminating 99.5 percent of all applicants solely on the basis of their score on a discriminatory test,'' the organization's letter said. ``Talented women and minorities, many at the top of their class, are thereby eliminated from the competition by a single test score, which even the test-makers say should never be used in isolation,'' said the letter. If the scholarship process were fair, young women, who receive better grades than young men in both high school and college and make up 54 percent of the qualifying test takers, would earn at least that proportion of the awards, or $4.4 million more than they currently receive, said the letter. It was signed by FairTest Executive Director Cinthia Schuman and by Sarah Stockwell, the organization's university testing coordinator.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: State And Local Tax Revenues Up 7.5 Percent in Fiscal 1989
DOC.TEXT: State and local governments increased their tax revenues by 7.5 percent each in the 1989 fiscal year, collecting $469 billion, the Census Bureau reported on Tuesday. Property taxes were the largest source. State and local governments reported total revenues, including taxes, of $953 billion, up 7.8 percent over 1988 when they were $885 billion. The 1989 revenues included $161 billion for a variety of services, $126 billion from the federal government and $111 billion from insurance trusts. Their spending in the 1989 fiscal year totaled $891 billion, a 7.8 percent increase, including $263 billion for education, $95 billion for public welfare and $71 billion for government-operated utilities. States collected $284 billion and local governments $185 billion in taxes, the Census Bureau said in a preliminary report. The total in 1988 was $436 billion. The increase for 1989 was lower than the average for the previous five years when local taxes went up an average of 8.4 percent a year and state taxes 7.6 percent. The bureau released some of the state figures in August and they showed that eight states had increases of more than 10 percent, including 22.5 percent for Oregon and 14.2 percent for California. Only Utah and South Dakota reported decreases in state tax collections. State fiscal years do not always end on Sept. 30, as does the federal government's, but Henry Wulf of the Census Bureau said that the figures for each state cover a single year, no matter when that ends. The new report included local government tax revenues and showed that property taxes produced $143 billion, or 30 percent of the total. All but $5.4 billion of that went to local governments. General sales taxes produced $113 billion and individual income taxes $98 billion. Together with property taxes, these provided nearly three of every four tax dollars collected by state and local governments. General sales taxes of $93 billion and individual income taxes of $89 billion provided nearly two-thirds of state revenues. Local property taxes rose 7.8 percent over 1988, slightly below the average annual increase since 1984 of 8.2 percent. Debts for state and local governments were $798 billion, up from $755 billion in 1988. About two-thirds, or $503 billion, was owed by local governments.

DOC.HEAD: Wine Brawl Wrecks Wedding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: A dispute over three cases of leftover wine at a wedding reception erupted into a brawl, which ended with the arrest of the bride's father and of members of the wedding party. Michael Calise, whose daughter was married Sunday, had paid for the wine and wanted to take it home when the reception ended. But Rolando Trovini, owner of the reception hall, said state liquor law prohibits removing liquor from the hall. That's when the fighting started. ``We ended up being assaulted,'' Calise said. ``Physically and psychologically battered. They descended on us so quickly - it was the most astounding thing that's ever happened to me.'' Trovini called police, who arrested Calise, 50, on charges of interfering with police, breach of peace and refusing to be fingerprinted. His daughter, Maria, 27, a bridesmaid, and his son, Frank, 23, also were arrested for interfering with police. Two other people also were arrested. ``One can't imagine what it's like to have a wonderful wedding, marry off a daughter, expend large sums of money and have something this astounding happen,'' Calise said. Trovini, owner of Sante's Manor, told police the wedding party caused $6,000 worth of damage. ``They pay for six hours of wedding - it doesn't mean they can take the place with them,'' he said. ``There was a lot of chaos here.'' Calise said he had purchased the wine himself from a winery rather than use the wine supplied by Sante's. However, state liquor law prohibits removing alcohol from an establishment, even if it is brought by a group renting a hall, said Jerry Langlais, a spokesman for the state Department of Liquor Control. The bride, Sandra Calise, and the groom, Carmine Cenatiempo, left for their honeymoon Monday - a day late.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says More Americans Contributing To Charity, Volunteering
DOC.TEXT: Led by baby boomers, Americans are giving more time and money to charitable causes, a Gallup Poll said Tuesday. The average household contributed $734, or 2 percent of income, in 1989, an increase of 20 percent after inflation compared to 1987, the survey said. Over the same period, the number of adults doing volunteer work grew 23 percent, from 80 million to 93.4 million. ``If these encouraging trends continue, we truly can predict a renaissance of philanthropy in America,'' said Virginia A. Hodgkinson, vice president of Independent Sector, which commissioned the survey. About 65 percent of donations, an average of $477, went to religious organizations or causes. Among others, $60 went to human services, $56 to education, $46 to health, $28 to youth development and $19 to arts, culture and humanities. Nine percent of families donated 5 percent or more of their household income,, the poll said. Gallup questioned 2,727 adults over the age of 18 from March to May this year. It carried out a similar poll in 1988 covering 1987 charitable activities. The results indicated that 71 million households, or 75 percent of the total, contributed to charity in 1989, up from 65 million, or 71 percent, in 1987. Among respondents aged 35 to 44, 86 percent of households gave to charity, up from 77 percent in 1987. People doing volunteer work grew from 45 percent to 62 percent in the 25-34 age group and from 54 percent to 64 percent in the 35-44 age group. ``The dramatic increases in donating time and money among the baby boom generation is good news for today and may suggest even better news for the future as this very large population group assumes community responsibility,'' said Independent Sector President Brian O'Connell. Independent Sector is a coalition of corporate and voluntary organizations that promote volunteerism and not-for-profit initiatives. The survey found that 61 percent of black families contributed to charities, up from 51 percent in 1987, and that the percentage of black volunteers rose from 28 percent to 38 percent. The average American adult did 2.2 hours of volunteer work a week, the poll said. The largest group of volunteers, 17.7 percent, helped religious organizations, followed by 10.1 percent in education and 9.7 percent in youth development. Fifty-eight percent of families who don't attend religious services contributed to charity, compared to 88 percent for families who go to services weekly. The survey also found that lower-income families are comparatively more generous than the rich. Contributing families with incomes under $10,000 annually gave 5.5 percent of their incomes, while the rate was 1.7 percent for those in the $50,000-$60,000 income bracket and 2.9 percent for those making $75,000 to $100,000. ``In comparison to lower-income families and, in contrast to their disposable income, most wealthy Americans have to be characterized as stingy,'' O'Connell said. The survey's margin of error was plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pit Bulls Attack Bumper of Appraiser's Car
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes, it's a dog-eat-car world for appraisers in Tulsa County. Appraiser Bob Bryant said his 1979 Toyota received $166 in damage when two pit bulls chewed through the rubber portion of his front bumper and gnawed at the paint Oct. 4 after he had appraised property in north Tulsa. Bryant said he petted the pit bulls - two adults and two pups - before he got into his car. ``As I drove from the property, the two adult dogs ran along beside and in front of my car,'' Bryant said. ``I knew they were biting at my tires because I could feel them bumping the side of my car.'' He said the dogs gave up the chase after a quarter-mile. Wayne Carr, county finance director, said the dogs' owner has been sent a letter seeking repayment. Carr said the dogs should have been tied up. It was not the first time a dog has attacked an appraiser's car. ``A few years ago, a Doberman bit a hole in a Honda's tire,'' Carr said.

DOC.HEAD: France, Lebanon Try to Ease Quarrel; Dismantling of Green Line Continues
DOC.TEXT: Army bulldozers removed more mines along the capital's dividing Green Line Tuesday, and France sought to ease an escalating quarrel with Lebanon over the fate of Gen. Michel Aoun. President Elias Hrawi pledged to reunify the nation and end its 15-year civil war. He said he would work from the bombed-out presidential palace, where Aoun had his headquarters, even if he has to put up a tent. Aoun spent a fourth day in the French Embassy in east Beirut, where he fled Saturday after being defeated in an eight-hour Syrian-led blitz. The assault, which left 160 people dead, ended the Christian general's 11-month mutiny. France promptly granted Aoun asylum. But the Lebanese government refuses to allow him to leave the country and wants to try him on a variety of charges, including the theft of state funds. On Tuesday, the government set up a military checkpoint near the embassy, but said the measure was designed to prevent anti-Aoun demonstrators from storming the building. ``France and Lebanon do not intend to permit a crisis to develop between them,'' French Ambassador Rene Ala told reporters after meeting Hrawi in Moslem west Beirut. It was his third meeting with the Lebanese president in 24 hours. Reporters on the scene said soldiers at the checkpoint made no move to stop people from getting into or out of the embassy or block traffic in the vicinity. Aoun began his mutiny in November 1989 after rejecting an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's civil war, which has killed an estimated 150,000 people. He called Hrawi, like himself a Maronite Catholic, a ``Syrian puppet'' and refused to recognize his government. The peace plan provides for the traditionally dominant Christians to share power with the Moslem majority. Aoun rejected the plan because there was no timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops. Bulldozers, meanwhile, continued to remove mines along the Green Line Tuesday, a day after authorities opened a key intersection to traffic. Several Lebanese compared the dismantling of the Green Line - a series of earth mounds that have split Beirut into Moslem and Christian sections since 1975 - to the removal of the Berlin Wall. ``There's a ray of hope now,'' Moslem housewife Jinan Sukkar said. ``Berlin has been united and has gotten rid of the wall that had divided it for many years,'' Agriculture Minister Mohsen Dalloul was quoted as saying. ``Now it's Beirut being united with the Green Line ceasing to exist.'' Hrawi told a delegation representing the Christian population in Aoun's former enclave that ``very soon I'll be in the palace. I won't wait for reconstruction works. I'll erect a tent there and receive people.'' He said that ``hostile acts'' by some pro-Syrian leftist militias that infiltrated into Aoun's former territory after his forces collapsed ``would be eliminated soon.'' ``I'll re-unify the nation,'' Hrawi pledged. In parts of Christian east Beirut and in Aoun's former stronghold, people spoke of alleged looting by the Syrians and their militia allies. Motorists were taking detours to avoid Syrian checkpoints in streets where posters of Aoun had been replaced by those of President Hafez Assad of Syria. As Hrawi spoke Tuesday, Syrian-backed Christian militiamen led by Elie Hobeika were seen patrolling the streets of suburban Hadath, southeast of Beirut, checking identity cards and searching houses along with Syrian soldiers for Aoun loyalists. ``Last night Hobeika's men searched the house for my two brothers, who were soldiers serving under Aoun,'' said a native of Hadath, who identified herself only as Georgette. ``I told them that I haven't seen them since the attack on Saturday. They didn't beat me or anything, they only searched the house and left,'' Georgette said. ``I wonder why didn't Aoun surrender to Hrawi's army. It would have been much better than having the Syrians and their allies humiliating us,'' she said. Syria, which has 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate, considers the country its strategic backyard. The fall of Aoun has strengthened its hold on the country. Also Tuesday, Parliament re-elected Hussein Husseini, a Shiite Moslem, as speaker for a four-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Survival Up, Despite Medicare's Hospital Payment Limips
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 4 p.m. EDT, time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Contrary to many doctors' fears, the survival of elderly hospitalized patients improved during the 1980s under the government's system of limiting Medicare payments, a study says. But the rate at which Medicare patients were sent home in unstable conditions - such as with rapid heartbeats or confusion - jumped from about 10 percent to about 15 percent, said the study of more than 14,000 patients. Unstable patients had a greater likelihood of dying. The chance was about 16 percent within 90 days, compared with about a 10 percent chance for patients discharged in stable condition, the study reported. ``The good news is that over time, there's better care delivered by doctors and nurses during hospitalization, and the new payment system didn't interrupt that,'' said Dr. Katherine L. Kahn, who headed the study for the RAND Corp., a non-profit research group based in Santa Monica, Calif. ``However, associated with the introduction of the new payment system, and probably caused by it, there was an increase in patients discharged with instability,'' which ``somewhat reduced the gains in survival overall,'' she said. The findings were published in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. The government footed the entire $3.9 million cost of the study of Medicare's so-called ``prospective pricing system,'' introduced as a cost-saving strategy in 1983. Under prospective pricing, the government limits payment for hospitalization of Medicare patients to a flat rate per admission calculated for each of 470 groups of illnesses. Before prospective pricing, the government paid whatever costs Medicare patients ran up while hospitalized. The new system has slowed the upward spiral of the cost of Medicare, which covers Americans over age 65. But it has raised fears that care would be compromised through shortened hospital stays and the substitution of cheaper services and procedures. A 19-member RAND research team compared 1981-82 patient records - before prospective pricing - to 1985-86 records - after prospective pricing - at 297 hospitals. The researchers found discharges were quicker - the mean length of stay dropped from 14.4 days to 11.0 days, a difference of 3.4 days. But the death rate overall also dropped, from 16.5 percent to 15.4 percent, in the 30 days after hospital discharge for patients with any of the five conditions studied. They were congestive heart failure, heart attack, pneumonia, stroke or hip fracture. Under the new pricing system, there also was a slight decline in the number of patients dead by 180 days, but the figure would have declined even further had it not been for deaths due to instability and other problems at discharge, researchers said. The researchers also reported that the proportion of patients receiving poor or very poor care declined from 25 percent to 12 percent but ``remained a worrisome issue.'' The study is the most comprehensive yet evaluating the impact of prospective pricing on the quality of care, other researchers said. But Bruce C. Vladeck, president of the United Hospital Fund of New York and a member of the Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, a congressional agency that evaluates Medicare pricing, said he was ``not terribly surprised'' at the findings. ``Other, less sophisticated efforts to try to measure the quality effects of the system have produced similar results,'' Vladeck said in a telephone interview. He added that the findings were nonetheless ``reassuring.'' Charles Dougherty, director of the Center for HePolicy and Ethics at Creighton University, said that even though ``there is some real good news here,'' the increase in discharges of patients in unstable medical condition is disturbing. ``People are leaving hospitals who in years previously ... would have warranted admission to a hospital,'' he said in a telephone interview from Omaha, Neb.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Leader Leaves on European Trip Despite Domestic Troubles
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister has left on a European trip despite growing pressures on his government, including a student's attempt at self-immolation to protest official corruption. Some said the suicide attempt was instigated by pro-military groups. The army's supreme commander, Gen. Sunthorn Khongsomphong, said in a television interview Monday that the situation in Thailand is ``very fragile.'' He said the military will ``try to prevent the situation from becoming violent and from affecting the people's normal way of life.'' Premier Chatichai Choonhavan left late Monday for official visits to Britain and Switzerland, where he hoped to encourage private business investment in Thailand. He has said that upon his return Oct. 23, he would reshuffle the Cabinet, which has been plagued by infighting, widespread charges of corruption and declining support from the army. Army commander Sunthorn denied any military involvement in the suicide attempt Sunday by Tanawot Klingchue, a 21-year-old student at Ramkhamhaeng University. Tanawot poured gasoline over his head and set himself on fire just outside the campus after accusing the government of corruption and demanding its resignation. Later Sunday, police stopped a small group of other students who threatened to set themselves on fire in front of the prime minister's offices if the government did not resign. Tanawot's act shocked the public. Self-immolation as a form of protest has been unheard of in Thailand in recent years. Tanawot remained in critical condition Tuesday with burns covering 90 percent of his body. His chances of survival were slim, said the acting commander at the hospital, police Maj. Gen. Pisoot Pintuyotin. The Students Federation of Thailand, the main student umbrella group, has also demanded that the government resign but has denounced the suicide attempt, saying it did not represent the student movement. The Ramkhamhaeng University Students Union said the student protesters belonged to a group infiltrated by the little-known Revolutionary Council, apparently a pro-military group. The Thai newspaper The Nation quoted unidentified government sources Tuesday as saying police were seeking to question two leaders of the council suspected of being behind the suicide attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis And Palestinians: Not Much Pity For The Others' Victims
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hearts have hardened in the violent struggle over the holy land, and neither Palestinians nor Israelis show much pity for the others' victims. After 19 Palestinians were shot dead by police on the sacred Temple Mount last week, an Israeli worker in a fast-food restaurant told a customer: ``I wish a hundred had been killed.'' After the same incident, a 58-year-old Palestinian said: ``I wish Hitler was alive, so he can finish the job and make them all into soap.'' And he is what many Israelis would call a ``good Arab,'' having worked for the Israeli government for 18 years and learned fluent Hebrew. These are spur-of-the-moment remarks, but they are indicative of the harsh atmosphere of daily life in Jerusalem. Psychologists say the comments are the result of a decades-old ethnic conflict that has intensified since the December 1987 start of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. ``In situations of prolonged conflict, the gap between the adversary communities keeps growing, and each side dehumanizes the other,'' said Ariel Merari, an expert on political violence at Tel Aviv University. Signs of such dehumanization abound. Israelis have been known to refer to Palestinians as ``dogs'' or ``cockroaches.'' Palestinians have termed Israelis ``animals'' or ``Nazis.'' In the early years of the Israeli occupation, an arm's-length coexistence developed as Arabs flocked into Israel looking for jobs, and Israelis poured into the West Bank and Gaza Strip to picnic and sightsee. But today, Palestinians see Israelis as the soldiers who open fire on teen-age stone-throwers and stop Palestinian drivers at roadblocks, or as indifferent military bureaucrats. Most Israelis see Palestinians only as the terrorists planting bombs on Jerusalem's Ben Yehuda Mall or as faceless figures sweeping the streets of Tel Aviv. Until now, the main expression of Palestinian hatred has been stones and fire-bombs. But after the bloodbath on the Temple Mount, the pro-PLO leaders of the uprising threatened to escalate the conflict. ``This stage requires the use of weapons, arson, stabbings and destroying anything we can reach,'' their leaflet said. If compassion is lacking, excuses are not. The Temple Mount clash began with Arabs throwing rocks down on Jewish worshipers at theWWestern Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, injuring 28 people, most of them slightly. To Israelis, it was a desecration so outrageous that whatever happened afterward seemed almost secondary. Police opened fire in response to the stoning. In July 1989, when an Arab grabbed the wheel of an Israeli bus and plunged it into a ravine, killing 17 people, Palestinians excused him by saying he was avenging the beatings of his family and friends by soldiers. Political leaders on both sides use history to justify their actions. Palestinians bring up Deir Yassin, the village near Jerusalem where Jewish militiamen massacred more than 250 people in 1948. Israelis cite Palestinian guerrilla attacks in which hundreds of Israeli civilians have been killed. Both sides often refuse to acknowledge each others' suffering. Many Palestinians belittle the Holocaust, the memory of which helps shape the prickly, uncompromising Israeli character. Israelis show little awareness of the constant humiliation and harassment Palestinians are subjected to under occupation. There are, however, many exceptions. Israeli peace activists brave the mockery and threats of violence by the militant right to demonstrate their sympathy for the Palestinians. Moderate Palestinians risk the wrath of hard-liners by trying to find common ground with Israelis. Dr. Michael Stark, a Jerusalem obstetrician, felt compelled to tell a patient's Palestinian husband how terrible he felt about the Temple Mount killings. ``I'm not justifying the people who threw stones, but I believe that the police response was out of all proportion. And I'm ashamed that this happened,'' Stark said. Said Kenaan, a pro-PLO businessman from the West Bank city of Nablus, said he and other moderates tried unsuccessfully to dissuade militants from calling for the killing of Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers. Kenaan said he is undeterred. ``Some of us still believe it's best to stick to non-violence,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Reacts Negatively to Mayor's Appearance on Donahue Show
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Bill Boner won little sympathy in his hometown when he and aspiring country singer Traci Peel discussed their romance before a national television audience on the ``Donahue'' talk show. ``I'm thoroughly disgusted with the way the mayor and his wife handled themselves,'' R.J. Hill, an engineering consultant, said after watching the syndicated show Monday. ``Boner and Peel should have defended themselves before the people of Nashville rather than to a national audience.'' The relationship between Boner, 45, and Peel, 34, made national headlines this summer while Boner was living with his third wife, Betty. Boner married Peel on Oct. 1, three days after the divorce was final. ``You are very close to giving the finger to the city,'' TV host Phil Donahue said during the taping of the show Thursday in New York. ``You're a distracted mayor. You were an out-of-the-closet adulterer.'' Boner said he has accomplished much during his three-year term. ``I've brought moremoney into Nashville than anybody else,'' Boner said. ``We lived up to our commitments. We have a totally integrated solid-waste management system.'' Peel told Donahue that her comment published in the Nashville Banner that Peel's passion could last for seven hours at a time was made in jest in a conversation she thought was off the record. The Banner has published statements that it stands by its story. At one point, Peel sang ``Rocky Top,'' accompanied by Boner on the harmonica. Students in Tommy Henley's sociology class at Maplewood High School were left with disdain. ``This is embarrassing,'' Tometrias Mullins said. ``They already think we're hicks.'' ``They should leave his personal life alone and get on the main issues like the landfill and education,'' said student Raymond Broughton. Phone calls poured into the Nashville Scene, a weekly newspaper edited by Bruce Dobie, who appeared on the talk show with Boner and Peel and WLAC-AM talk show host Les Jameson. ``They're saying we need to let this Boner thing rest. But others are saying, `This guy's a disgrace.' They want to know how we can recall him,'' Dobie said. The show resulted in a number of calls to the mayor's office, said Boner spokesman Rick Runyeon. ``We have received a number of calls and there has been probably an equal balance between positive and negative,'' Runyeon said. ``We've received a lot of calls from out of city and out of state and those tend to be more positive than the local calls.'' After taping ``Donahue!'' last week, Boner released a statement declaring his personal life off-limits to reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Investigate Case Of Child Who Dialed Long Distance for Help
DOC.TEXT: Child welfare officials said Tuesday they were investigating the case of a 4-year-old girl who was left alone with a bad cold and got help by randomly dialing a Wisconsin health department. ``This would be considered a child neglect case,'' said Patricia Watters, division chief for the Montgomery County Department of Child Welfare Services. ``Last year, we had about 500 cases of neglect reported, and about 5 percent of those were unattended children.'' The girl, whose name was not released, began dialing random telephone numbers to try to find her mother Monday morning. She reached the Walworth County ``Public Health Line'' about 9:30 a.m. EDT. ``I was kind of shaking at first,'' receptionist Sara Weeks, who answered the phone, said Tuesday. ``We were really concerned at first that she had been abandoned in her house.'' During the 2{ hours the girl was on the phone, Ms. Weeks and nurse Jane Hildeick alternated talking with her as authorities traced the call. ``We picked up on her cues,'' Ms. Weeks said. ``When we wrote down Washington, we screamed.'' Ms. Weeks said she was on the phone when police arrived at the apartment. ``I was on the phone when the officer came to the door and I could hear him through the door,'' she added. Mother and daughter were reunited a short time later at the police station in Silver Spring, Md. Ms. Watters said the problem of unattended children is increasing. ``One real problem we are dealing with is that people cannot afford regular day care. We are seeing more of that,'' she said. She added that Maryland law says no child under the age of 8 can be left alone or confined unless there is a reliable person at least 13 years of age left in charge. She said she understood that the mother, identified by police as 27-year-old Luvisca Deligny, had gone to the bank to run an errand and had left the child with her two roommates, who went to work. ``That's why we are conducting the investigation,'' Ms. Watters said. ``We are trying to discover if this is a pattern or one instance where someone who normally is supposed to be there isn't.'' Police charged the mother with leaving a child unattended, a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to $500 and a 30-day jail term. Ms. Deligny said she took the day off to care for her sick child and had left to run an errand. ``I'm still not sure she was on the phone that long,'' she said. ``I'll wait to see the phone bill to determine if it's true.'' Walworth County in Wisconsin is a farming area east of Madison and about 60 miles north of Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Leonard Bernstei Buried In Brooklyn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with Bernstein buried today. Picks up in 3rd graf, `Flags at ...'
DOC.TEXT: Leonard Bernstein, whose wide-ranging talents and flamboyant personality helped make him the first American maestro to conquer music's international podium, was buried today alongside his wife. Bernstein, who died of lung failure Sunday at age 72, was buried this afternoon in private ceremonies at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn. His wife, Felicia Montealegre, died in 1978. Flags at Lincoln Center, where the New York Philharmonic performs, were lowered in memory of the orchestra's first American-born music director. Bernstein was appointed in 1958 and stepped down in 1969 to spend more time composing. The Philharmonic will perform an all-Bernstein program beginning Thursday and continuing through Oct. 23. The schedule had called for works by Shostakovich and Beethoven. A memorial concert also is planned for Carnegie Hall on Nov. 14, the 47th anniversary of Bernstein's Philharmonic debut. Famed for his gymnastics at the podium, Bernstein composed symphonies as well as movie scores and Broadway shows such as ``West Side Story,'' ``On the Town'' and ``Candide.'' His Emmy-winning ``Young People's Concerts'' on television introduced thousands to classical music. ``He was the most unique musician of this century, there is no doubt about it,'' said Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. Larry Kert, who played Tony in the Broadway production of ``West Side Story,'' said Bernstein himself played the piano for him during rehearsals. ``He could have gotten a rehearsal pianist, but he cared too much,'' Kert said. ``I was the new kid on the block and he stroked me and took care of me - and I will never forget him for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Vegetable Harvest Down 15 Percent
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The vegetable harvest is down about 15 percent this year, more bad news for consumers already suffering from shortages of meat, eggs, cheese and sugar, Soviet media reported Tuesday. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda blamed the vegetable shortfall on heavy rain, a manpower shortage and lack of transportation. Consumer dissatisfaction has eroded public support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reforms. He unveiled a new economic plan on Tuesday. Under a headline asking ``What Will We Eat in Winter?,'' Pravda said 9.8 million tons of vegetables had been collected across the country as of Oct. 8, 1.5 million tons less than at this time last year. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov has voiced particular concern about potatoes, a key winter food. As of Oct. 11, Moscow had stockpiled only 13 percent of the potatoes the city is expected to need to get through the winter. At this time last year, the capital's stockpiles of potatoes were nearly six times larger than they are now, the newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets reported. Pravda carried short dispatches from its correspondents around the country describing the harvest. In many areas, the problem is not the quantity of vegetables growing in the fields, but lack of manpower, fuel, transportation and storage facilities to get the food to market, it said. In the Russian province of Stavropol, where Gorbachev spent his childhood, less than half the vegetables had been picked by Oct. 1. Plans called for 20,000 workers and 900 trucks to take part in the harvest there, but only about one-quarter of those people and half the trucks are working, Pravda said. In the Rostov region of southeastern Russia, there is a tremendous shortage of trucks, and what few are available often run out of gas, the newspaper quoted a regional official as saying. Similar problems plague the bumper Soviet grain harvest. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has estimated the Soviet crop at 235 million metric tons, nearly a record. But experts estimate 20 percent to 30 percent will be lost because of poor transportation and spoilage. There was no bread in Moscow stores for two weeks in September, but it is now readily available. Shortages of other goods, such as eggs and cheese, have worsened. Sugar is rationed, and people with ration coupons have difficulty finding any.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Rules Out `Partial Solution' to Persian Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III declared on Tuesday that ``a partial solution'' to the Persian Gulf crisis short of total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait is unacceptable to the Bush administration. Referring to persistent hints of compromise from Baghdad, Baker said President Saddam Hussein evidently was interested ``in a negotiated arrangement that would enable him to claim benefits from his unprovoked aggression against a small neighbor.'' Baker rejected that notion outright. ``It's a case. from our standpoint, of not wanting to succumb to the siren song of a partial solution to this crisis.'' The hints emanated from Baghdad after the Aug. 2 invasion and culminated Sunday with a report by a Soviet news agency that Saddam might be prepared to pull out from most of Kuwait in exchange for keeping several strategic islands in the Persian Gulf. The report followed a high-level visit to Iraq by Evgeny Primakov, the leading Soviet expert on the Middle East and Persian Gulf. Baker cautioned, however, that an overture may not have been made to the Soviet official and that Moscow ``has remained as solid as the United States on the issue of no partial solution.'' Determined to tighten the economic screws on Iraq, Baker said the U.N. Security Council should consider adopting resolutions demanding Iraq pay reparations ``in the rape of Kuwait which is still continuing'' and be held responsible for war crimes. Baker also said U.S. officials were ``quite concerned'' about Iraqi threats to unleash terrorism against the West in retaliation for the three-month economic blockade of the country. President Bush, campaigning in Des Moines for Iowa's Republican Governor Terry Branstad, responded to a challenge by three youthful protesters of U.S. policy in the Gulf by saying ``they've got it all wrong.'' Bush went on: ``What is happening is we see in Kuwait unprecedented acts of brutality inflicted by Iraq. Iraqi aggression will not be allowed to stand. Saddam Hussein will be held accountable and the legitimate government of Kuwait will be restored.'' Baker took questions from reporters at a State Department ceremony designed to heighten public interest in the U.S. campaign against terrorism. On another subject, he urged Israel to reverse its decision barring a U.N. mission to investigate a riot Oct. 8 on the hallowed Temple Mount in which 19 Palestinian Arabs were shot to death by Israeli police. ``It is only that way Israel will be able to make its case to the Security Council,'' Baker said. In a gesture to the Israeli government, Baker condemned the flinging of stones, bottles and other missives onto Jewish worshipers at the Western Wall that preceded the shootings. ``We don't think there is any excuse for that, either,'' Baker said. A senior Israeli diplomat said here Tuesday that it would be naive to consider the U.N. investigators as fact-finders. ``What's the point of sending an investigator after you've made the verdict already that Israel is to be condemned,'' Oded Eran, the deputy Israeli ambassador, said referring to the Security Council's unanimous adoption Friday night of a resolution condemning Israel. He said the Bush administration made no attempt to work with Israel to limit the impact of the resolution, which was drafted by the United States with some help from Britain. He called the affair an example of ``the failure of the U.N. to be evenhanded'' and explained that the decision taken Sunday by the Israel Cabinet against a U.N. inquiry stemmed from ``the fear of the introduction of the U.N. into the city of Jerusalem, which we have tried to avoid at all cost.'' Baker, in another dispute with Israel, implicitly criticized a decision by an Israeli Cabinet committee to encourage an increase in the settlement of Soviet Jews in East Jerusalem. He said the predominantly Arab sector of the city was beyond the ``Green Line'' that delineated Israel's boundaries before the 1967 Six Day War in which Jordan was stripped of East Jerusalem and the West Bank. To pave the way for a $400 million U.S. housing loan guarantee, Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy assured Baker two weeks ago that his government's policy was not to direct or settle Soviet Jews beyond the Green Line. ``We think the United States is and should be entitled to rely upon assurances received from the foreign minister of Israel,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Be It Bottled, Or From The Oasis, Soldiers Must Drink The Water
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military has a partial remedy for the sand and heat of the Saudi desert: drink water, and lots of it. ``We kind of force them to drink it. They have no choice,'' Capt. Kelly Marunale, 30, of Woodstock, Ill., says of the requirement that U.S. soldiers drink more than two gallons of water each day. One of the first tasks of soldiers in the desert every morning is to collect a box of six bottles of water - a day's supply. The rule holds despite the easing in temperatures, down at least 15 degrees from the summer highs of 120 degrees. At the height of summer, there were reports that U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia were required to drink six gallons of water a day. That made an impression on 10-year-old Hannah Bergstrem of Loveland, Colo., who wrote to an officer saying: ``I wouldn't like to be in Saudi Arabia drinking six gallons of water a day, but I guess somebody has to do it.'' Even the estimated two gallons each U.S. soldier is required to drink daily looms large when the water must be trucked in for some 200,000 troops. The expense and logistics of distributing the water - bottled water must be purchased - has prompted the military to begin using water taken from oasis wells and processed from the sea. ``Those plastic bottles are just a logistical nightmare,'' said Col. Dan Grigson, public affairs officer for the Army's 101st airborne division. ``So we hope to wean soldiers off the bottle.'' Repeated inquiries on the number of bottles of water consumed by U.S. soldiers were not answered by the armed forces. However, dehydration is one of the main problems treated by field hospitals as soldiers are prone to ignore their daily ration. The average consumption of water per soldier in September ranged between five and 11 gallons per day, including that used for showers and washing. The soldiers have no great love for the chlorinated water produced by mixing oasis water with chemicals. ``It's like drinking the swimming pool,'' said Sgt. Joseph Copley, 25, of Mansfield, Ohio. Because of the daily minimum requirement, the water is a constant topic of conversation. Even in the midst of night maneuvers, two soldiers were overheard discussing the subject. ``I drank that water for two weeks before they started putting in the chlorine and I never got sick,'' said one. ``It made you ugly,'' the other joked in answer. ``No, that came from eating MREs,'' said the first soldier, referring to the military field rations called ``meals-ready-to-eat.'' Troops get packages of flavored powder such as lemon-lime or grape in the MREs which they dump into the water, but they don't have enough to disguise the amount they must drink. Sometimes they use cocoa. ``Here it is 120 degrees outside and the water is so hot they would rather drink hot cocoa than hot water,'' said Marunale, a company commander with the Aviation Brigade of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Defends Role in Gulf as Hecklers Disrupt Speech
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, heckled on the campaign trail, battled Tuesday against signs of dwindling public support for U.S. involvement in the Middle East. ``America will remain in the Persian Gulf not one single day longer than necessary,'' he promised. Bush said U.S. forces must stay in the gulf until Iraq's Saddam Hussein withdraws his army from Kuwait. ``If we don't stand up against aggression around the world when it's naked and brutal, who will?,'' Bush asked on a three-state campaign swing stretching from Des Moines, Iowa, to Grand Rapids, Mich. Three protesters disrupted Bush's speech at a political fund-raiser before more than 1,000 people in the Des Moines Civic Center. ``Mr. President, bring our troops home from Saudi Arabia,'' one young man shouted. ``Stop the buildup. ... No war for oil,'' the trio shouted before being hustled away by police. Bush was loudly applauded when he responded, ```The fight isn't about oil. The fight is about naked aggression that will not stand.'' Two women interrupted Bush at a fieldhouse rally at DuPage College in the Chicago suburb of Glen Ellyn. Addressing himself to the protesters, Bush said, ``What we are for is peace in the Middle East. What we are also for is principle.'' He appeared irritated at the disruptions. ``I'm so glad we have free speech here, but once in a while, you know, we ought to get on with our business.'' The disturbances coincided with the release of a Washington Post-ABC News Poll showing a sharp drop in support for U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf, where more than 200,000 Americans are on duty. The survey said 60 percent of people questioned believe the United States should keep troops in the region until Iraq withdraws from Kuwait. Five weeks ago, the figure had been 75 percent. Support for Bush's handling of the gulf crisis has dropped from 78 percent in September to 64 percent in the most recent Post-ABC poll. Bush said he understood the passions of the demonstrators. ``I went through World War II,'' he said. ``We've been through a couple of agonizing periods, the Korean War and the Vietnam War, so their views shouldn't be entirely written off. ``But they've got it wrong. They've got the facts wrong,'' he said. ``They're looking introspectively in a bit of an isolationistic way. You can't do that. We have the responsibility to lead, the United States does.'' Bush said the United States ``has the responsibility to lead and to put together this coalition that says to Saddam Hussein very simply, you cannot bully your neighbor, you cannot wipe out a member of the Arab League, a member of the United Nations.'' The president recounted stories of atrocities committed in occupied Kuwait by Iraqi forces, such as babies being taken off incubators and patients removed from dialysis machines so the equipment could be moved to Baghdad. Bush said, ``The bottom line for us is Iraqi aggression will not be allowed to stand, Saddam Hussein will be held accountable and the legitimate government of Kuwait will be restored.'' Vowing that U.S. forces will not remain longer than necessary, Bush said, ``I look forward to the day when every single man and woman serving there now with pride, and beautifully trained, every single one of them comes home. But we must stay for as long as it takes to complete our mission.'' His comments were loudly cheered. Bush campaigned in Iowa fo the reelection of Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, favored in the polls, and for Rep. Tom Tauke, who is struggling to replace Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin. In Illinois, Bush sought to boost the chances of Jim Edgar, the GOP candidate for governor, who is in a close race with Democrat Neil Hartigan. Bush's last stop for the day was Michigan, where neither Republican gubernatorial candidate John Engler nor GOP Sen. challenger Bill Schuette was given more than a long-shot chance of upsetting the Democratic incumbents.

DOC.HEAD: Former S&L Owner's Trial on Bank Fraud Begins Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: Highflying former savings and loan owner Donald Ray Dixon goes on trial Wednesday on charges he used depositors' money to finance lavish acquisitions, leaving taxpayers with a $1.3 billion federal bailout. Dixon, 50, traveled the world for gourmet parties and acquired such trinkets as a 17th Century castle door, Baccarat crystal, Remington sculptures, a silver-studded saddle and a posh house in Solana Beach, Calif., just north of San Diego. The government says those luxuries, as well as payments to prostitutes and political campaigns, were financed from the vaults at Vernon Savings & Loan Association, which collapsed under the weight of Dixon's excess in 1987 and was taken over by the government. A dozen other Vernon executives and associates have preceded Dixon in court; 10 have been convicted and a guilty verdict against two others was set aside because the jury discussed Dixon's indictment. ``Perhaps when my day in court comes, if they'll listen, they'll find out what really happened and the blame can be properly assessed and properly assigned,'' Dixon said in July when he was arraigned on a 38-count indictment. The indictment charged him with conspiracy, misapplication of funds, making false statements and other crimes. Jury selection was to begin Wednesday in federal court. Testimony is expected to begin Monday, and continue three to four weeks. If convicted on all counts, Dixon could be sentenced to up to 190 years in prison and fined as much as $9.5 million. An extra-large panel of 75 to 80 potential jurors was called because of publicity in the case, said Jean Hiller, court coordinator for U.S. District Judge Joe A. Fish. Assistant U.S. Attorney David Jarvis of Dallas said 40 to 50 prosecution witnesses could testify. Included on that list is a convicted madam, who has confirmed that she supplied prostitutes for Vernon executives when they were in San Diego. Defense and prosecution attorneys declined to discuss the case this week, citing a instructions from Fish. Until the recent notoriety given Neal Bush and Silverado Savings and Loan in Colorado or Charles Keating and Lincoln Savings and Loan in California, Dixon and Vernon were at or near the top of the list of abuses cited in the industry. Dixon's trial is an effort ``to bring to justice people who break the law, who use savings and loan associations as personal piggy banks, and who may have thought they could just walk away free and let the American taxpayer shoulder the cost of their greed,'' said Timothy Ryan, Office of Thrift Supervision director in Washington. Vernon had a luxury yacht and a fleet of five planes worth $6 million. The S&L also paid the $22,000 tab for Dixon's gastronomic tour of European restaurants, the government said. Dixon also is charged with illegal contributions to such politicians as former House Speaker Jim Wright and Jack Kemp, a former Republican congressman from New York who is now Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Recipients of those funds did not know they came from illegal sources, prosecutors have said. When regulators closed Vernon, it was the largest thrift bailout in history, and it remains among the most expensive. Most of the expensive acquisitions have been sold at auction since the government takeover. When regulators closed Vernon, they renamed it Monfort Savings Association. In December 1988, Monfort was one of five insolvent thrifts combined to create First Gibraltar Bank, the largest savings and loan in Texas. Vernon also has resulted in the stiffest sentence to date for an S&L officer. Former Chairman Woody F. Lemons was sentenced to 30 years in prison earlier this year.
