DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Agrees to Study of Bridge Access to Ellis Island
DOC.TEXT: A Senate committee on Tuesday cleared the way for a National Park Service study on the feasibility of making permanent a pedestrian bridge to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved the study proposal from Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., as part of the 1991 Interior Appropriations bill. The measure aimed at easing access to Ellis Island still faces approval by the full Senate. The foot bridge, which connects Liberty State Park in New Jersey with Ellis Island, has been used by construction workers rehabilitating the immigration center. It was slated to be phased out in 1992. However, New Jersey lawmakers upset at the $6 per-person cost of getting to the monuments by ferry have suggested the bridge be retained. They include Gov. Jim Florio and Rep. Frank J. Guarini, D-N.J., whose district includes Liberty State Park, a departure point for the ferry. Opponents include the National Parks Service and Circle Line-Statue of Liberty Inc., which operates the ferry service. The company is considering a fare increase to $8 a person, according to recent congressional testimony. ``Ellis Island is part of our national heritage,'' said Lautenberg. ``Affordable access must be available to all Americans wishing to visit the island.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Plans Heavy, Costly Security for Coronation
DOC.TEXT: Police are preparing the nation's most costly security operation ever to keep terrorists away when Japan crowns a new emperor for the first time in more than 60 years. The government has decided on a security budget of $41.5 million, police and Finance Ministry officials said Tuesday. That is more than double the cost of policing Emperor Hirohito's funeral early last year. Japan's largest radical left group, the Chukaku-ha, through its official organ, ``Advance,'' has threatened to disrupt next month's coronation-related ceremonies. Its attacks are generally aimed at property, not people. Authorities refused to comment on what kind of security was planned. About 32,000 police officers were deployed in Tokyo for Hirohito's funeral in a security operation that cost the government $18.4 million. In the weeks before the funeral, police, often dressed in full riot gear, conducted random inspections of automobiles and searched strategically located buildings. Frogmen were called out to secure rivers and bay areas in Tokyo. Manholes near the palace were checked and sealed. A spokesman for Japan's largest opposition party, the Socialists, called the funeral an example of ``excessive security.'' Little of that kind of police presence is visible in Tokyo yet, although some checkpoints have been set up on major streets. Emperor Akihito assumed the throne immediately after his father died in January 1989 but the formal enthronement had to be delayed for a yearlong mourning period. The event will include a state coronation ceremony and parade Nov. 12. The ``Daijosai,'' or Great Food Offering Ritual, will be conducted according to the customs of Japan's native religion of Shinto the night of Nov. 22. Vice President Dan Quayle and Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, are among the dignitaries scheduled to attend the coronation. Before the funeral, police said tight security was needed to protect the representatives of 163 countries, including President Bush, French President Francois Mitterrand and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. But their ``steamroller'' approach was widely criticized as violating residents' human rights, and also because it did not stop leftist radicals from setting off a bomb along the funeral procession route. The blast, which sent mud and debris across the road but injured no one, went off about 20 minutes before the procession passed by. Japan's radical left has little support among the general public, but remains visible by frequently using violence to publicize its aims. The Chukaku-ha, or Middle Core Faction, has a membership estimated in the thousands. The group, whose members wear helmets and bandanas to cover their faces, has a well-known, heavily guarded headquarters in northern Tokyo. Before Hirohito's funeral, the Chukaku-ha claimed it had mortars able to launch projectiles as far as a few miles. So far this year, radicals have claimed responsibility for 53 incidents, 40 involving imperial targets such as shrines or buildings used by palace employees.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Bill Expanding SEC Powers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a bill Tuesday expanding the powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission to intervene during stock market emergencies and to monitor major Wall Street players. Bush said the measure would ``improve the stability of America's vital securities markets and the protection of tens of millions of investors.'' The White House announced Bush's action during a GOP campaign stop in the Chicago suburb of Glen Ellyn. The measure will allow the commission to regulate program trading during times of extreme market turbulence. Program trading is the use of computers to execute scores, even hundreds, of separate trades all at once, frequently in combination with trades in financial futures markets at the same time. The bill also expands the authority of the SEC chairman to shut down the securities markets, with presidential permission, in times of market emergency. Previously only the president could order a trading halt. Other provisions: -Require large securities traders to report their market positions to the commission. -Mandate coordinated clearance and settlement of stocks, options and futures contracts between the SEC and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. -Require the Treasury Department, Federal Reserve Board, the CFTC and SEC to report annually to Congress on their efforts to protect the integrity of the markets. -Give the SEC authority to assess the financial health of the parent holding companies of broker-dealers. While hailing the bill, Bush said part of it was ``still troubling.'' ``The final language of the bill gives the SEC only carefully limited and narrow authority to control trading practices and is an improvement over earlier versions of the legislation,'' Bush said. ``However, it is still important that this authority be carefully and judiciously exercised to prevent any interference with technological innovations in financial markets that can enhance market liquidity,'' the president added. ``We must be careful not to damage the vitality of America's markets at the same time that we protect market stability.''

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Kuwaiti Gov't Rules Out Concessions to Iraq
LaserPhotos AMM1,DHA1,4,TOK1
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's government-in-exile on Tuesday ruled out conceding ``one inch'' of territory to Iraq in any settlement, and the United States said it would not accept partial solutions to the Persian Gulf crisis. The comments followed hints that Iraq might withdraw from Kuwait if it is allowed to retain three key areas - two islands controlling Iraq's access to the gulf and part of an oil field. But Iraq took a firm position Tuesday, with the newspaper of Saddam Hussein's ruling party saying: ``We will not give it (Kuwait) up even if we fight for it 1,000 years.'' Japan's government, meanwhile, introduced a proposal in Parliament that would permit Japanese troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf.The plan envisions the establishment of a non-combat force of civilians and soldiers to participate behind the lines. Japan's constitution forbids sending troops overseas. GIs in Saudi Arabia got a surprise visitor Tuesday - comedian Steve Martin. Martin signed autographs and climbed aboard a tank during a USO stop. Martin was told not perform because of concern by U.S. commanders that American-style humor could offend the Saudis. Kuwait's crown prince and prime minister told a news conference that Iraq's 11-week occupation of his emirate will ``never force us to make any concession.'' ``We will never give up any part of our country, not even one inch,'' Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah said in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. Kuwaitis fleeing into Saudi Arabia said the Iraqis were setting up fences that separate most of Kuwait from the disputed oil field of Rumailah. But Iraq repeatedly has denied speculation that it would withdraw in return for territorial concessions. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Washington also would not agree to concessions. ``We are unwilling to engage in a search for partial solutions,'' Baker said. He said Saddam evidently was interested ``in a negotiated arrangement that would enable him to claim benefits from his unprovoked aggression against a small neighbor.'' President Bush, on the campaign trail in Iowa, encountered signs of dwindling public support for U.S. involvement in the gulf. ``America will remain in the Persian Gulf not one single day longer than necessary,'' he promised. Bush was loudly applauded when he responded to three protesters, ``The fight isn't about oil. The fight is about naked aggression that will not stand.'' The United States has massed nearly 200,000 troops in the Persian Gulf region since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The United Nations has imposed a land, sea and air embargo on Iraq. Jordan's King Hussein, who has worked to try to find a peaceful solution to the crisis, said in remarks published Tuesday that war may be imminent. Hussein told The New York Times that the outbreak of war would be partly the fault of Bush and other Western leaders, who he said failed to respond promptly to Saddam's early indications he was willing to withdraw. Also Tuesday, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev dispatched an envoy to the West to seek a peaceful end to the crisis. A Soviet spokesman said Yevgeny Primakov, recently back from talks with Saddam in Baghdad, would visit Rome and Paris, then meet Bush in Washington. ``The Soviet leadership believes that if there is a smallest chance to settle the conflict peacefully that chance should be used to the ultimate,'' Gorbachev spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said in Moscow. Tass reported that Saddam had hinted to Primakov he might be prepared to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait in exchange for the two islands and the Rumailah oil field that straddles the Iraq-Kuwait border. Saddam had accused the Kuwaitis of drawing more than their share of oil from the field. PLO chief Yasser Arafat has also said Saddam was showing flexibility. But Iraq said Tuesday its position remained firm. Al-Thawra, the newspaper of the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party, said control of Kuwait ``is our final decision, a decision that all Iraq defends and guards by 6 million fighters.'' Iraq's army newspaper, Al-Qadissiya, discounted the possiblity of war before Christmas, saying that Bush was not likely to allow American soldiers to come home in coffins during the holiday season. In other developments Tuesday: -Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi said Libya would mobilize atn soldiers if needed in the gulf crisis, the nation's official news agency reported. Gadhafi, however, did not say which side the troops would fight on o least a millior what would prompt the mobilization. The dispatch by Libya's JANA news agency said he made the remark in a speech Monday. -Honduras said it will send a military force to Saudi Arabia to join the multinational force. Argentina was the first Latin American nation to pledge military personnel to the force.

NEW YORK: Cron said.
DOC.TEXT: For the major part of his career, Blakey did his drumming for the Jazz Messengers, the band that came together under his leadership in the early 1950s. Dizzy Gillespie, the giant of be-bop, once described Blakey as ``the volcano'' of be-bop drummers. He was considered in the top echelon that included such drummers as Max Roach and Buddy Rich. In a television film about Blakey's career, a Jazz Messengers alumnus, pianist Walter Davis, said: ``I think no one in jazz has brought more great musicians to music that Art Blakey.'' The 1981 Newport Jazz Festival gave over an evening to ``The Blakey Legacy,'' in which the drummer was joined by the players who had been with his band during the previous quareer century. Blakey denied being a teacher, saying that as a self-taught musician, ``I don't know anything myself.'' But another time he said, ``When I take these 18-year-old kids out on tour, it makes most of the pros feel like cutting their wrists. ... They're going to take the music farther than it has been.'' Among the musicians who got a start with Blakey's band have been horn players Wynton Marsalis, Freddie Hubbard, Clifford Brown and Chuck Mangione, saxophonists Jackie McLean, Wayne Shorter and Johnny Griffin, pianists Keith Jarrett and Walter Davis. Blakey was born in Pittsburgh in 1919, escaping the steel mills as a 15-year-old by playing piano at a nightclub. Then a 14-year-old hotshot named Erroll Garner showed up and ``I was told to go to the drums by the club owner,'' Blakey recalled. The young Blakey caught on with Fletcher Henderson's band and went on to Billy Eckstine's big band in the mid-1940s, when he first worked with Gillespie and Charlie Parker. The Jazz Messengers band was formed in 1954 by Blakey, pianist Horace Silver, trumpeter Kenny Dorham and saxophonist Hank Mobley. The band toured Europe and played all around the United States for the next three decades, including a White House performance in 1981. Blakey's jazz drummer son, Art Jr., died in 1988 at age 47.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says Loan To Iraq Shows Need To Monitor Foreign Banks In US
DOC.TEXT: A national board may be needed to monitor foreign banks operating in the United States such as an Italian institution that secretly lent several billion dollars to Iraq, the chairman of the House Banking Committee said Tuesday. Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which is owned by the Italian government and is Italy's second-largest bank, lent $1.9 billion to Iraq through its Atlanta office until August 1989, when it was raided by the FBI and Federal Reserve. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, called the scandal ``a case study in regulatory failure'' and said the current system of dividing responsibility for regulating foreign bank offices among federal and state agencies is inadequate. ``Maybe it is time we established a national screening board to monitor more closely foreign bank presence in the United States,'' he suggested. ``Such a screening board could review applications for foreign bank entry into the United States as well as monitor these banks to ensure they are not engaged in foreign policy activities.'' According to the Conference of State Bank Supervisors, 557 state-licensed foreign banks with $622 billion in assets operate in the United States. Another 80 financial institutions with $33 billion in assets are licensed by the Treasury Department's Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. Regulators, appearing before Gonzalez' panel, said the current system was adequate but warned that cases like that of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro are difficult to prevent. ``This was a situation that involved massive fraud in which a large number of employees acted together to conceal the operation and deceive auditors and examiners,'' said William Taylor, director of banking supervision at the Federal Reserve. ``The physical segregation of records, together with the concerted efforts of key employees, make it extremely difficult for examiners to uncover this type of illicit and fraudulent activity,'' he said. Some of the Italian bank's lending was guaranteed by the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corp. Because Iraq stopped paying its debts after invading Kuwait on Aug. 2, U.S. taxpayers will be on the hook for $2 billion through the Commodity Credit Corp., including $347 million loaned by Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. Taxpayers will lose another $55 million guaranteed through the Export-Import Bank of the United States. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said the Lavoro scandal was ``an inevitable result of the poorly managed and ill conceived'' Agriculture Department loan guarantee program. ``In effect, we've doled out billions of dollars of free money which enabled Saddam Hussein to build the powerful nation that confronts us today,'' he said. Pietro Lombardi, executive vice resident in charge of the Italian bank's North American operations, said the Atlanta office's lending was conducted without the knowledge or approval of bank executives in New York and Rome. While the activity may have been unauthorized and improperly reported, loans to Iraq at the time were ``not illegal or in any way inconsistent with the policy of the United States,'' he said. The Justice Department is conducting a criminal investigation of the affair and Tuesday's committee hearing was held over the protests of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who had warned it could hurt prosecutors' efforts.

DOC.HEAD: `Wild and Crazy' Comedian Plays it Cool in Saudi Desert
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhotos DOD1-2, LaserColor DOD103
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 6th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Steve Martin, who bills himself as ``that wild and crazy guy,'' was told to be tame and sane in a visit to U.S. troops Tuesday. ``They said they didn't want us to do a show,'' Martin told soldiers at Camp Midway, a base for the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division. Martin's subdued manner reflected concern by U.S. commanders about Saudi sensibilities. While they are eager to have celebrities visit the Desert Shield forces, they fear some American-style humor could offend the Saudis. It was the third stop of the day for Martin and and his wife, actress Victoria Tennant, who are on a weeklong USO tour. During his hour at the camp, Martin donned a helmet and goggles for a brief ride on an M-1 tank, signed autographs and a homemade ``Steve Martin for President'' poster, and cracked only one joke relating to the gulf crisis. ``I have the answer to Saddam Hussein. If the press would just keep talking about his mistress, his wife would kill him.'' In a recent interview, U.S. Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the overall commander of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, said the Americans were ``trying in every possible way to be culturally sensitive ... without depriving our troops of what we think they should have.'' U.S. officials had earlier canceled troops' attendance at a show staged by some American civilians after Saudi objections to women revealing too much leg. About 500 troops, sitting on a sand dune littered with empty soft drink cans, waited about three hours in 104-degree heat before Martin's group arrived aboard two UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters. They cheered wildly when Martin and his wife climbed on the tank, and the comedian cracked, ``We're going to put up a condo here.'' The stars wore camouflage fatigues and red USO baseball caps, adorned with pilots' wings and souvenirs from earlier stops. It was clear the soldiers had expected Martin to do a comedy routine. But after telling them ``we appreciate what you guys are doing,'' Martin said, ``what we're going to do is what they call grip and grin - we grip your hand and grin at you. It's all we can do.'' He posed for pictures, greeted individual soldiers and handed out cards. ``Don't squeeze too hard,'' he told one. Kevin McCarthy, a USO executive producer, said the organization has discussed visits with several other entertainers, but gave no names. He said this was Martin's first military tour. ``It's only our second day here. We know it's a long trip and we're trying to pace it a little bit so we can make it the whole week. It's pretty hectic,'' McCarthy said. After climbing into the turret of the M-1 tank and whirling around the camp in a cloud of sand, Martin told some soldiers that ``there'll be more people coming,'' mentioning boxer Thomas Hearns. When a trooper asked, ``Can't you stay?'' Martin quipped, ``I've got a meeting.'' Martin said he has generally avoided political issues. ``I'm not here as a political person, but as friend of people,'' he said. ``I felt guilty, everybody coming out here, giving up part of their lives for this effort. I had some time off and I felt kind of bad just sitting there, so I came.''

DOC.HEAD: Withdrawals From S&Ls Slow In May
DOC.TEXT: Net withdrawals from the nation's savings and loans slowed to $7 billion in May after soaring to a record $15.1 billion a month earlier, the government said Tuesday. Depositors withdrew $3.2 billion from 2,471 solvent S&Ls and another $3.8 billion from the 312 failed institutions operated under government control, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. That compares with a net outflow in April of $9.6 billion at solvent institutions and $5.4 billion at government-run thrifts. For the first five months of the year, withdrawals totaled $46.4 billion compared with $35.6 billion during the same period a year ago. Overall, it was the 23rd outflow in 24 months. While analysts attributed withdrawals in 1989 and earlier to lack of depositor confidence in S&Ls, the recent outflow is described as a deliberate strategy of shrinking to meet the tough financial standards imposed in August 1989 by the S&L bailout law. Thrifts wrote $14.8 billion in new mortgages in May, up from $13.9 billion a month earlier but less than $16.4 billion a year earlier. The sluggish economy is holding back the housing market, according to economists. S&Ls in May held $902 billion in deposits and had assets of $1.2 trillion. The thrift office is about three months behind in its reporting of financial data. In past years, deposit activity through August would be available by now.

DOC.HEAD: A.S. Byatt Wins Britain's Top Literary Prize
DOC.TEXT: Critic and novelist A.S. Byatt on Tuesday won the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious literary award, for her tale of two young scholars investigating the lives of a pair of imaginary Victorian poets. The five judges deliberated two hours before awarding the $39,000 prize to Antonia Byatt for ``Possession,'' one of six finalists in the 21-year-old competition. Last year's Booker winner was Kazuo Ishiguro for his novel, ``The Remains of the Day.'' Television executive Sir Denis Forman, chairman of the judge's panel, announced the prize at a banquet in London's Elizabethan Guildhall, seat of the city's Lord Mayor. ``There was very strong individual support for several books on the short list and finally `Possession' by A.S. Byatt was the winner by a majority vote,'' said the judges. ``The panel was unanimous, however, in agreeing that the standard of the other five novels was exceptionally high and this made their decision unusually interesting and unusually difficult.'' Ms. Byatt, who earlier this month won the $43,000 Irish Times-Aer Lingus prize for international fiction for the same work, has published five novels since 1964. In ``Possession,'' she tells how two graduate students piece together the relationship and lives of two imaginary Victorian poets from fragments of their letters and by retracing the poets' journeys across England and to France. The influence of the past on the living is a theme throughout the book. Ms. Byatt, born in 1936, is the daughter of a lawyer and sister of novelist Margaret Drabble. Her first novel, ``Shadow of a Sun,'' concerned the efforts of a woman to escape the shadow of her novelist father. A 1978 work, ``The Virgin in the Garden,'' makes allegorical allusions to Shakespeare and other English literary geniuses in a tale of a play performed at a country house. Ms. Byatt taught English and American literature at University College in London until 1983, when she quit to write fulltime. Other finalists this year were 1979 Booker Prize winner Penelope Fitzgerald with ``The Gate of Angels,'' Irish novelist John McGahern's ``Amongst Women,'' Canadian-born Mordecai Richler's ``Solomon Gursky Was Here,'' Brian Moore's ``Lies of Silence,'' and Beryl Bainbridge's ``An Awfully Big Adventure.'' They were chosen from a list of 113 books published in the United Kingdom in 1989. The Booker Prize is sponsored by Booker, an international food and agriculture business, and administered by The Book Trust. It is Britain's top literary award.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Minister Quoted As Saying Hostage Issue About to End
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Cabinet minister was quoted Tuesday as saying that Western hostages held by pro-Iranian extremists in Lebanon are about to be freed. Agriculture Minister Mohsen Dalloul said Syrian President Hafez Assad's government has ``achieved progress'' in its efforts to free the hostages, who include six Americans. ``The question of the hostages is about to come to an end. Our Syrian brothers are carrying out contacts and have achieved progress,'' Dalloul was quoted as saying by the leftist Beirut newspaper As-Safir. The daily said Dalloul declined to set a specific date for the release or say whether the hostages would come out together or separately. ``We should not talk about this subject so that we would not spoil the ongoing efforts,'' Dalloul, a pro-Syrian Shiite Moslem, was quoted as saying. Another Lebanese leader close to Syria, Abdulla al-Amin, said efforts to free the hostages are not likely to be affected by the crushing of rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's 11-month mutiny on Saturday. ``The attack on Aoun's enclave cannot be linked with the issue of the foreign hostages. Here are two totally separate issues,'' al-Amin told The Associated Press. There has been speculation that Syria's preoccupation with preparations and execution of the Syrian-led blitz would delay the anticipated release of British hostages. Media reports before the assault on Aoun's enclave said Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite and possibly British journalist John McCarthy would be released in a matter of days. These reports said the move would be a result of the resumption of diplomatic relations between Britain and Iran and a subsequent visit to Tehran by the Syrian president last month. The attack on Aoun was mounted by President Elias Hrawi's army and Syrian troops from three directions, one of which was south Beirut's Shiite Moslem slums, where most of the Western captives are believed held. Militiamen of the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, have since been clashing with a pro-Syrian Christian militia in suburban Hadath, a Christian residential district close to the Shiite slums. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella of underground Shiite fanatics holding most of the Westerners in Lebanon. Waite disappeared in Moslem west Beirut Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his hotel for a meeting with hostage holders. He was trying to negotiate the release of hostages. No group has claimed to hold Waite. But former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, who was released in August, said he was held n the same house as Waite for a while. McCarthy was kidnapped April 17, 1986 while driving to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. The missing Westerners include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans, and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Shiite leader Hussein Musawi, who heads a pro-Syrian wing in Hezbollah, has said British hostages would be released first because of the improvement in British-Iranian relations, and that U.S.-led military deployment in Saudi Arabia had dimmed chances of early release for Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Much-maligned Field Rations Not All Bad: Camels Said to Like 'Em
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The new-fangled field rations scorned by U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia must indeed be hard to swallow if even the Army's top officer is making fun of them. Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the Army chief of staff, drew roars of laughter during an address to a military conference Tuesday when he jokingly said the rations, called Meals-Ready-to-Eat, or MREs, aren't as bad as they're made out to be. ``They're humorously maligned by a lot of people,'' Vuono understated, ``but I want to dispel the story that has been going around'' among troops in the Saudi desert that even the camels wandering into Army camps can't stand the MREs. ``One such camel, while observing one of our soldiers enjoying his delicious MRE, thrust his hairy face right in the soldier's lap and grabbed his MRE. ``After chewing for a few seconds - so the story goes - the camel spit the meal out in disgust and angrily chased our great trooper across the Saudi desert. ``Now look, that's the myth that's going around,'' Vuono said, adding, tongue-in-cheek, that he had tracked down the soldier and had gotten the true story of the camel's reaction. ``Yes, one camel did in fact steal that trooper's MRE. But, far from rejecting the meal, the camel munched the MRE with great pleasure, enjoyed the hot sauce, ... belched contentedly and gave our soldier a great kiss on the cheek.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Unveils New Compromise Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS throughout to UPDATE with gov't not to offer interest-free loans, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today unveiled a new plan to rescue the Soviet economy, eliminating a 500-day deadline for switching to a market system. The 66-page blueprint, delivered to committees of the Soviet legislature and signed by the Soviet president, is at least the fourth recent plan for reviving the economy. It is the result of a three-week, behind-the-scenes effort by Gorbachev and the country's top economists to resolve fundamental differences over how to move away from a centrally planned system that fails to provide adequate food, shelter or services for the country's 285 million people. ``People's lives are becoming more difficult, their interest in labor is falling, their faith in the future is crumbling,'' the plan says. The plan, which Gorbachev is scheduled to present to the full 542-member Supreme Soviet on Friday, sets no time limit for switching to a market economy but states: ``The experience of applying stabilization programs in other countries ... shows that such a period can take about 1{ to two years.'' It would give the Soviet republics a powerful voice and new flexibility in running the country's economy. ``The main guidelines will determine only the principal approaches. Every republic, Moscow and Leningrad have the right to act as they like within the framework of these guidelines,'' Gorbachev's spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, told reporters today. The plan calls for establishment of an ``inter-republic economic committee'' to oversee reforms and for republic representatives to be included in central executive bodies. Ignatenko called the committee a departure from the tradition of ministries in Moscow dictating to thousands of factories, farms and businesses what to produce, where to sell it and at what price. In 1992, the plan says, only the prices of bread, meat, dairy products and a few other staples would remain fixed by the state. That is a slower transition to free pricing than envisioned in a draft prepared by Soviet economist Stanislav Shatalin, which envisoned a 500-day deadline. Under Gorbachev's plan, republics would have the right to override price increases allowed by central authorities, and to control most of the resources on their territory. To reduce the huge amount of money that Soviets have stashed away in personal savings, the government would accept advance payment for scarce and expensive goods such as cars, computers, furniture, telephones, housing and rural plots. The goods would be delivered when they became available, and the government would not pay interest on the money in the interim. Shatalin's plan received stong support from reformers such as Boris Yeltsin, the president of the Russian Federation. Gorbachev earlier said he preferred elements of the Shatalin plan to those in another proposal offered by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov.

DOC.HEAD: Saving the Whales: Iceland's Critics Dispute Its Whale Research
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: On the face of it, the United States government and environmentalists may seem an unlikely alliance, but allied they are in their opposition to the resumption of commercial whaling in Iceland. In the second of two stories, AP Science Editor Paul Raeburn examines the efforts to blunt Iceland's contentions that its whales are not endangered. ---

``A whale is the most beautiful animal I have ever seen,'' the poet W.H. Auden wrote during a visit to Iceland in 1936. ``To see it torn to pieces with steam winches and cranes is enough to make one a vegetarian for life.'' That kind of revulsion has helped make the global save-the-whales campaign one of the most dramatic successes of the environmental movement. An international moratorium on commercial whaling was instituted in 1986, and environmentalists now are pushing for a permanent ban on all whaling. ``We would certainly be against whaling until we could definitely show it would not affect the (whale) stocks,'' says Kevin Chu. ``If there is any doubt, we want to err on the side of conservation.'' That's tough talk - and it doesn't come from an environmentalist. Chu is a foreign affairs officer in the U.S. State Department's Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs. Asked to describe the U.S. position on whaling, Chu says: ``The United States is against it.'' The perhaps unusual consensus among the government and environmental groups is fueled by two things: concern that whales are in danger of extinction and the kind of sentiments evoked by Auden. The government takes a strong anti-whaling stance because ``the only voices we hear are the voices of the environmentalists,'' Chu said. Iceland, one of the three major whaling nations along with Norway and Japan, argues strenuously that the whales it wants to hunt are not endangered and that it should be allowed to resume commercial whaling. But even if scientists eventually agree the populations are indeed not endangered, the campaign to save the whales is unlikely to die. ``Politically, it comes down to a relatively simple thing,'' said William Evans, the U.S. representative to the International Whaling Commission. ``There are a number of countries and scientists that believe . . . there is not a justification, or need, for any country to continue to harvest these animals.'' ``I'm completely of the mindset that we have to protect oceans for our own survival, and the whales are a component of this ecosystem,'' said Sally Shoup of Greenpeace. ``We have to stop this devastation of the other creatures on the planet if we want to protect ourselves. ``I think whales are special,'' she said. ``I think they are intelligent creatures. I think Icelanders can understand that as well.'' The save-the-whales campaign began in 1972, when the landmark U.N. Conference on the Environment, in a 53-0 vote, passed a resolution calling for a 10-year moratorium on whaling. Whalers killed 46,000 whales that year. The United States immediately proposed the moratorium to the whaling commission, which rejected it. But the U.S. continued to push. In 1982, the commission finally approved a moratorium, beginning in 1986. ``What we were going to do was take five years of no whaling,'' said Evans, the U.S. representative to the commission. ``Well, we haven't had five years of no whaling, because Iceland invented scientific whaling.'' A clause in the international whaling convention allows the killing of whales for scientific purposes. Iceland exploited it. ``You have the same boats and the same people and you take the same whales and you sell it to the same people and you call it scientific whaling,'' said Roger Payne, a noted whale expert and president of the Long Term Research Institute in Lincoln, Mass. ``It's a joke.'' Johann Sigurjonsson, senior whale specialist at Iceland's Marine Research Institute, vigorously disagreed. ``Those who have been following what we're doing understand the seriousness of what we're doing,'' he said. In 1985, the last year of its commercial whaling operation, Iceland killed 344 whales. It caught 116 in 1986, and the number declined to 68 in 1989. This year, Iceland shut down its whaling operation entirely, but it continues to press vigorously for a resumption of commercial killing of fin, sei and minke whales. Congress has passed several laws that allow the United States to impose economic sanctions against countries that violate whaling commission regulations. Iceland's critics have argued that the scientific whaling is merely commercial whaling under another name, and have pressed the United States to impose sanctions. The United States might be reluctant to do so, however, because Iceland is the site of a strategic NATO base. Payne said the methods used to estimate whale populations are highly imprecise, and that the Icelandic scientific research has ``shown us nothing we didn't know before.'' It could take as long as 100 years to know how many whales can be captured without reducing the size of a given whale population, he said. DOC.HEAD: The Showdown: Iceland Battles for Its Embattled Whaling Industry
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, AP Graphic
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Weary of being portrayed as environmental outlaws for killing whales, Icelanders are fighting back. In the first of two stories detailing the whaling controversy, AP Science Editor Paul Raeburn examines Iceland's efforts to overturn an international moratorium on commercial whaling and protect a way of life. ---

In a 1989 Icelandic television documentary entitled ``Survival in the High North,'' Icelanders talk about the difficulty of making a living on what they call ``the border of the habitable world.'' A villager who hunted minke whales until a moratorium on commercial whaling says, in apparent puzzlement, ``It seems to be incredibly important to stop catching a few minke whales here every year, but it doesn't seem so important to the world that it is being destroyed by nuclear pollution and that people are being killed all over the planet.'' The villager's lament is heard often in a land where whaling has been a way of life for centuries. This year, for the first time since the 1940s, Iceland abandoned whaling, part of a carefully plotted campaign to overturn the moratorium. Iceland, one of the three major whaling nations along with Norway and Japan, wants to kill whales again. ``The whaling industry means to Iceland what the auto industry means to the U.S.,'' said Guthni Bragasson, spokesman for Iceland's Foreign Affairs Ministry. Whaling is a small part of the overall economy, but an important one. But a more telling reason might be Iceland's very different point of view about the relationship between people and natural resources. Many people outside Iceland view whales as magnificent creatures worthy of protection; many Icelanders view them as just another ocean resource. When the moratorium on commercial whaling began in 1986, the aim was to give scientists time to determine whether they could set quotas that would allow whaling without endangering the mammals' survival. Iceland immediately exploited a whaling commission loophole by beginning a program of ``scientific whaling,'' arguing that it couldn't assess the status of its whale populations without killing and examining a number of whales. That prompted Greenpeace to launch a boycott of Icelandic fish products. Picket lines appeared outside restaurants in the United States operated by Burger King, Wendy's and Long John Silver's, which purchased Icelandic fish. ``The Greenpeace campaign was very effective,'' said Gudmundur Hermannsson, a reporter who covers whaling for Morgunbladid, Iceland's largest daily newspaper. ``I have a feeling that if there hadn't been this pressure from Greenpeace, Iceland this year would have announced a new scientific whaling program.'' At the International Whaling Commission's meeting in July, Iceland presented evidence that its whales aren't endangered, setting the stage for a showdown at the next meeting, to be held in May in Reykjavik, Iceland's capital. ``If they don't accept some whaling, they're not following the scientific evidence,'' said Jakob Jakobsson, director of the country's Marine Research Institute. ``If they are protecting whales because they are nice, then why do Minnesotans shoot deer? And why does the royal family hunt fox? And why does the King of Sweden come here to shoot reindeer, which he doesn't even eat?'' Jakobsson is eager to press the point to anyone who will listen; he sees his country as David fighting the Greenpeace Goliath. ``There was no way we could compete with Greenpeace in the media,'' Bragasson said. Indeed, Greenpeace was honored in August by the Better World Society ``for using the media and other methods of communication in the most creative and innovative ways.'' Are the Icelanders environmental outlaws, as Greenpeace calls them? Why do they continue whaling in the face of widespread international condemnation? ``Our main point is that these are exploitable animals,'' said Johann Sigurjonsson, the senior whale specialist at the Marine Research Institute. ``Nobody in Iceland wants to wipe out the whales. Nobody wants to wipe out any species.'' Iceland's population of 250,000, spread thinly along the coast of a largely uninhabitable volcanic island the size of Virginia, has depended almost entirely on the sea for survival since the country was settled by Norsemen and Celts in the 9th century. Icelanders had been hunting whales for 600 years before Herman Melville chronicled Capt. Ahab's fateful pursuit of Moby Dick in the 19th century. An illustration in the 13th century Icelandic book of law called the Jonsbok shows a whale being ``flensed,'' or having its blubber peeled off. Iceland's fisheries now account for about 75 percent of its exports, providing vital foreign exchange for a nation that must import nearly all of its manufactured goods. Before the whaling moratorium, whale products made up about 2 percent of Iceland's exports, Sigurjonsson said. Iceland takes pride in its careful stewardship of its marine resources, and that might be the one point on which Iceland and Greenpeace agree. ``Greenpeace has said repeatedly that Iceland does have one of the better-managed fisheries in the world,'' said Sally Shoup, a Greenpeace whale specialist in Washington. ``We want to have the responsibility for management of our resources, because we are the party that will be hurt if the resources are overexploited,'' Sigurjonsson said. ``People have been saying, `OK, if we are not allowed to take care of the whales in our waters, what will be next?' '' In 1916, Iceland's parliament, the Althing, banned most whaling because of concerns about the depletion of whale stocks. Whaling resumed briefly in 1935 until it was interrupted by World War II. The present whaling operation began in 1948 in Whale Fjord, a deep gorge on Iceland's eastern coast, north of Reykjavik. The whaling station consists of a half-dozen red-roofed, yellow brick buildings on a hillside overlooking a broad concrete pier. Whales are hoisted up a wide metal ramp onto the pier, where they are cut up and processed. The station was nearly deserted during this summer's whaling season, the first summer since 1948 that the fjord hadn't resounded with the rumble of winches and cables and the shouts of whaling men. The action this year was in the Netherlands, at the whaling commission's meeting. There, Sigurjonsson and other Icelandic officials argued that the whales they want to hunt are not endangered in Icelandic waters. The whales in question are fin whales, sei whales and small whales called minke whales, which are hunted by 50 or 60 families in Iceland but not by the operation at the whaling station.

DOC.HEAD: WHALE FJORD, Iceland: whaling station.
DOC.TEXT: Minke whales topped the agenda this year. The minke population around Iceland, East Greenland and Jan Mayen, a small island northeast of Iceland, is estimated at 28,000, Sigurjonsson said. For 40 years, Icelanders have killed 200 to 300 minke whales a year. Sigurjonsson has concluded that the effect on the population has been negligible and would not drive minke whales to extinction. The data on fin whales will be addressed by the whaling commission next year. Sigurjonsson estimates 11,500 fin whales are in the East Greenland-Iceland stock. The annual catch of 230 to 240 fin whales could resume without damage to the stocks, he said. Less is known about sei whale stocks, but the killing of 60 to 70 animals per year ``appears not to have substantial impact on the stock,'' Sigurjonsson said. ``But I stress that we have not completed our study on that.'' These numbers have been derived in part from Iceland's scientific whaling program. Greenpeace and other critics have contend the killing of whales is not necessary to estimate populations. Scientific whaling is nothing more than commercial whaling by another name, they say. ``That's a very unfair statement,'' Sigurjonsson said. ``We believe that lethal research is necessary for certain types of investigations.'' Fin whales, for example, dwell not in coastal waters but offshore. ``It's pretty rough out there,'' Sigurjonsson said. ``If you want to know the age distribution, and particularly age at maturity, and the fecundity rate, the quickest way is to sample.'' Iceland will make a pitch for resumption of minke and fin whaling next spring, with the completion of studies on the fin whales. If the International Whaling Commission doesn't allow Iceland to resume whaling, the country is threatening to withdraw from the commission. Then, it no longer would be bound by the moratorium. But even if Iceland's efforts to prove its whales are not endangered ultimately succeed, it's not likely that international opposition would dissolve. Sigurjonsson has acknowledged the widespread belief outside Iceland ``that because whales are so intelligent and highly developed, they have the same right as human beings to live without being harvested.'' That view is held by one of Iceland's most important trading partners and, on this issue, one of its most formidable opponents: the United States government.

DOC.HEAD: United's Parent Places Order with Boeing Worth Up to $22 Billion
With PM-Boeing 777, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines has ordered as many as 128 new Boeing airplanes - a deal potentially worth a record $22 billion - in hopes they will help it reach more destinations more frequently and more efficiently. The agreement includes firm orders for 34 Boeing model 777s and 30 Boeing 747-400s, with a total value of about $11 billion. In addition, United has the option to purchase an additional 34 model 777s and 30 model 747-400s. If all those options were exercised, the total value of the purchase would swell to at least $22 billion and make it the largest order in history. Assembly on the 777s is to start in late 1992. As they are delivered, United said, they will replace the company's DC-10 planes on domestic routes and provide expansion capacity. Delivery of the 747-400s would start in 1994. A number of 747-400s from a previous order are expected before that and will be used for continued expansion of United's international market. Stephen Wolf, chairman of Chicago-based UAL Corp., United's parent company, said the company would more than double its service to Europe in 1991 by adding destinations. For United customers, Wolf said, the order means ``more service to more destinations in the world's newest, most modern and efficient aircraft.'' ``For our shareholders, it means more revenue growth'' to be reflected in increased shareholder value. ``In short, it will ensure that this company is positioned to compete aggressively around the world,'' Wolf said. The announcement of the deal on Monday was followed by the U.S. Department of Transportation decision to give the airline authority to operate a nonstop Chicago-Tokyo route. The aircraft deal includes Boeing's new 777 model, the first-ever order for that plane, and represented a significant coup for Boeing over its leading competitors, McDonnell Douglas Corp. and Airbus Industrie of Europe. It also came a week after a protracted employee effort to buy United failed, and seemed to signify an attempt by one of the nation's leading airlines to refocus attention on its long-term competitive position. Wolf declined to discuss plans for financing the order. But he said it wouldn't affect employee contract negotiations. ``We don't intend to ask them to make concessions to pay for the fleet,'' he said. ``We anticipate raises.'' Wolf said the expansion ``provides a sense of security'' for United's 74,000 employees. The largest order in the industry, excluding options to purchase aircraft, is $16.8 billion, made in April 1989 by an Ireland-based aircraft leasing company, GPA Group Ltd. It ordered a total of 308 planes from Boeing, Airbus Industrie and McDonnell Douglas.

DOC.HEAD: Early-October Sales Fell 2.1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: A 2.1 percent decline in early-October sales of North American-made vehicles doesn't give much of a clue about the state of the auto industry, analysts say. During the Oct. 1-10 period this year, General Motors Corp.'s car sales soared 15.9 percent from a year earlier, Ford Motor Co. sales sank 23.8 percent and Chrysler Corp. sales gained 2.6 percent from last year. ``There's almost no way of reading the numbers,'' said auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. ``We're going to need - to get a sense of where this market is - another couple of 10-day reporting periods.'' The 10 major companies making cars and trucks in the United States said they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 30,096, compared with a rate of 30,734 during the same time last year. Car sales, spurred by the big GM increase, rose 1.9 percent while truck sales dropped 9.5 percent. Car sales by the Big Three dropped 1.5 percent while sales of domestically made cars with Japanese nameplates rose 42.6 percent. GM, Ford and Chrysler had 89.4 percent of the domestic car market in early October. The companies together have been battling a slumping sale rate ever since the 1989 model year technically ended Sept. 30, 1989. During the last quarter of 1989, the sales rate fell to its lowest levels of the year. Car and truck sales rates tend to drop in early October mainly because of the deals offered in September as the model year closes out. GM was particularly aggressive with incentives in September 1989, making cars and trucks more attractive to consumers who had planned on buying later in the year. Consequently, GM's early-October combined car and truck sales pace last year was particularly low. A year-to-year comparison showed a 13.3 percent rise in GM's early-October sales. Ford's car and truck sales fell 21.3 percent in early October and Chrysler's dropped 10.8 percent. That bucks a trend of GM and Ford being down slightly and Chrysler's down more. ``There's a lot of noise in the numbers,'' said Ford sales analyst Joel Pitcoff. For the year through Oct. 10, domestic car and truck sales were down 4.6 percent, with car sales falling 5.1 percent and truck sales off 3.7 percent. GM's sales were down 5 percent, Ford's were off 9.1 percent and Chrysler's declined 14.6 percent. Sales figures are being affected by a wide variety of things - a slump in the general economy, declining consumer confidence, rising gasoline prices, big incentives on 1990 model cars and little ones on '91 versions and purchases by fleets, including rental car companies and large corporations. Chrysler, which recently returned to the fleet business, has shown increases in its car sales during the last two periods. The company said its combined car and truck sales for early October were 10.8 percent lower than last year, with car sales rising 2.6 percent and truck sales dropping 26 percent. Ford said its early October car sales fell 23.8 percent and truck sales were down 17.2 percent, combining for a 21.3 percent decline in vehicle sales. GM said its vehicle sales were up 13.3 percent over last year. In addition to the 15.9 percent increase in car sales, GM's light truck sales were up 7.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: State Announces Largest Automaker Refund Concession in Nation's History
DOC.TEXT: A settlement between the state and 12 major automakers will provide up to $100 million in refunds to consumers under the state's ``Lemon Law.'' The settlement announced Monday was believed to be the largest such refund ever by automakers and could set a precedent for other states, officials said. Within the next month, automakers will place advertisements detailing the details of the refund plan in major New York newspapers. The ads will run for six weeks and consumers have 4{ months to respond. The settlement covers all New York residents who bought or leased new cars after Aug. 2, 1986, and who were forced to pay for repairs that should have been covered by warranty. The repair must have been made after the manufacturer's basic warranty expired (normally duringthe first 12 months or 12,000 miles, whichever came first), but before the first 24 months or 18,000 miles, or whichever came first. The state's ``Lemon Law'' requires manufacturers and their dealers to make repairs under their warranty, at no cost to the customer, for a period of two years or 18,000 miles, whichever comes first. State Attorney General Robert Abrams said Monday that the settlement was the result of a ``long-fought effort'' of four years to get the auto manufacturers to agree on the terms. The car makers who entered into the agreement are: Chrysler, Ford, General Motors, Honda, Hyundai, Isuzu, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Subaru, Toyota and Volvo. Each company also paid the state $10,000 in costs, for a total of $120,000. But they did not admit wrongdoing in signing the settlement. Car makers such as Mercedes-Benz were not included in the settlement because their warranty programs are broader than the state's lemon law, Abrams said.

DOC.HEAD: Itel Sells Container Business To Buy Back Shares From Henley
DOC.TEXT: Itel Corp. announced it will buy back the 18.7 million shares owned by the Henley Group, Inc., using proceeds from the sale of its container business. Itel said Monday it will sell the container operation to General Electric Capital Corp. for $825 million. The deal will return to Itel a 38.5 percent stake it gave Henley in 1988 in exchange for a 17 percent share of Santa Fe Pacific Corp. and other assets. In the 1988 deal, the Itel shares represented about $373 million of a $1.2 billion transaction. Chicago-based Itel said it is buying back the shares for $375 million. Itel said the sale of its container leasing and servicing assets will result in a pre-tax earnings gain of about $250 million. The stock repurchase will ``provide an excellent opportunity to maximize shareholder value,'' Itel President Rod Dammeyer said in a statement. The sale will leave Itel with interests in railcar leasing, dredging services, and wire and cable distribution. Henley's principal business is laboratory and medical equipment. It has headquarters in La Jolla, Calif., and Hampton, N.H. G.E. Capital Corp., based in Stamford, Conn., is buying the container business on behalf of its Genstar Container Corp. subsidiary, based in San Francisco. Itel's stock rose 87{ cents to $11.87{ a share Monday on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Three Americans Capture Economics Nobel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16 grafs for grafs 9-16 pvs to UPDATE with quotes, edit for transition. Picks up 17th pvs ``The economics prize ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three American pioneers in financial economics and corporate finance won the 1990 Nobel prize in economics today. It was the seventh time in 10 years the award, given by the Swedish Academy of Sciences, has gone to Americans. Harry Markowitz of the City University of New York was cited for developing the theory of portfolio choice, the academy said. Merton Miller of the University of Chicago was honored for his ``fundamental contributions to the theory of corporate finance.'' William Sharpe of Stanford University won for his contributions to the theory of price formation for financial assets, the so-called Capital Asset Pricing Model, the academy said. The three will divide the $700,000 prize. Since 1969, when the prize was first awarded, 18 of the 30 winners of the economics prize have been Americans. The announcement of the prize was delayed for more than 45 minutes, while the academy tried unsuccessfully to reach Markowitz, who was in Japan. Miller and Sharpe, the laureates the academy reached by telephone, were ``really stunned,'' said Professor Assar Lindbeck of the Swedish Academy of Sciences. He said they asked about the exchange rate between the dollar and the kronor. ``We wanted to give the prize for pioneer work, innovators,'' said Lindbeck. He said financial markets has been one of the hottest areas for economic research in the past 10 years. Most of the prizewinners' work was done in the 1950s and 1960s. Their theories began to be used in the early 1970s, he said. ``Each of them (the winners) gave one building block'' to the financial market theory, Lindbeck said. ``The theory would have been incomplete if one of them had been missing. Together they created a complete picture of theory for the financial market which has had great importance in research and education.'' Most previous prizes have been awarded for broader areas of research, Lindbeck said. The working of financial markets is a specialized field. ``Financial markets serve a key purpose in a modern market economy by allocating productive resources among various areas of production,'' the academy said. To a large extent, it is through financial markets that savings in different sectors of the economy are transferred to firms for investments in buildings and machines, the academy said. It also said, ``Financial markets reflect firms' expected prospects and risks, which implies that risks can be spread and that savers and investors can acquire valuable information for their investment decisions.'' Markowitz, 63, a native of Chicago, made ``the first pioneering contribution in the field of financial economics'' in the 1950s, the academy said. He developed a theory for households' and companys' allocation of financial assets under uncertainty, the so-called theory of portfolio choice. The theory analyzes how wealth can best be invested in assets that differ in their expected return and risk. It therefore helps reduce risk. Miller, 67, a native of Boston, made the most important achievements in the theory of corporate finance and the evaluation of companys on markets, said the academy. Miller initially collaborated with 1985 economics prize-winner Franco Modigliani of the United States. The theory explains the relation, or lack of relation, between companys' capital asset structure and dividend policy on one hand, and their market value on the other. ``I'm delighted to accept it, and I'm still in a state of shock,'' Miller said in a radio interview this morning. ``Our work was always known as the Modigliani-Miller propositions of corporate finance,'' he said. ``He then won it for his contributions with me but also for his other work in economics. ``They've already recognized the work once and now I'm getting the other half,'' he said. Sharpe, 56, a native of Cambridge, Mass., was the leading figure among several researchers in the 1960s who used Markowitz's portfolio theory as a basis for developing a theory of price formation for financial assets, the academy said. That was the so-called Capital Asset Pricing Model. The economics prize is the only Nobel award established to complement the five prizes that dynamite-inventor Alfred Nobel created in his will at the end of last century. It was instituted in 1968 by Sweden's Central Bank. Nobel's original prizes in physics, chemistry, medicine, peace and literature have been awarded since 1901. The economics prize is awarded by the same body that awards Nobel's physics and chemistry prizes. It follows the same guidelines, including Nobel's wish that the prize shall be awarded to those who have ``conferred the greatest benefit on mankind.'' The Nobel physics and chemistry prizes are to be announced Wednesday. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was awarded the peace prize on Monday. The prizes are presented Dec. 10, the anniversary of Nobel's death in 1896. The peace prize is given in Oslo, and the others in Stockholm.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Falls Eight for Latest Week
DOC.TEXT: California led a decline for the week in the number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States, which dipped by eight this week to 1,056, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The Houston-based toolmaker reported Monday the count remained above that for the same week a year ago, when there were 981 working rigs. Last week, Baker Hughes reported an increase of 17 rigs to 1,064, working wells. California reported a loss of six rigs for the week, followed by Texas and North Dakota, which each lost three; Oklahoma and Michigan, which each dropped two, and Colorado, which dropped one rig. Baker-Hughes has kept track of the rig count, the widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Louisiana showed the most gains for the week, with an additional five rigs operating there. Kansas and Wyoming each added three rigs for the week; New Mexico increased by two rigs; while Pennsylvania added one. The count for Ohio remained unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Douglas Aircraft To Lay Off 1,200 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Aircraft Co. will lay off 1,200 workers at its Long Beach and Torrance facilities this year and hopes to reduce its work force by another 1,500 employees in 1991, a company executive said. Layoff notices will be distributed this week to supervisors, salaried workers and some unionized hourly employees, said Joe Pirkle, chief financial officer. The ranks of aircraft assembly workers will not be reduced, he said Monday. The layoffs will take effect in December, Pirkle said. The aerospace firm plans to reduce its work force by another 1,500 employees next year through attrition, he said. Beset by slumping defense spending, Douglas already had laid off 5,000 workers and 2,200 contract employees since May. The layoffs are part of a $700 million cost-cutting program ordered by Douglas' parent company, McDonnell Douglas Corp. of St. Louis. Douglas employs about 46,500 workers at its headquarters and final assembly facility in Long Beach and its Torrance fabrication plant.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Company Hires Salomon Bros. To Market Its Bahamian Property
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc. has taken a step toward selling its three hotels and one casino in the Bahamas, but the company says no sale is imminent. The casino company announced Monday the hiring of Salomon Brothers investment firm to help sell its Paradise Island properties because of its experience selling hotel and resort properties, said Resorts spokesman Andy Brimmer. That includes the sale last year of more than 500,000 rooms in the U.S. hotel industry, Brimmer said. Resorts officials told the state Casino Control Commission in August that they expect to sell the properties by December 1991, two months before the casino company's license comes up for renewal. Resorts anticipates the sale would generate between $250 million and $300 million. Prior to their August approval of a debt-for-equity plan to take Resorts out of bankruptcy, state casino commissioners said the Paradise Island sale was crucial to the success of Resorts' restructuring. Resorts also retained Salomon Brothers last year as bankruptcy advisors. Brimmer said a sale was not imminent and that the December 1991 target remains viable, although the latest possible sale date would be within four years. ``I do think that they plan to sell it in a fairly timely manner,'' Brimmer said Monday. ``They're not going to make any rash decisions.'' He discounted the prospect of trying to sell a casino company when gaming revenues are flat and indications are that the country may be heading into a recession. ``It's being sold on a global basis. It's nt affected by local economic problems,'' Brimmer said. ``This is the crown jewel.'' Resorts' Atlantic City property - Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel - recorded a profit of $2.7 million on gross revenue of $59.2 million for the quarter ending June 30, the latest period for which figures were available. Overall, Resorts International posted net earnings of $803,000 on revenues of $109.1 million for the second quarter. Like the rest of the Atlantic City gaming industry, Resorts Casino Hotel has lost business as a result of the recession and the April opening of the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort. Last month, Resorts posted gross gaming revenues of $17.9 million - a 12.9 percent decline from the $20.5 million recorded in September 1989. Salomon Brothers director Charles Masson said he would not comment on a price for the Bahamian properties but shared Brimmer's optimism that a sale would occur. ``Clearly, it's in the company's best interest to sell the property as soon as possible,'' Masson said. ``The environment for selling these types of properties is obviously not the best.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI, Education Department Join In Investigation of Sallie Mae Office
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials have begun an investigation of the Student Loan Marketing Association office in Lawrence, Kan., to determine if it bought worthless loans to inflate assets and boost the company's stock price, an FBI spokesman said. Max Geiman, spokesman in the FBI's Kansas City office, said Monday that agents with the Education Department's Inspector General's Office in Kansas City and the FBI started a joint criminal investigation three weeks ago. He said it began after two former employees filed a lawsuit alleging fraud within the loan servicing and purchasing procedures of the association, commonly called Sallie Mae. ``The purpose is to determine if there has in fact been any violation of any criminal laws,'' Geiman said. He said the investigation could be lengthy, given the complexity of Sallie Mae, which holds $18 billion in student loans, making it the nation's largest purchaser of government-backed student loans. The Lawrence operation is one of five Sallie Mae loan servicing centers. Gisela Vallandigham, a spokesman at Sallie Mae's headquarters in Washington, D.C., denied the allegations and declined to comment on the investigation. Geiman said the investigation is the result of the lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Kansas City, Kan., by Diana Crossfield and Brenda Albright, former managers at Sallie Mae's Lawrence office. Ms. Crossfield was once the second-highest ranking manager at the center. She and Ms. Albright allege they were forced to resign last year after telling top management about irregularities in Sallie Mae's methods. The two allege that Sallie Mae bought large numbers of void and canceled student loans from banks, and employees were instructed to log those loans into the ledger, even though the student borrowers clearly owed nothing. They say that loans that had lost their federal guarantees were purchased and put on the books, even though they stood to cost Sallie Mae money if the borrower defaulted. Further, they contend Sallie Mae told students their accounts were delinquent when they were current, in an attempt to collect more money. Their complaint does not indicate how large the problem was, or whether the alleged practices were common outside the Lawrence servicing center. Ms. Crossfield and Ms. Albright said they discovered the problems during internal auditing ordered by management. Worried that recognition of those problems would result in lost revenue that would devalue Sallie Mae's stock, those supervisors allegedly stopped the investigation and forced out the two women. Besides Sallie Mae, the lawsuit names nine individuals as defendants, including Edward Fox and Lawrence A. Hough, the past and present presidents of Sallie Mae, respectively. The lawsuit alleges securities fraud, as well as wire and mail fraud in a civil complaint brought under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The suit also alleges equal pay violations in which female supervisors were paid less than their male counterparts. Sallie Mae denies allegations contained in the suit, saying it has investigated the claims and finds no merit. Bankers who allegedly sold the bad paper also deny selling Sallie Mae void and canceled loans. Ms. Crossfield and Ms. Albright filed suit for wrongful dismissal on Sept. 14. Sallie Mae has not responded to the complaint in court filings. Reports on the suit prompted federal investigators to approach the women for further information. The two have declined to speak publicly about the allegations in their lawsuit. Student loans are guaranteed and subsidized by the federal government. Banks originate the loans, but then sell them to a secondary lender such as Sallie Mae. Typically, a bank sends a two-party check to the student's school before reselling the loan. With the student's signature on the check, financial aid officers then cash them to pay tuition and fee. If a student fails to enroll or doesn't qualify for the loan for some reason, the loan is canceled.

DOC.HEAD: Union, USX Open Contract Talks
