DOC.TEXT: The United Steelworkers of America will ask USX Corp. for a $1.25-per-hour raise, the union said as talks began on a new contract for 18,000 workers. USX, the nation's largest steel maker, hasn't revealed what terms it will seek in the negotiations which opened Monday. The old contract expires Feb. 1. The union has said it wants USX to fall in line with other steel makers who restored pay cuts that workers absorbed during the industry's decline in the early 1980s. According to Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm, USW District 15 director and chairman of the union negotiating committee, USW will ask USX to raise pay $1.25 an hour. USX workers make an average of $10.82 to $10.87 an hour, excluding benefits. Companies that have agreed to reinstate pay concessions are Bethlehem Steel Corp., National Steel Corp., Armco Inc. and the financially ailing Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. and LTV Steel Co. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry and Thomas J. Usher, president of the company's steel division, have said the company will stand alone in talks and ignore agreements struck with competing steel makers. ``We're optimistic we can get an agreement in this early bargaining process that will be in the interest of all concerned, the company and its employees,'' said Thomas W. Sterling, USX's chief negotiator. Palm has said the union will ask USX to pay into an industry-wide job training fund if the company schedules excessive overtime. The other steel makers have accepted the penalty, he said. The talks began 3{ months before the four-year contract's Feb. 1 expiration. Normally negotiations start a month or two before contracts expire. USX makes steel in Braddock, Irwin and Fairless Hills; South Chicago, Ill.; Gary, Ind.; and Birmingham, Ala. It mines iron ore in Minntac, Minn. The company operates several joint ventures, including a partnership with Japan's Kobe Steel in Lorain, Ohio. Workers at those plants are being included in the talks for the first time.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Economists Surprised By Nobel Honor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 5 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `Miller was ... with comments from Markowitz. Picks up 4th graf pvs: `Miller of...'; DELETES outdated 12th graf pvs: `Markowitz, 63 ...' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nobel-Economics
DOC.TEXT: University of Chicago economist Merton Miller said he initially thought it was a crank call when he was told he had won the 1990 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today. ``I'm delighted to accept it, and I'm still in a state of shock,'' Miller said this morning. Miller was one of three U.S. economists to win the 1990 Nobel prize in economics. He will share the $700,000 prize with Harry Markowitz of the City University of New York and William Sharpe of Stanford University. Markowitz, 63, a Chicago native cited for developing the theory of portfolio choice, said he gave up any hopes of winning the Nobel prize nine years ago when Yale University Professor James Tobin was honored for work on another facet of portfolio theory. ``I'd thought it was never going to happen,'' Markowitz said after news that he had won the 1990 prize reached him in Tokyo, where he starts teaching a class at Tokyo University on Wednesday. ``There was a prize given to James Tobin, also in portfolio theory but applied more to economics and less to business administration than mine. ``I figured that's it. They've given the prize for portfolio theory.'' Markowitz's portfolio theory analyzes how wealth can be best invested in assets that differ in their expected return and risk. The theory involves use of computers and data bases and is used by large institutional investors in the United States, Markowitz said. Miller of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, was honored for his ``fundamental contributions to the theory of corporate finance.'' The Swedish Academy of Sciences said the 67-year-old Miller made the most important achievements in the theory of corporate finance and the evaluation of firms on markets. In a telephone interview, the Boston native said he got the news in an early-morning phone call and ``thought it was a crank call at first'' when he didn't hear anything on the line. But he said his ``heart kind of stopped a bit'' when he heard the news from the accented voice on the other end of the phone. He worked initially in collaboration with 1985 economics prize-winner Franco Modigliani of the United States. The corporate-finance theory explains the relation, or lack of one, among firms' capital asset structure and dividend policy on the one hand, and their market value on the other. ``Our work was always known as the Modigliani-Miller propositions of corporate finance,'' Miller said. ``He then won it for his contributions with me but also for his other work in economics. ``They've already recognized the work once and now I'm getting the other half.'' Sharpe, 56, a native of Cambridge, Mass., won for his contributions to the theory of price formation for financial assets, the so-called Capital Asset Pricing Model, the academy said. Since 1969, when the prize was first awarded, 18 of the 30 winners of the economics prize have been Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Delays Fare Increase, Announces Thanksgiving Companion Deals
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines said it will postpone an 8 percent fare increase that was scheduled to begin today and announced a Thanksgiving holiday deal for companion flights. Dave Messing, a spokesman for the Houston-based airline, said Continental has delayed its fare increase until Oct. 23 in hopes that competitors also will postpone increases. The higher fares will be Continental's third increase since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait that caused record increases in the cost of jet fuel. Since the start of the Mideast crisis, the spot price for jet fuel has jumped from about 57 cents a gallon to $1.42 a gallon, according to Aviation Daily. While other carriers have considered such a move, only sister-carrier Eastern has announced a similar increase. In addition, Continental said it is offering half-price companion fares for travel on off-peak days around the Thanksgiving holiday. Tickets must be reserved and purchased this week. Under the offer, travelers, purchasing a round-trip Max-$aver fare for travel on U.S. mainland routes, leaving Nov. 14, 15, 18, 19, 20, 22 and 23 can take along a companion at half price. Return travel is permitted Nov. 22 and 23 or Nov. 27-Dec. 13. ``We can make this offer because business travel normally slacks off for the entire Thanksgiving week, and holiday travel tends to be concentrated on just a few days,'' a spokesman said. ``That gives us the opportunity to make more discount seats available during the off-peak days.''

DOC.HEAD: USAir in Pact with Flight Attendants
DOC.TEXT: USAir and its flight attendants have agreed on a new 18-month contract after more than one year of negotations, the Association of Flight Attendants said today. ``The agreement represents a significant victory for USAir flight attendants in maintaining their industry-leading contract in the face of tough economic times,'' said Dee Maki, president of the union local representing workers at the Arlington, Va.-based airline. Terms of the contract for were not disclosed, pending ratification by the membership by mail ballots in late November, the union said. The company said the pact affects about 9,000 flight attendants. The tentative agreement was reached during negotiations Friday, the union said. A federal mediator had been involved in the talks since July.

DOC.HEAD: In First Test of Milken Evidence, Government Strikes Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th graf pvs with 3 grafs to UPDATE with testimony today; picks up 12th graf pvs, At issue. . .
DOC.TEXT: In the first public test of prosecutors' evidence against Michael Milken, three government witnesses failed to definitively link the junk-bond financier to a key stock manipulation charge. At a special hearing on unproven allegations against Milken, former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trader Peter Gardiner claimed Monday his ex-boss ``without a doubt'' manipulated Wickes Cos. stock in April 1986 - but he offered no direct evidence. Testifying with immunity, Gardiner also said he was told Milken had authorized an order that Drexel workers throw out documents after learning speculator Ivan Boesky was cooperating with the government's securities fraud probe that November. But Gardiner and two other government witnesses failed to state directly that Milken told Boesky - or ordered someone to tell Boesky - to buy large blocks of Wickes in an illegal bid to drive up the price as the government has charged. Milken, 44, was first linked to wrongdoing with Boesky almost four years ago. He pleaded guilty in April to six counts of conspiracy and fraud, but the special pre-sentencing hearing is the first time the government's voluminous case involving dozens of witnesses has been aired in a courtroom. The hearing is to give U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood more information about Milken's professional character before sentencing. The ex-head of Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., junk bond division faces up to 28 years in prison. Wood said it was unclear from Gardiner's testimony that Milken directly ordered a manipulation. She said Milken's statements, as quoted by Gardiner, were ``fairly ambiguous.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll said Milken was ``the only person there who could authorize these transactions'' and that despite the lack of a direct link to Boesky the April 23 activity stemmed from his leadership position and his admitted illegal relationship with Boesky. But the judge said: ``I can't just assume because he did something in one context that he did it here.'' Boesky's information led federal investigators to Milken, one of the most successful financiers of the 1980s and the biggest figure to fall in the prosecution of Wall Street corruption. The hearing in Manhattan federal court, scheduled to last two weeks, continued today with further testimony on Wickes, the first of three transactions to be discussed. Testimony was to resume Thursday. Prosecutors questioning former Drexel corporate finance executive Joseph Harch sought to show Drexel was motivated to help Wickes retire the preferred stock to keep the client's business for lucrative financings. But Harch said Wickes Chairman Sanford Sigoloff never asked Drexel to buy Wickes stock to help retire the issue. Harch also said he was never told by Milken to buy the stock. At issue is the purchase of 1.9 million shares of Wickes stock by Boesky late on April 23, 1986, which helped the price close above 6[ and meet a provision allowing the company to retire an expensive issue of preferred stock. Gardiner testified Milken asked traders to obtain so-called unsolicited orders from customers to buy Wickes - violating Drexel policy for trading in securities of clients. Then he said Milken told him, ``Peter, Wickes, 6[, 6[.'' ``He looked at me and there was no question he was directing me to find buyers of Wickes stock. . . . One thing I am sure of is that Wickes was manipulated that day at Milken's direction without a doubt,'' he said. Gardiner offered no evidence he had anything to do with getting Boesky to buy Wickes stock for Drexel. He said his customers didn't buy any Wickes. Another former Drexel trader, Cary Maultasch, last week also failed to link Milken to Boesky on Wickes, as did ex-Boesky trader Michael Davidoff. Gardiner contradicted testimony by Maultasch that Gardiner told him to ask Boesky's trading company to buy Wickes. Gardiner said he couldn't recall doing that. He said Milken asked him ``to call Cary and ask him to find out how many Wickes we had bought.'' The government alleges Boesky made the purchases secretly for Drexel. Gardiner also said he believed Milken had approved an order to junk-bond department workers to discard documents on the day Boesky's plea deal with the government was announced on Nov. 14, 1986. After Boesky's plea was announced, Gardiner said former junk bond executive Alan Rosenthal told traders to ``clean out your desks, get rid of anything that isn't nailed down ... and don't throw it in the company garbage. ... He said that he had talked to Mike.'' On the alleged document destruction, Gardiner conceded Milken's name often was used by other junk-bond workers even when Milken himself had not approved an order.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 12.1 Percent Profit Increase in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: A strong gain in space and aviation business keyed a 12.2 percent earnings increase at Honeywell Inc. in the third quarter, the controls maker said Tuesday. Counting a $3.3 million loss from the spinoff of a major portion of its defense business, Honeywell posted third quarter profits of $83.5 million, or $2.21 a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with $74.4 million, or $1.73 a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales increased 4.1 percent to $1.56 billion from $1.5 billion a year earlier. ``While we are concerned about the economic outlook, especially in the United States, our order rates remained positive in the third quarter,'' said James J. Renier, chairman and chief executive officer. Third-quarter operating profit for the company's space and aviation sector was $55.2 million, more than double the $26.9 million in 1989. The commercial flight systems, military avionics and space systems businesses all reported strong results, Renier said. Sales for the sector were $501.7 million, compared with $500.7 million in third-quarter 1989. Honeywell's industrial sector also gained in the third quarter with operating profits of $47.4 million, a 21.2 percent increase over the same period in 1989 when operating profits in the division were $39.1 million. Operating profits in the homes and buildings sector were $61.8 million, down from $62.6 million. Renier said the loss from the spinoff of Alliant Techsystems equaled 9 cents a share. A year ago in the third quarter the discontinued defense business earned $6.6 million for Honeywell, or 15 cents a share. Nine-month net income was $272.6 million, or $7.08 a share, up 28.5 percent from $212.1 million, or $4.92 a share, in 1989. Total sales for the first nine months of 1990 were $4.636 billion, up 4.2 percent from $4.449 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Airline Orders Jets
DOC.TEXT: The Brazilian airline Varig has placed orders for as many as 26 Boeing jetliners in a deal valued at up to $2.6 billion, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Tuesday. The order comes just one day after United Airlines placed what could amount to the largest commercial aircraft order in history: $22 billion for as many as 128 planes. The Varig deal includes firm orders for six 747-400s and eight 737-300s, totaling $1.3 billion, Boeing said in a release. It includes options for five 747-400s and seven 737-300s. The order is the largest in dollar terms of any Latin American carrier. In February Varig confirmed orders for 15 Boeing 737-300s valued at $450 million. The 747-400 is the world's largest commercial aircraft, seating up to 412 passengers. It can fly nonstop up to 8,400 miles. The 737-300 seats up to 128 passengers and can fly close to 3,000 miles nonstop. The announcement brings total orders of the 747-400 to 385, and for all 737 models to 2,842. Boeing orders for 1990, including United's order Monday, total 413 planes valued at about $38.7 billion.

Excluding that business, which makes such products as Woolite detergent and Black Flag bug spray, sales increased 5 percent, the company said. Specifically, the company reported a 10 percent rise in pharmaceuticals - its largest segment - and medical supplies and diagnostic products. Consumer health care sales fell 4 percent. DOC.HEAD: Three Sundstrand Executives Found Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday acquitted three former mid-level Sundstrand Corp. executives of wrongdoing in a scheme by the aerospace contractor to defraud the Pentagon. The verdicts ended the only prosecution of individuals so far in connection with Sundstrand's admitted fraud, for which the Rockford company paid the government nearly $200 million in a record settlement for such offenses. U.S. District Judge Prentice H. Marshall said he was satisfied the three defendants had done no wrong. But he said he was ``perplexed'' by the lack of other indictments, given Sundstrand's 1988 admission of corporate guilt. ``Why those who directed that behavior ... were not prosecuted baffles me,'' Marshall said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Keith Syfert declined to comment immediately after the bench trial ended. The defendants were Ray John Chapel Jr., former director of business planning; Ralph G. Hamann, former Sundstrand section manager for government contracts; and Joseph J. McCarthy, former vice president for finance and administration. Marshall found the men innocent of conspiracy to lie to the government and of concealing the alleged conspiracy. He acquitted them last week on charges of lying to the government. The trial began Sept. 10. McCarthy said there was no fraud at Sundstrand. ``In my opinion, Sundstrand paid $200 million for nothing,'' he said. He said that Sundstrand was ``extorted'' by a government threat of racketeering charges and that the company's leaders ``made a decision that dumped it all on me.'' Hamann said the verdict ``makes me wonder what in hell we were doing here. It just boggles my mind.'' In 1988, Sundstrand pleaded guilty to five counts of criminal fraud, admitting it had overbilled the Pentagon from May 1980 through August 1985. Sundstrand - which sells the Navy and Air Force generators and parts - admitted billing the government for such expenses as baby-sitting, golf, movies and snow plowing for executives. Sundstrand paid the government $199 million in fines and penalties - the largest such payment ever - and was suspended for nearly four months as a defense contractor.

DOC.HEAD: Hasbro Reports Higher Third-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new action figure dolls combined with a strong performance in Europe boosted Hasbro Inc.'s third-quarter earnings nearly 6 percent, the company announced Tuesday. The toymaker said it earned $33.1 million, or 57 cents per share, for the July-September quarter, compared with $31.3 million, or 53 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 11 percent to $448.8 million from $403 million. Alan G. Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive officer, said several new Hasbro toys enjoyed strong sales, including dolls based on the pop musical group New Kids on the Block and World Wrestling Federation characters. Hassenfeld said he was pleased with the results, but said much of Hasbro's growth came from overseas. Slumping domestic sales forced the company to lay off about 90 of its white-collar workers in Rhode Island last week. John T. O'Neill, Hasbro's chief financial officer, said strong sales in new product lines was ``replacing volume that's going away on other products.'' ``Domestically, New Kids, World Wrestling Federation, Cabbage Patch (dolls) all performed well,'' he said. ``But we needed those to perform well to basically have a flat domestic business from what we did a year ago.'' The third-quarter results were not enough to offset the company's earnings slump from earlier in the year. For the first nine months of 1990, Hasbro reported profits of $61.3 million, or $1.05 per share, down from $68.2 million, or $1.15 per share, a year earlier. Nine-month revenue rose to $1.03 billion from $992.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
Down and Out in Belgium
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Pierre Van Rossem was considered a guru of Belgium's stock market, a self-proclaimed financial whiz who reportedly managed $7 billion from international investors last year alone. He also loved to flaunt his own wealth, which he once put at $300 million: There was the fleet of red Ferraris he hauled to news conferences, the prestigious Formula One racing team he sponsored. But Van Rossem's empire became unglued over the summer, the apparent victim of a deal gone bad and overextension. Van Rossem, 45, recently spent a month and a half in jail - including his honeymoon - on charges of forgery and writing bad checks. The French photo company Kis accused him of not having enough money to cover a check for $54 million for a 12 percent stake in the company. ``I finally fell on my face,'' he said at a news conference over the summer, called to announce that his company Moneytron was broke. Moneytron has yet to file for bankruptcy. And earlier this month, Van Rossem said was negotiating to sell the company to an unnamed banking consortium in Singapore. In his heyday, Van Rossem boasted he knew a system to beat the stock exchange and futures market and his Moneytron forecasting system caught on among investors. Last year, he managed $7 billion from international investors, according to the Financial Times of London. It's not clear exactly how Van Rossem ran into his financial problems. He blames much of his woes on go-betweens of an unnamed U.S. broker, who, he says, failed to repay $362 million from a futures deal. He said about $200 million of that money belonged to clients. Today, Van Rossem says he lives off the profits from the clothing shop owned by his new wife, Rachidi. In fact, she had to put up the shop as collateral to pay the wedding bill, he said. Despite his personal misforutnes, Van Rossem remains ``an expert in the media game,'' said Hans Verstraeten, a communications professor at the Brussels University. His hulking figure, unaffected by 45 days of prison food, recently adorned the pages of Britain's Financial Times. His rasping, insolent voice is still in demand with talk show hosts. A recent magazine interview with him was advertised in advance in major newspapers. ``In a small country like this, not a lot has to happen before you stand out,'' said Verstraeten. ``He is the rebel who worked his way up and still mocks the rich,'' added Guy Mortier, editor of the magazine Humo, which featured Van Rossem on its cover recently. ``Maybe people will tire of him but I think he still has a long way to go.'' Van Rossem doesn't exactly cut the figure of a smooth operator. He is grossly overweight. His gray, straggly hair droops onto his chest. He smokes non-stop and in heated discussions - his usual style of conversing - white spittle forms in the corners of his mouth. As a guest on a popular television talk show recently, Van Rossem assailed an earlier guest - the mayor of a North Sea resort who wants to keep working class visitors out of his tony town - for making ``racist'' and ``criminal'' remarks about the working man. In 1989, when he owned the Onyx Formula One racing team, Van Rossem called one racing organizer a ``Nazi'' and another a ``shark.'' Born into a Catholic family whose bourgeois lifestyle he said he despised, Van Rossem became a Marxist as a student. With his capitalist ventures in shambles, he now calls himself an anarchist. Van Rossem said literature is his next domain. He wants to ``fill the void'' in modern literature in Belgium and the Netherlands with a thriller penned in prison. His novel, ``The State in a State of Decomposition,'' was released earlier this month. He also wrote a crude poem recently about his father describing him as having ``a mouth full of vinegar and slime.'' He and his father are no longer on good terms. On his tombstone he said he would like to have inscribed: ``Here lies Van Rossem. He made loads of money for others, but didn't keep a cent for himself.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Fall As Harvest Advances
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed modestly lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as harvest pressure prevailed over the mixed effects of a congressional compromise on a new crop program. DOC.HEAD: DeBartolo Ends Agreement Not To Seize Campeau Assets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES 10th graf to CORRECT that DeBartolo not running Campeau.
DOC.TEXT: Edward J. DeBartolo Corp., one of Campeau Corp.'s largest creditors, said Tuesday it will not extend an agreement that prevented it from seizing assets of the beleaguered Campeau without notice. Under the agreement, DeBartolo could not call in $480 million in loans to Campeau without giving nine days notice. DeBartolo had extended the agreement several times over the past year, but allowed it to expire Tuesday. Campeau spokesman Richard Wertheim said DeBartolo's decision meant a similar agreement with two Olympia & York Developments Ltd. subsidiaries involving a $260 million loan from those firms was also suspended. Wertheim said it was too soon to tell if Youngstown, Ohio-based DeBartolo would move on any Campeau assets, mainly Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. However, even if they did try to seize Campeau assets, most are tied up in Chapter 11 bankruptcy court proceedings now under way in the United States, Wertheim said. Campeau's Allied Stores Corp. is also going through the Chapter 11 process. ``We're continuing to talk,'' said Wertheim. ``He (Edward J. DeBartolo) has talked about various options. I hope we'll continue talking and see where it goes from there.'' Campeau borrowed $480 million from DeBartolo to help finance the $6.7 billion buyout of Federated in 1988. The buyout failed a year ago after Campeau was unable to make interest payments on junk bonds used to finance the Federated and Allied deals. After Federated filed for protection from its creditors, liability for the loan fell to Campeau, which had struck the loan agreement with DeBartolo. Wertheim has said Campeau Corp.'s strategy is to reorganize the U.S. operations under the Chapter 11 process, sell off a substantial portion of the company's real estate holdings in Canada and reach an agreement on restructuring the debt with the principal lenders, including DeBartolo and Olympia & York.

DOC.HEAD: No Progress on GATT-Farm Subsidy Cuts
DOC.TEXT: European Community nations remained divided Tuesday over a subsidy reduction plan designed to end a deadlock with the United States in talks to liberalize world trade. Officials said the EC agriculture ministers could not back a compromise under which the EC Commission would devise compensation measures aimed at offering ``a future to the Community's farmers.'' Sources said the compromise was rejected as too vague. France and West Germany were the strongest opponents to both the compromise and a 30 percent cut in subsidies, while Britain, the member most favoring free trade, supported the subsidy cuts. The issue is key to the success of the Uruguay round of talks to liberalize world trade, held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The talks are scheduled to end in December. The United States wants an elimination or drastic reduction in subsidies, saying they give an unfair advantage to farmers in EC member nations. But most EC states find as much as a 30 percent cut too drastic, arguing the subsidies are needed to help their farmers compete. The 30 percent cut would apply to such products as cereals, rice, sugar and livestock over the period 1986-1996, but not to subsidies for exports of EC farm goods. On Monday, the EC missed a GATT deadline to submit a formal proposal on subsidies while the United States issued a proposal calling for 90 percent cuts in export subsidies and 75 percent cuts in subsidies to farmers over 10 years, starting in 1991. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said in Washington Monday the United States ``simply concluded that in the next 10 years we may well not be able to get all the way.'' ``But let's go as far as we can,'' he added. Agricultural subsidies cost the industrialized world an estimated $250 billion a year, with just over half of that spent by the EC.

DOC.HEAD: Four Big Drug Companies Report Higher Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Four major U.S.-based pharmaceutical companies reported sharply higher third-quarter results Tuesday, led in part by strong sales growth at home and abroad for disease-fighting drugs. The results reported by Warner Lambert Co., Merck & Co., Eli Lilly and Co. and Pfizer Inc. also reflected the declining strength of the dollar, which inflates the value of sales in other countries when calculated in dollars.
DOC.HEAD: Warner-Lambert
DOC.TEXT: Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., said earnings for the three months ended Sept. 30 totaled $124.76 million or 93 cents a share, up 16.7 percent from $106.92 million or 79 cents a share a year in the 1989 third quarter. The year-earlier per-share figures were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split this past May. Third-quarter sales rose to $1.19 billion, a quarterly record, up 7 percent from $1.11 billion a year earlier. Joseph D. Williams, chairman and chief executive officer, attributed the results to the strength of the company's worldwide pharmaceutical business, led by prescription drug sales, notably in the cholesterol-regulating drug Lopid. Non-prescription drug sales also rose, paced by strong performance of Listerine mouthwash and Halls cough tablets. The gums and mints segment, which includes brands such as Certs, Chiclets and Sugar Daddy, fell slightly. For the nine months, Warner-Lambert said earnings totaled $379.54 million or $2.83 a share, up 18.5 percent from $320.36 million or $2.37 a share a year earlier. Sales totaled $3.44 billion vs. $3.15 billion, up 9.2 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Merck
DOC.TEXT: Merck, a Rahway, N.J.-based maker of health products and specialty chemicals, said third-quarter earnings rose 19 percent to $465 million or $1.19 a share, from $390.5 million or 99 cents a share a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose 17 percent to $1.91 billion from $1.63 billion a year earlier. The company reported gains in all operations and said there was particularly strong demand for its pediatric vaccine M-M-R II, which protects against measles, mumps and rubella. The Centers for Disease Control strengthened its recommended dosage of the vaccine in response to higher incidence of measles infections in the United States. For the nine months, Merck said earnings totaled $1.34 billion or $3.42 a share, up 18.5 percent from $1.13 billion or $2.85 a share a year earlier. Sales totaled $5.57 billion vs. $4.79 billion, up 16.3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Eli Lilly
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly, headquartered in Indianapolis, said third-quarter earnings rose 21 percent to a record $257 million or 90 cents a share, vs. $212.4 million or 73 cents a share a year earlier. Chairman Richard D. Wood attributed the strength to higher sales at home and abroad, led by demand for the antidepressant drug Prozac and other pharmaceuticals. For the nine months, Lilly earned $872 million or $2.99 a share, up 22 percent from $714.2 milloin or $2.45 a share a year earlier. Nine-month sales totaled $3.75 billion vs. $3.03 billion, up 23.7 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Pfizer
DOC.TEXT: Pfizer, a New York-based maker of health care and consumer products and specialty drugs, said third-quarter earnings totaled $243.3 million or $1.45 a share, up 12 percent from $217.5 million or $1.29 a share a year earlier. Quarterly sales totaled $1.64 billion vs. $1.44 billion, up 14 percent. The company said strong growth in pharmaceutical sales was paced by the cardiovascular agent Procardia XL and antifungal drug Diflucan. For the nine months, Pfizer said earnings totaled $646.4 million or $3.85 a share, up 8.8 percent from $594 million or $3.52 a share a year earlier. Sales for the period totaled $4.62 billion, up 10.5 percent from $4.18 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp's Profits Drop 38 Percent in Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp on Tuesday reported a 38 percent plunge in third-quarter profits as problem loans mounted, putting increasing pressure on the nation's largest banking company to restructure and rebuild its capital base. Separately, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. and First Interstate Bancorp reported a return to profitability while No. 12-ranked Wells Fargo & Co. said profits rose 6 percent. Citicorp's net income for the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $221 million, or 56 cents a share, down from $358 million, or 99 cents a share a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings in the 70 cent-a-share range. But Rick Mueller, a vice president with Chicago-based Duff & Phelps, noted that despite the worse-than-expected earnings, analysts are ``worried about other issues.'' What sparked concern was a 34 percent increase in problem loans - excluding debt to less-developed countries - which grew to $5.65 billion from $4.54 billion in the previous quarter. ``That's up significantly,'' Mueller said. Though analysts had expected an increase in Citicorp's non-performing assets, Mueller said the size of the increase makes it ``that much more difficult what they will have to do to take care of it.'' With capital levels below industry norms, Citicorp has been pressed to restructure. In recent months commercial businesses in the bank's global finance unit have been under review. But analysts anticipate a larger, companywide restructuring to take place involving significant cutbacks in personnel, asset sales, a possible stock issuance and trimming of the dividend. Surprisingly, the board declared a regular quarterly dividend of 44 cents a share. The announcement comes at a time when other major banks have been forced to scale cut payouts to shareholders to rebuild capital. Citicorp stock fell 25 cents to a $13.87{ share in late trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was the most actively traded issue. Experts have said relatively high dividends have served to support bank stocks as earnings eroded. Separately, interest revenue during the period totaled $7.3 billion, down 11 percent from $8.19 billion a year earlier. Interest expense amounted to $5.48 billion, down 13 percent from $6.32 billion in the year-ago quarter. Citicorp noted in a statement that it ``continued to be pro-active in recognizing loan losses and has been building its corporate reserve position to provide for possible further deterioration.'' The bank said that because the domestic real estate market has not yet stabilized, ``continued write-offs and `cost to carry' will extended into 1991.'' Citicorp said non-performing domestic commercial real estate loans totaled $2.18 billion, up from $1.17 billion in the third quarter of 1989. Loans to less-developed countries totaled $3.55 billion during the quarter, down from $3.58 billion in the previous quarter and $4.93 billion a year ago. For the nine-month period, Citicorp said profits totaled $700 million, or $1.81 a share, down 45 percent from $1.28 billion, or $3.62 a share in the first nine months of 1989. Interest revenue rose 4 percent to $23.68 billion from $22.68 billion while interest expense advanced 7 percent to $18.26 billion from $17.14 billion in the first nine months of last year.
DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Hanover
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers Hanover Corp. reported net income of $77 million, or 89 cents a share, compared with a loss of $789 million, or the equivalent of $15.46 a share a year ago, when the bank set aside $950 million to cover potential losses from shaky Third World loans. The nation's eighth-largest banking company, based in New York, said non-performing loans, excluding those to less-developed countries, increased to $985 million from $915 million in the previous quarter and from $833 million in the year-ago quarter. For the first nine months, net income totaled $206 million, or $2.41 a share, compared with a $580 million loss in the year-ago period, or the equivalent of $11.82 a share.
DOC.HEAD: First Interstate
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles-based First Interstate Bancorp said third-quarter profits totaled $155.4 million, or $2.39 a share, a turnaround from a $15.5 million loss, the equivalent of 57 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The recent quarter's results included a $90.1 million pre-tax gain from the sale of the company's consumer finance subsidiary. No. 9-ranked First Interstate said net income for the first nine months amounted to $377.7 million, or $6.02 a share, up 72 percent from $219.8 million, or $4.26 a share in the year-ago period.
DOC.HEAD: Wells Fargo
DOC.TEXT: Wells Fargo & Co., the No. 12 bank nationwide, said net income totaled $162.6 million or $3.03 a share, up from $153.7 million or $2.83 a share in the same period of 1989. Loan losses totaled $75 million, down from $82 million during the same year-ago quarter. For the first nine months, net income jumped 25 percent to $554.8 million or $10.48 a share, from $442.6 million or $8.07 a share a year ago. The San Francisco-based bank said the formation of Wells Fargo Nikko Investment Advisors, a joint venture with Nikko Securities Co. Ltd., created a $116.5 million pre-tax gain that helped boost earnings this year.

Prices declined broadly on Wall Street today as oil prices rose and disappointing earnings reports began to flow in. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 36.39 to 2,379.95.

DOC.HEAD: Hanson Swaps Newmont Mining Stake for Timber Company
DOC.TEXT: The British conglomerate Hanson PLC said Tuesday it had agreed to swap its 49 percent stake in Newmont Mining Corp. for control of a major U.S. timber company. Hanson said it agreed to buy General Oriental Securities Ltd. and Hornwood Barbados Ltd. of the United States for $1.3 billion in cash. Together, the two companies own 99.5 percent of Cavenham Forest Industries, the large U.S. timber company. Hanson said that at the same time it would sell its 49 percent stake in Newmont Mining Corp. of the United States to the owners of General Oriental and Hornwood for $1.1 billion in cash and $189 million in notes. The remaining 51 percent stake in Newmont is held by the public. Hanson acquired its stake in Newmont as part of its August 1989 purchase of Consolidated Gold Fields PLC for 3.3 billion pounds, or $6.5 billion. General Oriental Securities and Hornwood are controlled by companies associated with financier Sir James Goldsmith and British merchant banker Jacob Rothschild, sources close to the companies said, speaking anonymously. Hanson Chairman Gordon White said Cavenham's strong cash flow and profit record would enhance Hanson's natural resources interests. Cavenham owns or controls about 1.7 million acres of timberland in the U.S. West and South. In July, Hanson paid $1.2 billion for full control of Peabody Holding Co., the United States' biggest coal producer. Hanson has extensive interests in the United States, including SCM Chemicals, Grove Cranes, Jacuzzi whirlpool spas, Kaiser cement, and Ames Garden tools.

DOC.HEAD: Lufthansa Withdraws Application to Acquire Share in Interflug
DOC.TEXT: Lufthansa said Tuesday it has withdrawn its application to acquire a 26 percent stake in the former East German state airline, Interflug. Lufthansa, which is 51 percent-owned by the German government, said in a short statement that a ``changed situation exists'' since German unification on Oct. 3. It said because the Bonn government now owns the assets and shareholdings of the former East German state, the fact that both Lufthansa and Interflug are controlled by one major shareholder ``opens creative maneuvering room that must be considered.'' The statement provided no further elaboration. A spokesman at the company's headquarters said only that the changed political situation in Germany ``leaves all the options open'' regarding Interflug's future. He declined to comment on whether Lufthansa currently is negotiating with government officials in Bonn over business links with Interflug. Lufthansa and the Federal Cartel Office have been at odds over the airline's intention to expand broadly into eastern Germany. The office, in a preliminary opinion, recently informed Lufthansa of its reservations about the planned cooperation with Interflug on antitrust grounds. Lufthansa dominates its domestic market. Berlin-based Interflug serves what is now eastern Germany and is in dire need of a complete overhaul of its fleet, which consists mainly of aging Soviet airliners. Interflug recently was reported by the Hamburg-based weekly news magazine Der Spiegel to be on the verge of bankruptcy. The German government is said to be eager to sell off at least part of Interflug into private hands quickly.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Praise Farm Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, It was, to UPDATE with Yeutter statement. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists say they were heartened by the approval early Tuesday by a House-Senate conference committee of a $40.8 billion farm bill that enhances agricultural conservation. ``It's now an environmental statute,'' Ken Cook of the Center for Resource Economics said of the farm bill. ``We've made it one where it wasn't before.'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee and the conference committee, said the package was ``a mark of how environmental awareness is changing in this country.'' The committee, which has been working on the legislation for weeks, completed the bill after a 14-hour marathon of negotiations that ended Tuesday at 3:45 a.m. EDT. The major disappointment for environmental groups watching the lengthy negotiations was the omission of a ban on the export of pesticides that are outlawed or unregistered in the United States. ``They showed who they work for,'' Bill McNichol of the National Coalition Against Misuse of Pesticides said of the conferees. ``They had to make a choice between the economic interests of the chemical companies and the safety of consumers.'' ``It was an important provision that will be enacted someday soon,'' said Kathryn Hohmann of the Sierra Club. ``But we look at the other provisions in the bill and we see some gigantic strides.'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday he does not like everything in the bill and would have written it differently. ``But, in the end, it is a respectable work product that balances well innumerable sensitive, often divergent interests,'' he said in a statement. Agriculture Undersecretary Richard Crowder predicted President Bush would be satisfied with the bill. Leahy had made the pesticide export ban a personal crusade, but pulled it from the negotiating table when conference members tried to water down stringent language he had designed. The proposal had been intended to stop pesticides that are not used in the United States because of health concerns from showing up on the American dinner table as residue on imported food. But chemical companies lobbied hard against the plan, saying they would lose billions of dollars in overseas business and be forced to close manufacturing plants in the United States, wiping out hundreds of jobs. The National Agricultural Chemical Association pointed out that many pesticides manufactured here are unregistered because they are directed at pests that exist only in other countries. Leahy said he would introduce his plan as separate legislation next session. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the ranking Republican on the Senate Agriculture Committee, called the overall farm bill an ``excellent marriage'' of environmental and business concerns. ``It gives the American farmer a great deal of flexibility and freedom to plant,'' he said. ``It clearly is oriented to make us more competitive.'' Some of the planting flexibility in the bill was forced on the committee by the need to cut the federal budget by $500 billion over the next five years, including $13.6 billion from agriculture. ``You cross your fingers and hope that giving them flexibility will make up for the loss of support,'' said de la Garza. The bulk of the bill's budget savings would be achieved by requiring farmers of rice, feed grains, wheat and cotton to reduce the acreage protected by the government's support system by 15 percent in each of the five years of the measure. This so-called ``triple-base'' plan allows farmers flexibility to plant those commodities, experimental crops, industrial crops, or products not already in substantial supply. However, they would not be subsidized by the taxpayers. The government sends the farmer a check, known as a deficiency payment, when the market price falls below the government-established target price. The conferees agreed to calculate those payments on a 12-month basis, starting in 1994, instead of the current five months used for most crops. Since current calculations are based on the months immediately after harvest, when market prices are lowest, the government expects to save money by averaging the entire year. The conference committee also agreed to allow winter wheat farmers, who already are planting their crop, to choose between the triple base or the 12-month deficiency payment for 1991. Despite the decreases in subsidies these changes would create, the bill still provides $8 billion to $10 billion in support to farmers, said Leahy. Other savings would come from: -Setting marketing loans for soybeans at $5.02 a bushel with a 2 percent service charge. -Putting a 1 percent service charge on loans for sugar, peanuts, tobacco and honey. -Requiring reduction of 15 percent of acreage for the 1991 wheat crop and 7.5 percent of the corn crop. Other significant provisions include: -A $10.10 per hundredweight minimum support price on dairy products with a 5-cent assessment per hundredweight this year, rising to 11-cents in later years. -A limit of $100,000 on deficiency payments and $150,000 on marketing loans that can be received by a single farmer. -Continuation of the crop insurance program. -Forestry provisions designed to save millions of trees on private forest land. -Incentives to farmers who participate in programs to improve water quality around their farms and underground. -Strengthening of penalties against draining wetlands for crop production. -Procedures by which farmers could drain wetlands in the middle of their planting area if they create new wetlands on easements on their property. -Requirements that records be kept on pesticides that are being used.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Surges Ahead of Texas in Daily Oil Production
DOC.TEXT: Alaska has surged ahead of Texas as the nation's leading oil producer, topping the 2 million barrels-per-day mark for the first time since Prudhoe Bay began its decline in 1988, state officials said Monday. Texas, with a daily output of 1.7 million barrels of crude, is now the nation's Number 2 producer. ``The numbers got our attention,'' said Chuck Logsdon, chief petroleum economist with the Department of Revenue. Last summer, Alaska's crude oil production dropped to a low of 1.6 million barrels a day. Every 100,000-barrel-a-day increase in crude output, on an annualized basis, produces another $200 million in revenue for the state at current prices, he said. Nearly every oil field in the state has increased production during the past month, said Dudley Platt, petroleum economist with the Department of Revenue. ``Higher oil prices make people do crazy things,'' Platt said. ``A week ago a half million dollars was too much to spend on a well, this week they'll spend a million to get it done in a hurry,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Move Broadly Lower Amid Earnings Fears
DOC.TEXT: Prices declined broadly on Wall Street today as disappointing earnings reports and rising oil prices brought the stock market's two-day rally to an end. Stocks meandered for the first half of the session, but took a downward turn as third-quarter results began to flow in and oil prices advanced. Among the casualties were companies that announced their results today, but even firms that have yet to release their figures were hit. Just the fear of lower earnings was enough to make some traders sell, analysts said. Meanwhile, the November contract for delivery of light, sweet crude oil rose 94 cents to $38.89 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, worsening the outlook for inflation. Analysts said many traders were on the sidelines, waiting for September consumer price figures and the August trade deficit report due out Thursday morning. Today's decline - which was steepened in the last half-hour by computer-program trading - ended Wall Street's two-day rally. The Dow Jones industrial average had gained more than 51 points over Friday and Monday.
